#351SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3◊ Abynthe
Originally Posted by Kaij
Why is the generic "overall DK DPS compendium" thread closed? I feel there were several great contributions in there and yet the thread was locked and broken down into individual threads. Having one great DK DPS bible was oh-so useful
The massive bible threads were great if you already knew what was in them, and not-so-great if you wanted to find a single fact among the 100+ pages of discussion. Now at least you know which of the 5 odd threads (tanking, 3 trees, dw) are most likely to answer your question. I suspect the intent is that the content that used to live in the first post of the bible threads should move to the theorycraft think tank.
#352SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Teninches
Macro Questions?
Is there a way to bind Horn of Winter to an ability like say Blood Strike? I know you can bind trinkets with abailities but I wasn't sure about binding abilities with runic power to abilities without them.
#353SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3slant
You could do it with a castsequence and pound the button twice after waiting 1.5s for the GCD to finish, but why would you want to cast horn of winter every time you bloodstrike? That would be wasteful of both runic power and precious GCDs. In other words-- no, don't do that.
#354SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Noraj
Originally Posted by Teninches
Is there a way to bind Horn of Winter to an ability like say Blood Strike? I know you can bind trinkets with abailities but I wasn't sure about binding abilities with runic power to abilities without them.
As the above poster mentioned this would simply cast Horn of Winter every time you hit your Blood Strike button assuming you had 20 runic power available, or 10 if glyphed...Since Horn of Winter is on the global cooldown you definitely would need to use a /castsequence macro, and would still have to hit the button again at the end of the GCD to cast the next ability in the sequence.

Unfortunately as of 2.0.1, it is no longer possible to use boolean logic in macros or /script commands to initiate spellcasting, so creating a macro to only cast Horn of Winter if you do not already have the buff isn't possible.

The easiest way to keep it up for me has been to just bind it to a separate key, and reapply it during the RP dump of my rotation.

On a separate note, HoW gives the same buff at rank 2 as the highest rank of Strength of Earth Totem before the shaman puts any points into Enhancing Totems, and shouldn't stack under the new Wrath buff stacking rules, so depending on your raid, you may find that keeping HoW up is a moot point anyway.

If you're looking for an easier way to check and see if you have the buff, you might try Power Auras Classic : WoWInterface Downloads : Buff/Debuff/Spell Mods .

Originally Posted by Quon
Wondering how to gem as a Death Knight?

currently blood specc and having specially hard times to figure out the meta to use


if anyone could help me out with this and maybe suggestions on enchants it would be greatly appreciated
For DPS, your two best options are Chaotic Skyflare (21 crit rating + 3% crit damage) or Relentless Earthsiege (21 agility + 3% crit damage). Agility has the added benefit of upping your armor and if you have Bladed Armor, your AP slightly as well, while increasing your dodge too.

For tanking, there is either Austere Earthsiege (32 stam + 2% more armor from items) or Effulgent Skyflare (32 stam + 2% reduced spell damage taken).

Either one can be helpful depending on the situation, but if you're going for maximum spell damage reduction as a niche tanking role, go with the Effulgent Skyflare.
Last edited by Noraj : 12/01/08 at 1:07 AM.
#355SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kurenai
Does Acclimation get triggered only by spells (as the tooltip indicates) or does it also work against elemental based damage done by any elementals throughout Northrend (e.g. Fiery Elemental hits you for 1200 fire damage)?
#356SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Bashere
Originally Posted by Noraj
For DPS, your two best options are Chaotic Skyflare (21 crit rating + 3% crit damage) or Relentless Earthsiege (21 agility + 3% crit damage). Agility has the added benefit of upping your armor and if you have Bladed Armor, your AP slightly as well, while increasing your dodge too.
For DPS I'd assume the Chaotic Skyflare would be better, simply because Agility doesn't add to spell crit rating.

#358SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Noraj
Originally Posted by gospel
So, I'm confused. For a DRW spec, why is Annihilation better than Necrosis/BCB? And, why is Obliterate really that much better than Death Strike w/ the Glyph that does more damage per runic power? This seems against intuition so I'm assuming there's some heavy math behind this.
It's less about Obliterate and more about the fact that the second obliterate in the rotation grants you two extra death runes for more heart strikes instead of having to reapply diseases because the first obliterate removed them. With Epidemic, your diseases last just long enough to get the bonus damage on all four of the heart strikes at the end of the rotation.

Abilities: PS -> IT -> HS -> HS -> OB -> RP Dump
Runes: U -> F -> B -> B -> UF
Abilities: OB -> HS -> HS -> HS -> HS -> RP Dump
Runes: UF -> DR -> DR -> DR -> DR


As for glyphed DS vs. glyphed Oblit: Glyphed DS yields 60% weapon damage + 2% / 5 runic power for a total of 40% extra + 178. Max, that's weapon damage + 178. Glyphhed Oblit is 120% weapon damage + 350, with an additional 350 if both diseases are up.

x+178 > 1.2x+700

That's a very clear numerical difference unless I'm doing the math completely incorrectly.
Last edited by Noraj : 12/01/08 at 6:55 AM.
#359SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Petersen
Does the speed enhancement from "Unholy Aura" (the talent) affect mounted speed? I know the standard Unholy Presence speed modification is only run speed.

I really wish blizzard would clarify the tooltips to distinguis between Mounted, Run, Swimming, and Movement (all the the former) speed.
#360SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3◊ Bryne
Originally Posted by Petersen
Does the speed enhancement from "Unholy Aura" (the talent) affect mounted speed? I know the standard Unholy Presence speed modification is only run speed.

I really wish blizzard would clarify the tooltips to distinguis between Mounted, Run, Swimming, and Movement (all the the former) speed.
No. Unholy Aura affects your non-mounted movement speed only. Effects that change your movement speed don't affect "all the former" - they affect run speed only. I don't think any effects actually say "run speed" on them, and effects that boost your mounted speed say "mounted speed" specifically. It's much less complicated than you're making it out to be.
#361SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Petersen
Originally Posted by Bryne
No. Unholy Aura affects your non-mounted movement speed only. Effects that change your movement speed don't affect "all the former" - they affect run speed only. I don't think any effects actually say "run speed" on them, and effects that boost your mounted speed say "mounted speed" specifically. It's much less complicated than you're making it out to be.
I did not mean to imply I thought it was complicated. It is improper usage. "Movement speed" suggests the speed at which you move, the method of movement is unspecified, leading a logical person to presume it should apply to all forms of movement be it mounted movement, movement through water, or movement on foot. All are movement, all should be enhanced by something labeled "Movement speed".

They do indeed have specifically named Mounted Speed (and swim speed) enhancements. Of particular note is Pursuit of Justice "increases movement and mounted movement speed". Surely I cannot be the only one who finds that awkward if not redundant. Having it read "Increases run speed and mounted speed" would be much more elegant.
#362SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3slant
Originally Posted by Bryne
No. Unholy Aura affects your non-mounted movement speed only. Effects that change your movement speed don't affect "all the former" - they affect run speed only. I don't think any effects actually say "run speed" on them, and effects that boost your mounted speed say "mounted speed" specifically. It's much less complicated than you're making it out to be.
To clarify slightly, unholy aura will speed up mounts using the WOTLK vehicle system, including the traveler's tundra mammoth and engineering motorcycle, as you're essentially the vehicle's pet and thus in the same party.
#363SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Thiris
I have a question that I've been confused about for some time now. Are stat focuses heavily weighed to +hit for DW specs or are you attempting to settle around the +hit cap for special abilities? I can't say that I have specced DW yet, so I don't know what the damage breakdown is, but was curious if I should hold onto all of this +hit plate that I've been picking up.



Originally Posted by Teninches
Is there a way to bind Horn of Winter to an ability like say Blood Strike? I know you can bind trinkets with abailities but I wasn't sure about binding abilities with runic power to abilities without them.
The problem with tying a macro like that to an ability that you use a lot is that you are going to be using runic power like crazy and wasting it. Unfortunately there is no way to tie some sort of conditional to the macro since we cannot use "If XXX doesn't exist, cast YYY"

You can however tie abilities like Rune Strike to spammed keys, which is what I personally do. The macro for Blood Strike looks something like the following. Keep in mind that I'm using two "on use" trinkets so I tie them in as well. I prefer use the trinket name in case I have a PvP trinket equipped, which is actually tied to a different key binding so I don't use the equipment slot number.

#showtooltip Blood Strike
/use trinketname
/use trinketname
/cast Rune Strike
/cast Blood Strike

This will queue Rune Strike any time I cast Blood Strike. I have a similar macro tied to Plague Strike as well and it seems to keep them on cooldown most of the time. I haven't got into raiding yet on this character, but I may change this up depending on the fight mechanics and if there are any burn phases that I need to be aware of.
#364SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pfooti
Originally Posted by Thiris
The problem with tying a macro like that to an ability that you use a lot is that you are going to be using runic power like crazy and wasting it. Unfortunately there is no way to tie some sort of conditional to the macro since we cannot use "If XXX doesn't exist, cast YYY"
Also, with respect to Horn of Winter, that triggers the GCD, which means any other stuff later in the macro that is also gcd-bound (strikes, for example) will not trigger. Unfortunately, we just have to get used to casting HoW a lot. I try to do it after every fight, reflexively.
#365SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by Thiris
I have a question that I've been confused about for some time now. Are stat focuses heavily weighed to +hit for DW specs or are you attempting to settle around the +hit cap for special abilities? I can't say that I have specced DW yet, so I don't know what the damage breakdown is, but was curious if I should hold onto all of this +hit plate that I've been picking up.
Considering that a lot of dualwield specs' damage focuses on procs like Necrosis and Blood-Caked Blades, making sure your offhand weapon is hitting as often as possible is pretty important.

Originally Posted by pfooti
Also, with respect to Horn of Winter, that triggers the GCD, which means any other stuff later in the macro that is also gcd-bound (strikes, for example) will not trigger. Unfortunately, we just have to get used to casting HoW a lot. I try to do it after every fight, reflexively.
It's roughly the same as warrior shouts and shaman totems (though at least totems got taken off the GCD), so we shouldn't feel too persecuted. During long fights it's easiest to ensure its uptime during your RP dump.
#366SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyran
I was looking at the DPS compendium again (specifically, the 51/13/7 Blood spec, which I'm working towards) and I have a question: Why is Toughness ignored, given the synergy with Bladed Armor?

Also, I just noticed, Improved Icy Touch and Glyph of Plague Strike would be incompatible, wouldn't they. Each one provides more damaged to diseased enemies, so if you have both one of the spells on your IT-PS-HS rotation (or PS-IT-HS) wouldn't get the benefit.

If you weren't using the Glyph would the tradeoff of Toughness for Improved Icy Touch/Glacier Rot even be worth it? I calculate that at 10k armor the extra bonus from Toughness would add just over 41 ap (assuming Blood Presence or Unholy Presence):

10000 * 1.15 = 11500
11500 - 1000 = 1500
1500 / 180 = 8.33
8.33 * 5 = 41.65 ap
41.65 / 14 = 2.975 dps
How does that 2.975 across-the-board dps increase stack up against the 40% extra damage your Icy Touch would do with Improved Icy Touch and Glacier Rot?
#367SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pfooti
Originally Posted by Pyran
How does that 2.975 across-the-board dps increase stack up against the 40% extra damage your Icy Touch would do with Improved Icy Touch and Glacier Rot?
I think you answered your question there - 3 DPS out of around 1800-3500 DPS depending on gearing levels will not stack up at all. Imp Icy Touch is also a potential avoidance buff for your tank, if nobody else is providing a better haste debuff in the group.

Personally, I actually spec 5/5 toughness, but that's mainly because I want to be able to have the armor for when I tank 5-mans (I'm still only 77, tho, so I have a leveling spec).
#368SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Pyran
41.65 / 14 = 2.975 dps

How does that 2.975 across-the-board dps increase stack up against the 40% extra damage your Icy Touch would do with Improved Icy Touch and Glacier Rot?
41 AP does not equal 2.9 dps. 14 AP = 1 dps is not true for any melee due to having many AP-influenced attacks. For a Ret Pally, that AP is about 24 dps.

To know what is better, you would look at the addition of Icy Touch (assume 100 dps, it is likely more, Recount can tell you), so that is another 40 dps.


So toughness is not a great dps talent (outstanding for leveling/tanking/PvP though).
#369SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Gorgrom
How important do you consider reaching the spell hit cap?

I plan on raiding as a blood spec for raids 51/13/7 build listed in the compendium, but being someone who has only played a warrior since beta I am doubting my decision to cap for spells.
#370SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Broseph
Originally Posted by Gorgrom
How important do you consider reaching the spell hit cap?

I plan on raiding as a blood spec for raids 51/13/7 build listed in the compendium, but being someone who has only played a warrior since beta I am doubting my decision to cap for spells.
Spend 10 minutes on the practice dummy and report what percentage of your damage comes from icy touch and deathcoil. These are the only spells in your spec that spell hit affects. A one percent increase in spell hit toward the cap is a one percent increase in damage done by these spells only. It should be pretty low (0.3% overall DPS increase, estimated). In other words, it's nice, but you can probably find better ways to spend your gear or itemization points.

Oh, this doesn't take into consideration the GCD you might lose by missing an icy touch. So just a little more than the flat damage increase. But still not worth going out of your way to cap.

#378SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
[quote=Pyran;993689]I was looking at the DPS compendium again (specifically, the 51/13/7 Blood spec, which I'm working towards) and I have a question: Why is Toughness ignored, given the synergy with Bladed Armor?

Also, I just noticed, Improved Icy Touch and Glyph of Plague Strike would be incompatible, wouldn't they. Each one provides more damaged to diseased enemies, so if you have both one of the spells on your IT-PS-HS rotation (or PS-IT-HS) wouldn't get the benefit.

If you weren't using the Glyph would the tradeoff of Toughness for Improved Icy Touch/Glacier Rot even be worth it? I calculate that at 10k armor the extra bonus from Toughness would add just over 41 ap (assuming Blood Presence or Unholy Presence):

10000 * 1.15 = 11500
11500 - 1000 = 1500
1500 / 180 = 8.33
8.33 * 5 = 41.65 ap
41.65 / 14 = 2.975 dps
Are you saying trade only Icy Talons OR Glacier Rot for points in Toughness, or filling out Toughness for both?

At 5/5, Toughness would add 3,000 armor to a 10,000 armor base. 3000/180*5 ~= 80AP gained.

Granted, it's nothing to sneeze at, and it scales, but general theory is that five entire talent points spent for such a relatively minimal gain isn't worth it, even in a min max setting.


As for Icy Touch, between Glacier Rot and Black Ice it'll hit and crit for around as much damage as Blood Strike in pre-heroic gear. It won't approach Heart Strike and Obliterate, but it becomes a fairly strong attack, especially when it crits with the fact that it ignores armor and crits for 200% damage through class mechanics alone.

#383SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by NeuroMedivh
Fallen Crusader is a 1ppm enchant, but it has no internal cooldown, thus it can proc multiple times in rapid succession if that's the way the RNG goes.
Therein lies the confusion people are seeing then in assuming that 1ppm automatically means it can only proc once every 60 seconds instead of statistically proccing once per minute.

Now for some different questions for the mix: Which attacks can it proc from? I'd assume every auto attack and strike, but not spells. Also, can it proc from BCB procs? That would lead into further discussion about any benefits of placing it on both weapons in a dual wielding build for greater uptime.

Also, I checked a couple of WWS reports and noted 4 procs over 3'44" for one deathknight, and 6 procs over 3'45" for another. Chances are that it procced more than that, but since WWS only records buff gains, and a proc while Unholy Strength was up wouldn't count towards the total, it's difficult to tell. Still, those two in particular had a 1.08ppm rate, and 1.7ppm respectively, meaning they had 27% and 40% uptime of the buff. (60 seconds / 244 seconds, 90 seconds / 244 seconds)
#384SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pfooti
Originally Posted by Noraj
Therein lies the confusion people are seeing then in assuming that 1ppm automatically means it can only proc once every 60 seconds instead of statistically proccing once per minute.
My understanding of the PPM mechanic is that it's even more complex. The likelihood of any strike proccing the enchant is a function of the PPM and the weapon speed. But that chance doesn't change based on haste and specials. So if you use a special every GCD and are hasted, you'll see better uptime of the enchant, and this means a slow weapon will have a better chance to proc off of specials.

IOW: if you have a 1 PPM enchant, and you hit a target dummy with auto attack for N minutes, you should see N procs. If you do other stuff, you'll see more procs. That's why mongoose was so great on my rogue, it was up all the time, between the SnD buff for haste and all the sinister striking, I was attacking a lot faster than the base rate.
#385SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Fatedtolive
I don't remember seeing this explained in any of the threads on these forums.

But, is there a "breaking point" where one runeforge is better than another in terms of Personal DPS, and Raid DPS?
#386SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by pfooti
My understanding of the PPM mechanic is that it's even more complex. The likelihood of any strike proccing the enchant is a function of the PPM and the weapon speed. But that chance doesn't change based on haste and specials. So if you use a special every GCD and are hasted, you'll see better uptime of the enchant, and this means a slow weapon will have a better chance to proc off of specials.

IOW: if you have a 1 PPM enchant, and you hit a target dummy with auto attack for N minutes, you should see N procs. If you do other stuff, you'll see more procs. That's why mongoose was so great on my rogue, it was up all the time, between the SnD buff for haste and all the sinister striking, I was attacking a lot faster than the base rate.
Right...So for a 3.5 speed weapon, you should have (1/60)*(60/3.5)= 21% chance per autoattack to proc it.
#387SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Septus
Which is then applied to special attacks right, since they're not factored into the PPM calc? So 21% per attack?
#388SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Bibdy
PPM is the normalised representation of the proc rate. The chance to proc per melee swing is the thing that ends up being a function of your weapon's attack speed. For example, a 3.0 speed weapon will have double the chance of proccing than a 1.5 speed weapon, but then, the 1.5s speed weapon swings twice as often. So, in the long run, the number of procs in a given minute is equal.

The uptime of the buff, however, can depend on whether or not it overwrites itself. You could have a 3m fight, but the RNG gods screw you and you end up with 3 procs on your first 3 swings and no procs for the next 3 minutes. That's an extreme example, because of odds of that are pretty damn slim, but I hope you get the idea.

#396SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3faight
Originally Posted by slacman69
did anyone else have any input on my spec and rotation?
Yes.

Originally Posted by slacman69
I'm currently testing out a DW spec that allows me at lvl 75 to do a consistent 1200 dps in a 5 man instance.

Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft

this is my current gear i may still be in tank gear when you click the link i dont know how long it will take to update armory.

The World of Warcraft Armory

typically my rotation for single target is

IT->HB->BS->BS->FS
IT->HB->BS->BS->FS->FS

my rotation for aoe is

IT->Pestilience->HB->BS->FS

im just looking to get some feedback on this spec. It seems to be great on single target and aoe dps seeing as the main ability for it is an aoe. Since I'm DW Killing Machine is almost always up making most of my frost strikes crit.
[Fake Edit: Oh holy crap I just realized you have no points in Rime. Shame on you. However, I'm too lazy to go back and change all the crap I wrote.]

You have Annihilation but you never OB. You say PS won't boost your BS enough, but you're obviously trying to max your BS damage using talents (Bloody Strikes). If you're going to spam BS instead of using the Death Runes they create to OB then drop Annihilation, however considering the huge amount of damage OB will do, especially on crit with GoG, you should drop the two BS in the second part of your first rotation and just OB instead.

And not PSing is just silly. Letting a rune sit unused when you'll have to wait for more to come up is no excuse really. It's free damage you're missing out on. It's a DPS boost for one GCD, fire and forget.

Since the main focus of DW specs is to maximize white damage and use abilities that don't necessarily rely on weapon damage your rotations should look more like:

IT -> PS -> HB -> (OB) -> BS -> BS -> FS
HB -> OB -> OB -> FS

or

IT -> PS -> HB -> BS -> BS -> FS
HB -> OB -> OB -> FS -> (HB)

The section in parentheses are what you do if Rime procced off of your first IT, making your HB cost no runes. Since you don't have Epidemic though, you're going to have to refresh your diseases more often, however that's not really an issue anyways since using IT more is good.

On to your talents:
You have one point in Two-Hand Weapon Specialization. In a dual wield build.
No Rime in a HB centric build. Double yoo tee eff.
Points buffing BS in a DW build.

Personally I'd aim for something like this:

Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft

Tundra Stalker is 10% more damage with your abilities when your target has FF on it, which should be always.

The stuff in unholy gives your melee an extra 10%+ damage (since Necrosis is affected by Tundra Stalker/Blood Presence/etc). BCB gives you an additional melee attack to proc Killing Machine with, as well as just more free damage. While I regret not taking Bladed Armor and Dark Conviction I don't feel they play to your strengths as much (though in all honesty everyone should have Bladed Armor. It's that good).

You need Rime. It's just too good for an HB focused build.

Runic Power Mastery is not so good in my opinion, because you should always be dumping your RP before you can hit 100 in an instance. Soloing is a different story, but don't base your builds around soloing.

Virulence helps your HB/IT hit. Once you get enough hit gear you can probably drop it and get Ravenous Dead for some extra strength.


Some notes: If you're not going to OB drop those points and put them somewhere else (Rime for instance). However just realize the huge amount of single-target damage OB can do. Obviously it's a lot less dual-wielding than using a two-hander, but you need to focus your talents in places that will best boost your damage.

#398SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mewee
Hey I'm new here but I've been following this thread closely and lots of great information here. However I still have a few questions that's been bugging me:

1) On the topic of item budget for tanks, I read these conversions somewhere (tankspot or wowwiki I think)

39.35 dodge rating = 1% dodge
41.00 defense rating = 1% avoidance (miss/parry/dodge combined)
49.18 parry rating = 1% parry (also grants haste benefit on top)

With this in mind, I was wondering why people are suggesting top STOP stacking defense after the cap, and go for parry and dodge instead?

With the dodge conversion and defense conversion being so close, wouldn't it be WAY more beneficial to just stack as MUCH defense as possible, even over the 540 cap, seeing as defense would suffer the least from diminishing returns as it effects 3 different avoidance mechanics instead of one? Can someone elaborate why stacking dodge and parry is beneficial in any way if defense is availible?


2) As an unholy tank (mainly for heroics and 10-man Naxx) im currently running with this build:

Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft

(About unholy choices I took OaPH because I fly around alot, and I value AMZ over Desecration for 5-mans. Ghoul and Gargoyle for most dps per point, which helps loads on bosses)

As you can see, I left 4 points out, cause im really unsure what would get me the most bang for the buck.

I do either 4/5 bladed armor or 2/2 2h spec + 2/5 bladed armor.

With my gear it would come out as 290 Attack Power vs 4% twohand damage. I see the 2hand damage being the most beneficial for single target threat, however the attackpower helps boost my aoe threat instead. Is there a clear winner here?
#399SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by Mewee
With the dodge conversion and defense conversion being so close, wouldn't it be WAY more beneficial to just stack as MUCH defense as possible, even over the 540 cap, seeing as defense would suffer the least from diminishing returns as it effects 3 different avoidance mechanics instead of one? Can someone elaborate why stacking dodge and parry is beneficial in any way if defense is availible?
There are a couple of reasons: For one, it's harder for a DK to hit the 540 cap than the other classes due to the limited number of gear slots we have in comparison (no tanking sigils yet, only one of the two weapon slots to be used). Secondly, defense gives us stats we purely don't need, despite giving us ones we do. Once we reach that cap which is already taking up a large part of our item budget, it's time to move on to more specialized stats. Look at things like the [Durable Nerubhide Cape] for an idea of the gearing decisions that occur when you opt between a piece of gear with +defense, and one with +dodge or +parry in the Wrath loot tables.

In any case, here's a blue take on it:

I think DKs may end up stacking a lot of dodge and parry just because they can't benefit from block percent or block value. They aren't designed to be avoidance tanks though -- they do have a lot of armor and some very strong active abilities for mitigation.

DKs may have a harder time hitting 540 defense than warriors or paladins just because they don't have the shield slot, which often has defense on it.

-Ghostcrawler (MMO-Champion BlueTracker - Any plans on fixing DK tank mitigation?)
#400SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mewee
Originally Posted by Noraj
There are a couple of reasons: For one, it's harder for a DK to hit the 540 cap than the other classes due to the limited number of gear slots we have in comparison (no tanking sigils yet, only one of the two weapon slots to be used). Secondly, defense gives us stats we purely don't need, despite giving us ones we do. Once we reach that cap which is already taking up a large part of our item budget, it's time to move on to more specialized stats. Look at things like the [Durable Nerubhide Cape] for an idea of the gearing decisions that occur when you opt between a piece of gear with +defense, and one with +dodge or +parry in the Wrath loot tables.

In any case, here's a blue take on it:
Thanks for the reply, however it still doesn't answer my question.

Defense gives you, point for point, way more avoidance than parry rating and about the same avoidance as dodge rating. However defense doesn't suffer from diminishing returns as bad as the other stats.

Why should I stops stacking defense when I'm uncrittable, given the above facts?

One reason could be that defense is more expensive item-budget wise, but I haven't found any evidence of it being so yet.

Assuming im already uncrittable: 100 defense rating >>> 100 dodge rating? At least it would seem so with the DR penalty.

I'm pretty sure BoH is best in slot for us, ret as well as arms. My question is, which is 2nd, 3rd etc. I'm hoping BoH drops tonight and I get it but if not I really have no clue what to take other than staying away from Jawbone (which may not even be true, just basing that off the stats).

#403SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		huntcaudata
Originally Posted by Mewee
Thanks for the reply, however it still doesn't answer my question.

Defense gives you, point for point, way more avoidance than parry rating and about the same avoidance as dodge rating. However defense doesn't suffer from diminishing returns as bad as the other stats.

Why should I stops stacking defense when I'm uncrittable, given the above facts?

One reason could be that defense is more expensive item-budget wise, but I haven't found any evidence of it being so yet.

Assuming im already uncrittable: 100 defense rating >>> 100 dodge rating? At least it would seem so with the DR penalty.
You're being kind of silly here. Of course you should stop stacking defense once you hit the cap, because at that point, Dodge is better. And, of course, at some point, DR will make dodge worse than defense. You can't just ignore the range in which dodge is flat out better. Furthermore, the point at which diminishing returns makes defense worth more than dodge is very high. My calculation shows that if you have only 689 defense rating (the minimum), you need 871 dodge rating before it is more beneficial to get defense.

EDIT: This varies with strength and parry rating as well. For my calculation I used 900 str, which seems normal, and 10 parry rating, just to benefit defense more and give a more conservation number.
Last edited by huntcaudata : 12/03/08 at 11:52 AM.
#404SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mewee
Originally Posted by huntcaudata
You're being kind of silly here. Of course you should stop stacking defense once you hit the cap, because at that point, Dodge is better. And, of course, at some point, DR will make dodge worse than defense. You can't just ignore the range in which dodge is flat out better. Furthermore, the point at which diminishing returns makes defense worth more than dodge is very high. My calculation shows that if you have only 689 defense rating (the minimum), you need 871 dodge rating before it is more beneficial to get defense.

EDIT: This varies with strength and parry rating as well. For my calculation I used 900 str, which seems normal, and 10 parry rating, just to benefit defense more and give a more conservation number.

[Valor Medal of the First War]


[Essence of Gossamer]


[Seal of the Pantheon]

#405SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3huntcaudata
Not exactly. I'm talking strictly about avoidance here. Dodge is better than defense for avoidance purposes. Defense is still better than parry until even higher levels of rating. Whether you want to gem/enchant/gear for avoidance or effective health is really a question of philosophy, what content you're working on, etc.

#408SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by Mewee
Thanks for that, so you'd suggest getting crit immune and then forgetting about defense alltogether in favor of parry/dodge/stam?

On that very same topic, what comination of these trinkets should I use for unholy tanking:


[Valor Medal of the First War]


[Essence of Gossamer]


[Seal of the Pantheon]



Unfortunately, removing the seal will take me below crit immune atm so it's between Gossamer and Valor medal. Im having a hard time choosing between those two.
The Essence of Gossamer has a 2% proc rate according to the data on WoWHead: Essence of Gossamer - Spell - World of Warcraft

Here's the important thing in my opinion about it though: It's a shield, and you're specifically looking at Unholy tanking. Where's does Unholy's strength come from? Bone Shield! Any attack absorbed fully by a shield fails to eat a charge of Bone Shield, thereby extending its duration. The problem though lies in the fact that it only absorbs 4000 damage, which can be as little as one melee attack in heroics (unless the DK's mitigation percentages apply to damage that hits a shield effect instead of only applying to damage that passes through a shield effect). The stamina is phenomenal once you're crit safe though, especially with stamina scaling talents. While the stats on it don't themselves run into diminishing returns, they'll go down, down, down in usefulness the further you up the difficulty of the encounters you're taking the trinket into.

As for the medal, if I'm doing the math right and you popped it whenever its cooldown was up, it would lead to an overall 1% extra dodge before DR added by the use. It's a great trinket for quickly upping your avoidance, but deathknights are already stacked with usable abilities to increase or mitigation.

That's the line of reasoning I'd go down for choosing the Essence over the Medal: Going for the overall greatly increased effective health rather than avoidance that will be affected by diminishing returns. Your mileage may vary.
#409SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3huntcaudata
Read the essence again. It reduces damage from each attack by 140, for 28 attacks, essentially (but only 10 seconds - so it's primarily useful for AOE). This will have no affect on Bone Shield uptime unless you were taking less than 140 per hit.

Should be:
Virulence 0.38% 0.13% 0.25% 0.38%

Can somebody fix this?
#411SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ursu
A little question about melee special :

How works the AP contribution ? I have seen different things, but nothing really clear (maybe i miss something, there are a lot of posts)

Example :
a 100-100 damage, 2.00 speed, 1-h weapon (so 50 dps), with 1400 AP

The auto attack will be 100+1400/14*2 = 300 damage

Now, use BS, with no disease.

1. BS is 300*50%+191 = 341 damage so ap contribution is 0.071

2. BS is (100+1400/14*2.4)*50% + 191 = 361 damage so ap contribution is 0.086

3. BS is 100*50% +1400/14*2.4 + 191 = 481 damage so ap contribution is 0.171

4. an other weird thing

I have no problem with normalization, but i find weird that th ap contribution is normalized and cut in half (for BS). I think the second proposition is the good, but i really want a confirmation.

You're right...My fault for skimming it. The effective health it offers still outweighs the avoidance of the Medal to me though.

Only thing is, I can't find a thread stating that anywhere, and when I switched to Razorice I didn't see a boost in his DPS,
and I kinda want to keep using Fallen Crusader.

#414SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Frodus
Hey guys,
first post.

I've looked through the DPS Compendium as well as other threads here and can't really find anything definitive on which runes we should be Runeforging.
I have been using Fallen Crusader, but a mage in my guild has been telling me to switch over to Razorice, he says he saw a thread on here claiming the extra frost vulnerability could boost the DPS of frost or frostfire bolt specced mages by anywhere between 300-800.
Only thing is, I can't find a thread stating that anywhere, and when I switched to Razorice I didn't see a boost in his DPS,
and I kinda want to keep using Fallen Crusader.

I was wondering if anyone has done extensive tests/research/work to see if Razorice is more beneficial to bring to a raid if there will be mages, or if it's vulnerability isn't really that helpful.
From what I can tell from the DPS compendium and other threads here, it's still kind of up in the air as to which Runeforge enchant is the best to use.
It's exactly 5% more frost damage on the boss, assuming 3K DPS per mage, and 2mages, you're looking at a raid dps increase of 300DPS if they're only using frostfire bolts, which I'm not sure of, but I don't know much about mages. You're probably not getting this from a fallen crusader runeforge, so yeah, theorically it's better to use razorice. However on any fights that forces you to move around, the debuff won't be up most of the time because it has to be restacked, and it takes quite a decent amount of time with a 2H.
#415SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3jooce
Razorice would probably be best for dps burns, but like Pyros said, it probably wouldn't get stacked to 5 all that easily if you're having to run around a bunch. With a 2hander it can be slow to reapply it.

#421SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by mtrixis
Tried searching and reading through several threads, but I couldn't find an explicit consolidated answer, so:

1) Exactly what is considered a 'spell' for a Deathknight

2) Which of those 'spells' does Virulence affect

3) Which of those 'spells' does Impurity benefit

3a) What are the AP coefficients for those spells?
1) If it's not a "Strike," then it's a spell, with the exception of taunts, which should be all be based on melee hit for every class.
2) Apparently all of them
3) All of the below, except for Blood Worms should benefit from Impurity. Possibly not damage done by Summon Gargoyle.
3a) (Taking from the DPS Compendium thread)
Blood Boil 0.04
Blood Plague 0.055
Bloodworms 0.006
Corpse Explosion 0.0475
Death and Decay 0.0475
Death Coil 0.15
Frost Fever 0.055
Howling Blast 0.1
Summon Gargoyle 0.4
Icy Touch 0.1
Pestilence 0.04
Strangulate 0.06
Unholy Blight 0.013
#422SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lazare
Originally Posted by Noraj
1) If it's not a "Strike," then it's a spell, with the exception of taunts, which should be all be based on melee hit for every class.
No. Taunts are a spell, and thus are on the spell hit table. That's why there's a glyph for every tanking class which gives them 8% higher chance to hit with taunt. (9% for normal melee hit cap + 8% from the glyph = 17% spell hit cap) You were probably confused by a change Blizzard made some time ago so that taunts benefited from melee hit rating; they never changed them to use the melee hit table.
#423SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by Lazare
No. Taunts are a spell, and thus are on the spell hit table. That's why there's a glyph for every tanking class which gives them 8% higher chance to hit with taunt. (9% for normal melee hit cap + 8% from the glyph = 17% spell hit cap) You were probably confused by a change Blizzard made some time ago so that taunts benefited from melee hit rating; they never changed them to use the melee hit table.
Again, you're right. I was getting mixed up after some discussion elsewhere regarding getting rid of the 1% chance to resist taunts that was previously unavoidable. My mistake. I should really sleep more.

I, on the other hand, (as a rogue) am not allowed to roll on anything with strength. I understand this but isn't it hypocritical for her to roll on everything heavy on agility but I'm not allowed to roll on strength? Strength is not completely worthless albeit better for other classes but wouldn't' it benefit the raid more if the rogues/hunters got the agility heavy items? I think she has misconstrued agility with critical strike rating which is what is wanted for Frost.
#425SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Lazare
That sounds like an internal guild issue to me that should be solved in guild.

In any case, a DK will treat Agi much like a warrior will. They get minor amounts of crit and dodge from it, and very small amounts of AC. That's makes it vastly better than int, but still worse than a "real" DK stat.

You also don't give her role. If she's DPS that's especially silly; agi is about 1/3 as good as strength or hit for frost DPS.
Last edited by Lazare : 12/04/08 at 10:51 PM.

#428SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mokhtar
Hello DK Community,

I'm the developper of GridDynamicLayout, a mod that attempts at providing a dynamic role-based Grid Layout (essentially the raid is divided in melee / range DPS, healers and tanks based on their buffs / the stance they are in). I don't know a lot about DKs but I'm looking for a way to differentiate a tanking DK from a melee DPS DK, preferably not based on talent but on :
- either a buff all tanking DKs would have active at beginning of a fight
- or a presencec they are in
The first alternative would be better as it's programatically easier to detect buffs than presence (I assume presence uses the same mechanic than stance).
For the latter I'm under the impression that most tanking DKs are always in frost presence, are there reasons that a DK would be in frost presence other than if he intended to tank ? Conversely, would it be possible for a DK to tank while not in frost presence ?
#429SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Veritas17
You can tank while not in frost, but you aren't very affective at it. Your skills are still there, just not your talented frost skills. You'd go into frost in order to reduce the amount of incoming damage you're about to take be it spells or physical for an extended period of time... sorta like auras but not really. They don't fade, they cost a rune and you can screw your gcd if you switch around too much.
#430SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kurenai
Actually you tank in frost presence because of the HP, armor and huge threat buff you get from the presence. It never makes sense to not tank in frost or the other way around to dps in frost.
#431SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3tedv
Originally Posted by Mokhtar
Hello DK Community,

I'm the developper of GridDynamicLayout, a mod that attempts at providing a dynamic role-based Grid Layout (essentially the raid is divided in melee / range DPS, healers and tanks based on their buffs / the stance they are in). I don't know a lot about DKs but I'm looking for a way to differentiate a tanking DK from a melee DPS DK, preferably not based on talent but on :
- either a buff all tanking DKs would have active at beginning of a fight
- or a presencec they are in
The first alternative would be better as it's programatically easier to detect buffs than presence (I assume presence uses the same mechanic than stance).
For the latter I'm under the impression that most tanking DKs are always in frost presence, are there reasons that a DK would be in frost presence other than if he intended to tank ? Conversely, would it be possible for a DK to tank while not in frost presence ?
There's no buff like druids or paladins have that all tanks would have and no non-tanks would have. The only time you'd use Frost Presence is when you plan on tanking, as you lose the 15% damage bonus of blood and gain a bunch of armor, threat, and spell damage reduction.

There are a few situations where death knight would tank in blood stance, but that generally involves undermanning group quests without a healer. You can use Death Strike to heal yourself, and the additional damage from Blood Presence generates more healing for Death Strike than the mitigation lost from Frost Presence. In a raid setting though, this should never occur.

I'm trying to find out if BCB is really worth getting. I tried it before and did not get much use out of it but almost every DW spec requires it.
#433SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3jacclark
Hi guys,

Forgive my lack of knowledge, but I can't find a definitive source on the subject despite searching for several days:

Can resilience be used to prevent crits from bosses in instances / raids? (Yes / No)

I'm having trouble reaching the defense cap without resorting to using a defense trinket or a lot of defense gems. I'd like to start gemming for other attributes. (See my armory for ideas) My plan was to put a resilience gem on my belt.

Thank you.

Tali
(And, Yes i know about shoulders enchants and helm enchants - just looking for gem resilience info)
#434SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Clemz
Resilience does work for the crit immunity in PvE, I believe Feral Druids had to use a bit to reach crit immunity in BC. However, you're looking at defense the wrong way. It doesn't only provide you with crit reduction, it also gives you dodge, and parry(block too, but we don't use that). Gem for defense until the cap, use a trinket if you have to, we're missing out on a lot of defense rating from using a two hander, and not having a shield. When you find yourself over the defense cap, you can start switching out your gems for stamina, strength, expertise, etc.
#435SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3keltzed
*puts on noob hat*

Is there a way for an unholy DK with the perma-ghoul talent to dismiss a ghoul pet, for example in situations where you need to move carefully to avoid butt-pulling adds?
#436SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Chicken
Originally Posted by keltzed
*puts on noob hat*

Is there a way for an unholy DK with the perma-ghoul talent to dismiss a ghoul pet, for example in situations where you need to move carefully to avoid butt-pulling adds?
Right-click your ghoul's unit frame and click "dismiss" in the little menu.

#438SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Hidden
Originally Posted by jacclark

Hmm.. Yes I do know defense's myriad of benefits. (Seen my gear and achievements?) The issue with DKs, as you point out, is that we have an epic itemization issue whereby it's difficult maintaining Defense cap without resorting to blue defense trinkets or gemming out of colour.

I'm sitting on a bunch of epics, badges and other trinkets I'm desiring to use. Plus, I have to think about upp'ing my hit and expertise to maintain threat.
It's not that hard to get crit immune by defense, enchanting your gear is a huge factor though.
You can get Defense on Helmet, Shoulders, Back, Chest and Bracers without sacrificing many/any other stats. Otherwise the reputation rewards offer plenty of Def.
#439SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Clemz
It sounds like he's trying to avoid the BC Druid fiasco of running around in blue tanking gear(Heavy Clefthoof), for a good portion of the expansion. My gear is mostly rep rewards with a smattering of epics, 8/9 sockets are 16 defense, the last is a perfect stamina/defense in a [Figurine - Monarch Crab] for the bonus, which is currently the only tanking trinket I use, waiting for an [Essence of Gossamer] for the other trinket. Placing me squarely at 540 Defense, once I go over by a fair margin, I'll start regemming. It also brings me to 195 hit rating(5.95%) and 26 expertise(6.50%).
#440SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by Clemz
It sounds like he's trying to avoid the BC Druid fiasco of running around in blue tanking gear(Heavy Clefthoof), for a good portion of the expansion. My gear is mostly rep rewards with a smattering of epics, 8/9 sockets are 16 defense, the last is a perfect stamina/defense in a [Figurine - Monarch Crab] for the bonus, which is currently the only tanking trinket I use, waiting for an [Essence of Gossamer] for the other trinket. Placing me squarely at 540 Defense, once I go over by a fair margin, I'll start regemming. It also brings me to 195 hit rating(5.95%) and 26 expertise(6.50%).
For the sake of reference, here are some Wrath +defense enchants available to all:

Chest - Enchant Chest - Greater Defense - 22 def
Cloak - Titanweave - 16 def
Head - Arcanum of the Stalwart Protector - 37stam 20 def
Shoulder - Greater Inscription of the Pinnacle - 20 dodge 15 def
Wrist - Enchant Bracer - Major Defense - 12 def

For a total of: 22+16+20+15+12= 85 rating
#441SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Denrire
Hit Rating?
In BC on my paladin I know that 9% was the miss rate for 2 handed weapons and ranged attacks and I have seen that number cropping up many times in reference to WotLK. I have been gearing my hit rating trying to reach 9%, however another post on the EJ forums lead me to believe that the hit rating is in fact 8%. Last night in Naxx, I had 250 (7.62%) hit rating and overall I had a 0.3% miss rate on my melee swings (click columns -> check "miss").

I know this is just one night of raiding. Has anyone else experimented with 8% vs. 9% for DKs? If the hit rating we need for melee attacks is 8% are we currently overvaluing hit rating in terms of itemization?
#442SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by Denrire
In BC on my paladin I know that 9% was the miss rate for 2 handed weapons and ranged attacks and I have seen that number cropping up many times in reference to WotLK. I have been gearing my hit rating trying to reach 9%, however another post on the EJ forums lead me to believe that the hit rating is in fact 8%. Last night in Naxx, I had 250 (7.62%) hit rating and overall I had a 0.3% miss rate on my melee swings (click columns -> check "miss").

I know this is just one night of raiding. Has anyone else experimented with 8% vs. 9% for DKs? If the hit rating we need for melee attacks is 8% are we currently overvaluing hit rating in terms of itemization?
EDIT: My original post was based on a change I was unaware of and therefore not valid.

However, did any of the members of your raid offer any +hit increasing buffs or debuffs to account for the difference?
#443SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		jacclark
Originally Posted by Hidden
It's not that hard to get crit immune by defense, enchanting your gear is a huge factor though.
You can get Defense on Helmet, Shoulders, Back, Chest and Bracers without sacrificing many/any other stats. Otherwise the reputation rewards offer plenty of Def.
Easy to say when you're a jewel crafter and you're putting in +27 defense gems. You have *three* of them.

Seriously guys.... let's look before we mention the obvious and mislead some people into believing things are just dandy with death knight gear and tanking.

FYI:
Greater Inscription of the Pinnacle
Requires The Sons of Hodir - Exalted

**Exalted** That's a lot of dailies or lucky finds of ice shards.

The issue is how to gem for hit / expertise / dodge when you're putting in 16 defense gems 7/8 slots. There's got to be a better way.

As this is EJ, let's talk some basic numbers:

As I calculated, resilience is 1.5 defense for dealing with crit cap. If you're willing to decrease your avoidance by a percentage, you can then gem for dodge which has a better avoidance per point basis than defense (39 dodge rating per 1% dodge versus 12 x 4.92 defense rating for combined 1% avoidance or 59 parry rating per 1% parry). Furthermore, if you check the calculations for diminishing returns you'll find that below (and after) dodge rating of 400, dodge rating is more beneficial than parry or defense.

As some DKs are finding out, maintaining threat with low hit and expertise becomes difficult and the inability to maintain defense cap and gem for hit / expertise without sacrificing other stats can become tricky - or a mathematical quandry. (And limited by a budget to some extent.)
Last edited by jacclark : 12/06/08 at 1:12 AM.
#444SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by jacclark
Easy to say when you're a jewel crafter and you're putting in +27 defense gems. You have *three* of them.

Seriously guys.... let's look before we mention the obvious.
Well if you're not going to level a tradeskill that lets you increase defense(JC/smithing mostly, maybe inscription unsure if it's a lot), you'll have to get a def trinket and keep it for a while, there's no working around that until they add the def runeforge and the def sigil. Another solution though is to wait until arena S5 starts, and get a pvp 2h sword then, along with some pvp jewelry, and just crit cap with resilience. But crit capping off resilience currently is hard because there's really not a lot of decent stuff to use since most of the pvp gear is unavailable.

So in the end, the best way to tank as a DK is to level a tradeskills that is actually useful to tanking. JC is probably the best, but smithing works nicely too.
#445SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3SurrealTichondrius
Originally Posted by heffroncm
It seems to me that Blacksmithing and Jewelcrafting offer the largest gains. The extra gem slots in your Gloves and Boots, along with the super gems and unique-equipped BoP gems, seem to outweigh what any other profession has to offer. The bonuses from LW, Enchanting, Alchemy, and Inscription are all nice, but in terms of total stat gain you get the most from Blacksmithing and Jewelcrafting.

Convient, in a sense, in that you can work one up with Mining, then Mine up the thousands of Ore needed to grind the other from 1 to 425ish or whatever skill you get the bonuses at.
I've done some testing on the Shadowguard embroidery from tailoring and found it is being undervalued in every analysis I see on these forums. The actual AP value of this proc averages at 90 AP, not the 75 which is being spread all over. (see below for the tests I ran to come up with this number)

It does not stack with traditional enchants, so you lose 22 agility to get this embroidery. Using the DPS compendium's stat weightings for Blood Spec, the AP value of 22 agility is ~18.16 AP. That leaves the incremental average value of the Shadowguard embroidery at about 72 AP. While this currently doesn't beat jewelcrafting (about 84 AP) or blacksmithing (about 82 AP) in terms of average AP contribution, it beats all other professions. It also has a different mechanic which in my opinion makes it superior to JC or BS for a Death Knight.

The proc rate is extremely high, so the activation times are very predictable. The first always comes within the first few seconds of combat, which is prime time to blow cooldowns for longer fights where the goal is to get more than one cooldown use in. That means the 300 AP in that 15 second window is getting some additional multipliers due to cooldowns like Hysteria, gargoyle, empower rune weapon, dancing rune weapon and heroism/bloodlust. You may be able to use the 2nd round of the above cooldowns with the 300 AP buff up as well, since the timing of this buff is so predictable.

-----------------------------------
Here are the results of my test:

In a series of ~600 second tests (10 minutes each) the Shadowguard effect procced 12 times against a level 80 heroic target dummy in that time frame. I ran three of these tests, and got the 12th proc at 09:46, 09:50 and 10:05 respectively. The proc chance is rather high, but still has a random component which accounts for the variance in how long it takes to get the 12th proc.

12 procs that last 15 seconds a piece = 180 seconds of uptime divided by 600 seconds = 30% uptime. That comes out to ~50 second internal cooldown, not the 60 second cooldown being claimed.

0.30 * 300 AP = 90 average AP over 600 seconds.

#449SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.32Face
I finally managed to read through all 18 pages of the Unholy DK PvE dps thread.
I'm in the process of rolling a DK to switch over to my main, so I don't know too much about how it works yet.

After 18 pages of reading, the generally accepted rotation for UDKdps is quoted:
PS, IT, BS, BS, SS, UB (BS's to make the Death Runes)
SS, SS, SS, RPD (2nd to last SS from the Death Runes you just made)
I have a few questions I have about this rotation:

1.) It's separated into two lines. Is there a reason to this? More specifically, after the first line (PS, IT, BS, BS, SS, UB), is there something that needs to be done (ie. RPD) before moving on to the second line?
2.) What does "2nd to last SS from the Death Runes you just made" mean?
3.) What is the best way to dump RP?
4.) Does this rotation require (or prefer) any specific glpyhs?

Thanks in advance.
#450SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by 2Face
I finally managed to read through all 18 pages of the Unholy DK PvE dps thread.
I'm in the process of rolling a DK to switch over to my main, so I don't know too much about how it works yet.

After 18 pages of reading, the generally accepted rotation for UDKdps is quoted:


I have a few questions I have about this rotation:

1.) It's separated into two lines. Is there a reason to this? More specifically, after the first line (PS, IT, BS, BS, SS, UB), is there something that needs to be done (ie. RPD) before moving on to the second line?
2.) What does "2nd to last SS from the Death Runes you just made" mean?
3.) What is the best way to dump RP?
4.) Does this rotation require (or prefer) any specific glpyhs?

Thanks in advance.
1) The separation is usual notation, it shows rotations in 2parts, which are 2 full sets of runes, until diseases drop(with epidemic). You can put them all on one line, but it'd probably end up being truncated and stuff. There's no pause however.

2) Means the 2nd SS is done with the deathrunes from the bloodstrikes. No idea why he'd bother explaining that since it's pretty obvious, unless you don't understand the concept of death runes.

3) Gargoyle > UB > DC in that order. If garg is up, use it, else use UB, and if it's already up, dump on DCs.

4) Scourge Strike is usually accepted as a good unholy glyph, refreshes diseases so you can sometimes just keep going. Else you reapply as needed. Icy touch is generally a glyph everyone takes, because the 10RP outdo the 10%dmg on IT on pretty much every build, but maybe the DW stuff. Last glyph doesn't really matter, ghoul is ok though I guess, or bone shield if you offtank with that spec.

Let's say u have Item A with 55 Strength and Item B with 132AP. Which Item should i pick?

#453SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Noraj
Originally Posted by Pyros
4) Scourge Strike is usually accepted as a good unholy glyph, refreshes diseases so you can sometimes just keep going. Else you reapply as needed. Icy touch is generally a glyph everyone takes, because the 10RP outdo the 10%dmg on IT on pretty much every build, but maybe the DW stuff. Last glyph doesn't really matter, ghoul is ok though I guess, or bone shield if you offtank with that spec.
The disease refresh from Glyph of Scourge Strike is definitely nice, but if you use Desecration in your build for the added damage modifier, you'll still need to Plaguestrike in the appropriate place. [Glyph of Plague Strike] as a minor is useful here since it further ups PS's damage for the times that you have to use it.

Originally Posted by blecap
One noobish question. As i read this on a forum "Focus on strength over AP. 1 str = 2 AP unmodified. Strength also scales with kings, some of our talents, and one of our major DPS runeforge weapon enchants (Rune of the Fallen Crusader) gets drastically better the more strength you have. "

Let's say u have Item A with 55 Strength and Item B with 132AP. Which Item should i pick?
For Blood, the difference after a few buffs drops down to around 4AP difference. It's only slightly higher of a difference for Unholy due to its 1% less strength modifier.

However, you're leaving a few things out: Is this an armor piece, or a necklace / ring / trinket ? If it's armor, it must not be plate, since plate doesn't have +AP on it anymore with the exception of two greens. If that's the case, do you have Bladed Armor? Because that would more than make up for the difference between the two pieces if the decision is to be based entirely on AP.

EDITED: Posting while sick and tired leads to one-sided readings.

#455SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3wow
Originally Posted by blecap
One noobish question. As i read this on a forum "Focus on strength over AP. 1 str = 2 AP unmodified. Strength also scales with kings, some of our talents, and one of our major DPS runeforge weapon enchants (Rune of the Fallen Crusader) gets drastically better the more strength you have. "

Let's say u have Item A with 55 Strength and Item B with 132AP. Which Item should i pick?
It depends. What spec are you (do you have bladed armor, +STR modifier talents, etc)?

In general though, there are plenty of leather pieces out there that beat out plate pieces even when considering STR modifier talents, Kings (don't forget, it works on agility as well), Rune of the Fallen Crusader and Bladed Armor. It would be easier to help you if you simply told us what both of the items were.
#456SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Daedalix
It also depends on if you are deep Blood spec or Unholy or neither. Unholy scales str by 5%, deep Blood by 8% through talents.

#458SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Bibdy
Does Abom's Might (and similar +10% AP raid buffs it doesn't stack with) count after Kings, or before?

If its after, then I guess that makes sense why we prioritise STR over AP (due to the AP we get from Strength getting both bonuses, while AP would only get one)

If its before, then only Blood is going to get more out of Str than AP, since it has STR boosting talents (due to AP from either stat would each be increased by 10% independently, so neither gets a benefit over the other without the Blood talents).

Anyone know for certain?
#459SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Torrential
Could somebody describe how to find the point of inflection for Frost Strike vs. Death Coil?

WD: Weapon Damage
MC: Melee Crit
SC: Sepell Crit (I understand these are different due to one using AGI and one using INT, is that correct?)
GoG: Guild of Gorefiend

Assuming spell hit cap and Morbidity.

Frost Strike: [(WD * .6) + 150] * (1-MC) + [(WD * .6) + 150] * (MC) * (2 + GoG)

I am still unclear on how AP effects spells like Death Coil as my DK is not my main and I've not focused much of my reading on DK stuff yet, so any help on getting Death Coil damage as well as a confirmation of my Frost Strike formula would be great.
#460SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Feorthas
Originally Posted by Torrential
Could somebody describe how to find the point of inflection for Frost Strike vs. Death Coil?

WD: Weapon Damage
MC: Melee Crit
SC: Sepell Crit (I understand these are different due to one using AGI and one using INT, is that correct?)
GoG: Guild of Gorefiend

Assuming spell hit cap and Morbidity.

Frost Strike: [(WD * .6) + 150] * (1-MC) + [(WD * .6) + 150] * (MC) * (2 + GoG)

I am still unclear on how AP effects spells like Death Coil as my DK is not my main and I've not focused much of my reading on DK stuff yet, so any help on getting Death Coil damage as well as a confirmation of my Frost Strike formula would be great.
Frost Strike is strictly superior to DC whenever you have a level-appropriate 2H weapon equipped and your spec is appropriate (ie you went 41+ into frost and buffed frost strike with all of the available talents). The only reason I have used DC since creation was a lack of Frost Strike (not enough talent points) or being out of melée and needing to dump RP.

Personal Opinion: Never spec Frost Strike when DWing; you need those points in unholy to boost your white swing damage.
#461SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Torrential

Frost Strike is strictly superior to DC whenever you have a level-appropriate 2H weapon equipped

#462SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		crimsonsentinel
Originally Posted by Bibdy
Does Abom's Might (and similar +10% AP raid buffs it doesn't stack with) count after Kings, or before?
10% str is added first and then 10% AP is calculated on top of your total AP.

Originally Posted by Torrential
I'm fully aware of this. I have, however, seen people claim FS is > DC even if dual wielding. I suppose I'll spend some time today finding all the relevant info and figure this out.
Frost strike benefits from killing machine and guile of the gorefiend, so even though it does less damage than death coil (although with all the frost talents, in my experience the difference in my gear is about only 10% and I have really terrible weapons) it crits at a much higher rate and for more. This does use up km charges though so you need to make sure you have the crit rate to sustain km for howling blast as well.

I don't think many people take fewer than 21 points into unholy for DWing. Gargoyle, blood caked blade, and necrosis is too much damage in that build. People who take FS generally take their points out from blood and possibly impurity. Also, FS DW builds go deep into frost mainly for guile of the gorefiend, at which point taking FS is just one more point anyways. Lastly, without impurity, FS is much more competitive with DC even without taking into consideration the crit chance.

Unique talents that FS takes advantage of:
Glacier Rot-10%
Black Ice-30%
Killing Machine-higher crit rate, depending on white crits
Merciless Combat-12% on targets <35%
Guile of the Gorefiend-245% crits

Unique talents that Death coil takes advantage of:
Morbidity-15%
Impurity-25% better AP scaling
Virulence-3% hit if you're under spell hit cap (which, by the way, added with misery, means that your hit rating required to reach spell hit and melee special hit caps are very close, allowing you to gear for other stats). When I'm DW specced I take virulence anyway for howling blast, but keep in mind FS doesn't need virulence to be hit capped.
Last edited by crimsonsentinel : 12/09/08 at 7:47 PM.

#466SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Wayde
weapon speed
What is the optimum weapon speed for a tanking dk?
#467SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3tedv
Originally Posted by Wayde
What is the optimum weapon speed for a tanking dk?
As slow as possible, to avoid getting parried by the boss (and thereby accidentally instagibbed). As a corollary, dual wield tanking is not a remotely viable option.
#468SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3jstorrie
Originally Posted by tedv
As slow as possible, to avoid getting parried by the boss (and thereby accidentally instagibbed). As a corollary, dual wield tanking is not a remotely viable option.
This depends somewhat on your spec. If your rotation contains very few parryable strikes, and you are using a slow main-hand, you may not be throwing out considerably more parryables than a 'normal' tank.

DW tanking's viability is crimped less by parrygib and more by the necessity to stack absurd amounts of +hit, and by the DW-favouring talents not lining up too well with a build that goes for the deep frost or unholy tanking abilities.

GoG is a 45% increase to crit damage. I can't math out going from 200% to 222.5% damage using a 45% increase whether with adding or multiplying bonuses. How does GoG create 222.5% damage?
Last edited by Torrential : 12/09/08 at 7:19 PM.
#471SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Feorthas
Originally Posted by Torrential
I'm feeling dumb here.

GoG is a 45% increase to crit damage. I can't math out going from 200% to 222.5% damage using a 45% increase whether with adding or multiplying bonuses. How does GoG create 222.5% damage?

Also, which here is correct (if either) for the frost component of Frost Strike?

150 * 1.3 (Black Ice) * 1.1 (Glacial Rot) * 1.13 (E&M)

or

150 * (1+.3+.1+.13)
GoG "Increases the critical strike damage bonus of your Blood Strike, Frost Strike, Howling Blast, and Obliterate abilities by 45% and increases the duration of your Icebound Fortitude by 6 secs."

So, what used to crit for 200% (100% + 100% bonus) now crits for 245% (100 + (100 + 45)).

Frost Strike = 1.3 * 1.1 * (0.6 * WEAPON + BONUS).
#472SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Torrential
Originally Posted by Feorthas
GoG "Increases the critical strike damage bonus of your Blood Strike, Frost Strike, Howling Blast, and Obliterate abilities by 45% and increases the duration of your Icebound Fortitude by 6 secs."

So, what used to crit for 200% (100% + 100% bonus) now crits for 245% (100 + (100 + 45)).

Frost Strike = 1.3 * 1.1 * (0.6 * WEAPON + BONUS).
Thanks. Frost Strike does benefit from CoE/E&M though right? I see no reason why it wouldn't.

#477SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by chrisb3
I badly need to know the anser to this also. The DK's in my guild have all decided to DPS as Blood, which seems to have the least amount of utility and an awful lot of useless leveling/healing talents.
I cannot actually find any theorycraft on which spec does the most DPS, so which is it and how far ahead of the other specs is it? A little advice would be greatly appriciated as I'm not quite sure what to make of DK DPS in raiding at the moment.
Yes, there are lots of talents in the blood tree for healing yourself while soloing or leveling, but in a raid DPS build, there is no need to take any of them (except, perhaps, for the first point of Rune Tap as a filler)...filling your spec with things like Scent of Blood, Bloodworms, and Vendetta for end-game is just out and out silly. The same goes for the tanking talents in the tree.

Ultimately, what you end up providing to the raid is Abomination's Might, Blood Aura, Hysteria, and Mark of Blood, all of which are fairly useful, with Hysteria and Mark of Blood being very powerful if used correctly. MoB provides a great relief to healers duing periods of rapid burst damage, and Hysteria, when actually used on the person in the raid that has the highest PHYSICAL DPS is huge buff...just using it on yourself certainly ups your own damage as blood, but it definitely isn't always the most judicious use of the buff.

#479SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3

#480SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Vierbein
Originally Posted by Volrath50

Also, does Ebon Plaguebringer only buff the diseases of the DK who applied it, or all diseases, including, say devouring plague?
Ebon Plague contributes to magic dmg, but it doesn't count as a disease when it comes to heart strike or obliterate.
What means you will still have bonus from two diseases, but dmg from magic will be increased(DC, IT etc...)

#483SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3rimmer
Originally Posted by Vierbein
Ebon Plague contributes to magic dmg, but it doesn't count as a disease when it comes to heart strike or obliterate.
What means u will still have bonus from two diseases, but dmg from magic will be increased(DC, IT etc...)
I think he's talking about the fact that Ebon Plaguebringer includes the effect of Crypt Fever which increase disease damage by 30%. As far as I know it increases all disease damage not just the DKs own, the only DK only part is it counting as a third disease for strike benefit.
#484SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Shoa
1: Currently in any list/compendium I find only IT/HB and DC are attributed to spell hit. Now at 8.9% melee hit I've missed with both Pestilence and Bloodboil, are they working asimilar to Judgement spells (Magical damage, melee hit properties) or have they been oversighted?
Death Knight spells have a natural 200% crit damage modifier (from Runic Focus), so they most likely function entirely as spells.

Unholy Blight seems to be capable of missing over the melee hit cap too. (And maybe Death and Decay?)
#485SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Bibdy
Does Abom's Might (and similar +10% AP raid buffs it doesn't stack with) count after Kings, or before?
I want to confirm that Abom's Might seems to be the last thing calculated when considering a DK's total AP. I tested with HoW and the Unholy Crusader proc, both applied their additions to AP and then Abom Might's addition was added on top of that.
#486SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Darian_TruBlade
Originally Posted by Volrath50
Sometimes, it appears that my runes regenerate in 7 seconds, not 10. Is this a display thing, or is there some reason runes might regen in only 7 seconds?
From the DPS Compendium, Section 4.1:

It was always assumed that Runes just had a pure 10 second regen time. This has proven to be false from various tests. The behaviour that has been noted is that after the first set of runes very often runes regen after 8 seconds. The current concensus is the following:

Runes have a 10 second regen time. However, if you do not use your regenerated rune as soon as it comes up, it will activate a timer (up to 2 seconds, is the current theory) which will count as the Rune being used.
Basically if you use a rune in the 2 seconds after it comes off cooldown it acts as though you used it immediately off cooldown. There's a little more in that section of the DPS Compendium that might help you if you're still having trouble conceptualizing this.

#492SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lazare
Originally Posted by chrisb3
Noone really ansered my question here, I am right in thinking that there is no consensus on which DK spec is the best for single target dps?
The DK's in my guild are just a drain on our raid with their low dps, and their refusal to even consider frost/unholy for raid buffs is calling their raid spots into question in my mind.
Checking out the WOW Meter site, and looking at the top 10 DKs by DPS on Patch, we see:
  • Unholy (4769 DPS)
  • Frost (4751 DPS)
  • Unholy (4599 DPS)
  • Unholy (4580 DPS)
  • Unholy (4499 DPS)
  • Unholy (4405 DPS)
  • Blood (4396 DPS)
  • Unholy (4393 DPS)
  • Unholy (4354 DPS)
  • Unholy (4321 DPS)

That data makes Unholy look like it dominates, but I suspect that's mostly a function of the sheer number of Unholy DKs running around right now. Certainly blood and frost can pump out very solid single target DPS in ideal conditions, and I think it's fair to say that the main criteria for picking a tree for DPS is a mostly a matter of personal preference and raid buffs right now.

If your DKs are doing poor DPS as blood, it's possible changing to unholy or frost will help - but what might help more is making sure they have the right spec, optimal gear/enchants/glyphs, and are using a vaguely sane skill rotation. Certainly changing specs shouldn't significantly lower DPS though, so if you need certain raid buffs those specs can provide, there's no reason not to except personal preference.
#493SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3crimsonsentinel
Unholy dominates because sigil of awareness is heads and shoulders the best dps item in the game for death knights atm, and it increases unholy damage more significantly than either frost or blood.
#494SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Patchwerk is also a VERY unholy friendly fight. No AE at all, the pets stay the whole duration. Unholy advantage melts like ice on heavy AE fights, or fights where pets AI fail them(heigan, grobbulus). Unholy is however the leading DPS spec, in general, with or without the sigil, even on boss AE heavy fights. And it destroys the other specs(at least blood, frost can dps decently) on fights that involve adds, especially massive little adds spawn(sartharion, gluth, noth) due to a much superior AE.
#495SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Feorthas
Originally Posted by Looter
Question:

Does the forst damage part of Frost Strike scale with attackpower like all other DK spells or does it stay flat?
Frost Strike is a weapon attack that is all Frost damage (yeah, the tooltip isn't worded in the best possible way :-/) so, yes, it scales with AP at a rate of 1 DPS per 14 AP like all other melee attacks.

#502SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Feorthas

I would think Rune Strike is better simply because it is unavoidable and deals roughly twice as much threat as a normal swing. It's definitely better Threat per RP as it costs a noticable amount less than FS and generates about the same amount of threat as a melée swing + frost strike.
#503SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Darian_TruBlade
Frost Strike is unavoidable. It's also pure Frost damage and thus not affected by armor mitigation.

The idea of comparing the two seems flawed. Rune Strike is a next melee attack that requires a dodge/parry and Frost Strike is an instant available so long as you have the RP and the GCD. I don't believe RP is so scarce while tanking that one can't use both.

#508SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by MissnL1nK
With that being said is it wise to macro RS into my rotation or should I avoid doing that based on the dmg from FS and possibly not having enough RP to use it when needed, or does it even matter.
You do still want to use Rune Strike in your rotation, especially with the upcoming changes involving it receiving a much larger threat modifier. It's there to smooth out the penalties of missing with any of your attacks. You should still find that you have enough RP for Frost Strike too.
#509SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
In my opinion it's not wise to macro RS, simply because there will be times when you want to have a specific amount of RP for something in the fight. For example, 20RP for IBF before a predictable burst, or 60RP(soon 40) for UB before adds spawns. You can stop pressing anything for a few seconds to make sure you have the RP, but that sounds a bit counterproductive to me. Instead, I bound RS to my mousewheel, so I just roll my mousewheel during the fight and RS everytime it's up, unless I don't want to.

Either way though, you want to use RS every cooldown. At low level of gear threat is a non issue, but we're running into threat issues more often now that people are pushing 5k DPS, especially fury wars and their total lack of threat dumps. It's GCD free damage too, which is good.

#512SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Aaberg

Blood is generally bad, until they patch then it will be pretty ok I think.

#514SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3richard
Another gear related question,
If I have 520 defense, how much resilience would I need to become crit immune?

Or, what is the chance for a boss mob (lvl 83) to get a crit on me?
#515SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Noraj
Originally Posted by richard
Another gear related question,
If I have 520 defense, how much resilience would I need to become crit immune?

Or, what is the chance for a boss mob (lvl 83) to get a crit on me?
This is based on numbers in this thread: [FAQ]Working theories of raiding at level 80

The chance should be 5.6%.

At 520, you have 4.8% chance to not be crit, meaning you need another .8%.

In resilience, that's... ((1 resilience / 1 percent) * (81.97497559 rating / 1 resilience)) *.8 percent = 65 resilience rating
#516SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3thevidon
Is the healing increase from Vampiric Blood counted before or after mortal strike?
#517SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3moghed
Short Answer: It doesn't matter.

Say it's before.

150% health from healing X 50% is 75% healing.

After:

50% healing +50% extra healing is 75% healing.

My question though is does Pestilence have a set way that it moves? I noticed awhile back that paladin's Avenger Shield would always bounce in a specific pattern. Does Pestilence do the same thing? Pestilence will be useful if you can use it twice to spread it to four targets, but it's not so useful if it just jumps to the same two targets twice.
