#755SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3joypunk
In a 20/51 DW build, what rotation would I be looking at?

The best answer I could find was a post-patch speculation post by kurokaze: Dual Wield Builds - Post #780

His spreadsheet showed an optimal rotation of PS IT BS IT DC IT DC / PS IT BS DC IT DC IT DC.

However, this only uses 5 runes per rotation (only one blood rune) among other things.
#756SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Janraea
Originally Posted by joypunk
In a 20/51 DW build, what rotation would I be looking at?
The best answer I could find was a post-patch speculation post by kurokaze: Dual Wield Builds - Post #780
His spreadsheet showed an optimal rotation of PS IT BS IT DC IT DC / PS IT BS DC IT DC IT DC.
However, this only uses 5 runes per rotation (only one blood rune) among other things.
If you must use a rotation, the best one I can think of is PS,IT,PS,IT,DC,IT,BS - PS,IT,DC,IT,DC,BS,IT, until 3.0.8. If you mean to ask about post-3.0.8, then PS,IT,UB,IT,DC,IT,BS - PS,IT,DC,IT,DC,IT,BS.

Using the priority system will serve you better though.
#757SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3joypunk
Originally Posted by Janraea
If you must use a rotation, the best one I can think of is PS,IT,PS,IT,DC,IT,BS - PS,IT,DC,IT,DC,BS,IT, until 3.0.8. If you mean to ask about post-3.0.8, then PS,IT,UB,IT,DC,IT,BS - PS,IT,DC,IT,DC,IT,BS.

Using the priority system will serve you better though.
I wasn't sure if there was a priority system considering the bulk of your rune uses goes to Icy Touch... a rotation seemed more logical in this case. I am more concerned with post-3.0.8 and would much rather have a priority system than a rotation.

What would the priority system be? From the looks of the rotation you posted (post-3.0.8) each line would start with PS IT followed by using BS to convert Death Runes, dumping RP to keep UB up, using Icy Touch, and then using Death Coil when your next rune use would put you over the RP cap.
#758SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Janraea
Originally Posted by joypunk
I wasn't sure if there was a priority system considering the bulk of your rune uses goes to Icy Touch... a rotation seemed more logical in this case. I am more concerned with post-3.0.8 and would much rather have a priority system than a rotation.

What would the priority system be? From the looks of the rotation you posted (post-3.0.8) each line would start with PS IT followed by using BS to convert Death Runes, dumping RP to keep UB up, using Icy Touch, and then using Death Coil when your next rune use would put you over the RP cap.
A priority system for 20/51 goes like: PS (no bp) > IT (KM up, or 2+ frost runes available)> UP (if it's down) > BS > DC > IT (no KM and only one frost rune active) > PS
Note that that's not strict - you'll need to adapt it for the period before and after you summon a gargoyle, and other cooldowns. If you don't want to spare the attention to watch KM procs, just combine the two IT priorities and stick it where the (KM up) IT is at now.
#759SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
That wasn't an 'optimal' rotation, it was the only one I tried. I got it off some post in the DW thread way back probably by Gothya. It looked very good so I didn't mess around with it.

It skips an unholy rune, not a blood rune; like the Antiseptic 2H Frost rotation, it assumes one death rune active per rotation segment from either a Blood Tap before the pull or from replacing an IT with a BS in the very first rotation.

I've definitely soured on the whole rotation idea though. I never use one in practice anyway. I've started recoding my tool to use priority systems instead, but the complexity of doing so (and doing it well) necessitated a complete restart and switch to C++, which adds considerable interface design overhead time. So don't expect anything more from me on that front for at least another week.

#766SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Janraea
Originally Posted by Pretoriaan
3 questions about that:

1: Could you possible link that specc?

2: And what kind of rotation is best to use with DW?

3: Is it best to use classic fury wepon speed like slow main hand and fast off hand?
1) http://talent.mmo-champion.com/?deat...h=142103060504
The points in dirge, epidemic, and unholy aura are all at-will - if you want desecration, move some there. This spec will change somewhat after 3.0.8, if you want a version for post-patch, pm me and I'll send you another.

2) No rotation at all, but a priority system.
Simple priority: IT(no fever) > PS(no plague) > HB > IT > BS > DC > PS

Complicated priority:
IT(no fever) > PS (no plague) > HB (KM up) > IT (KM down) > HB (KM down) > IT (KM up, DC instead if waiting one gcd will let you cast HB) > BB/BS (either of, depends on gear) > DC > PS (plague up)

If you really can't manage the simple priority, use the rotation:
IT,BS,BS,PS,HB,DC - IT,IT,IT,PS,HB,DC,DC (no IT glyph)

Generally, use BB if you're spell hit capped and not expertise capped, or if you have at least 20% spell haste from gear+buffs, or if you can hit more than one thing.

Edit: Forgot to say - gargoyle is a big damage source for us. He takes his stats from the moment of casting, so you want to pop trinkets/racials, and you want to do that after any strength/ap increasing procs go off (mirror of truth, greatness, unholy strength). You can boost his dps by 20-30% by casting him with an extra 1.5k ap. Also, when he's out, don't cast DC - he'll be eating your rp, and you can't make it fast enough to keep him out the full duration if you spend much of it.

3)Until patch, Fast/Fast is *far* better. After patch, it doesn't matter much - Slow/Fast will probably be slightly better.
Last edited by Janraea : 01/13/09 at 12:35 PM.
#767SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3gravedgr
Originally Posted by DaveyD1200
What is the expertise 'cap' for 2H and for DW?

I know it was proven recently that the hit 'cap' is now 8% but I havent been able to find any information on expertise.
Here is a quote from the tanking thread.
Originally Posted by dukes
- The 2h hit cap is 8%, both for autoattacks and specials. 8% melee hit is ~262 hit rating, which is approximately 10% spell hit (as the conversions are different).

- The spell hit cap is 17%. If you have Virulence and either Misery or Improved Faerie Fire, this is 11%. Considering that you should be aiming for 8% hit for melee, you'll end up with 1% spell miss with virulence and buffs, or 7% spell miss without virulence and buffs.

- Expertise removes 0.25% dodge and parry from a bosses avoidance per point. Each point takes ~8.2 expertise. The approximate values are 6.25% dodge and 15% parry that you need to overcome. This makes expertise approximately twice as valuable as hit up to the point at which you are capping dodge avoidance (26 expertise).

This makes hit very valuable up until 8% melee hit (262 hit rating), and expertise very valuable up until 6.25% reduction (26 expertise).
In case you didn't extract the number, its 6.25% expertise softcap.
#768SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
I've been reviewing my Be Imba page and while I've met the melee cap, I have not met the spell cap. I'm confused on how exactly to raise the my spell hit - I figured that capping melee hit would do it up until capping melee hit didn't... how do we do it? And is it really a vital statistic over say AP and Crit?
#769SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3SecondrateSaint
Simple question here, not especially relating to Death Knights, but they have the best example I can think of.

When you have a multitude of talents that provide +x% to (stat), how is it calculated? Is it [percentage of initial stat], followed by [percentage of the previous total], etc..., or are the +% added and then applied ([+5%+2%+4%]=11% more of stat x)?
#770SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ilzhahkha
Is there any consesus about what trinket's best in slot (except for greatness) for dualwield (0/32/39) pre and post patch? For me it seems like [Mirror of Truth] will become worse compared to [Bandit's Insignia] and [Fury of the Five Flights] post-patch when you no longer need crit for KM-proccs as well as a lesser effect from popping gargoyle during a multiprocc.
#771SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Oncelot
EDIT: NVM Found my answers in Blood DPS Appreciations Thread
#772SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Noraj
Originally Posted by Naerys
I've been reviewing my Be Imba page and while I've met the melee cap, I have not met the spell cap. I'm confused on how exactly to raise the my spell hit - I figured that capping melee hit would do it up until capping melee hit didn't... how do we do it? And is it really a vital statistic over say AP and Crit?
To reach the spell hit cap after reaching the melee hit cap, you just keep stacking more hit rating. In Wrath of the Lich King, crit, hit, and haste rating were all made to affect both melee and spells, just as spell power was made to impact both healing and damaging spells in a single unified stat. That means that the same hit rating you're using to up your melee hit chance is also upping your spell hit chance. The chance to hit with spells is just inherently higher than the chance to miss with melee attacks. Maybe there's something I'm misunderstanding about your question, though.

As far as +hit's importance, it is absolutely vital to hit the melee cap as any melee class, and Death Knights are no exception...until you reach that cap, hit grants more DPS for its itemization value than any other stat in most cases. As far as spell hit goes, it's still a boost to your overall damage to try and reach the cap, but not nearly as much so.

EDIT: The short version is that you personally with the gear I'm seeing right now on the armory would need to add 145 more Hit Rating to your gear to reach the 17% spell hit cap, just like the Be Imba page you're referring to says. You should also really consider checking out the Dual Wield thread to see how to improve your spec, especially with things going on like your skipping Virulence which is a talent which directly addresses the issue at hand.
Last edited by Noraj : 01/14/09 at 5:30 AM.

#774SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Suno

As a 2-hander tank though, this is an amazing change that will restore frost as the superior tree for my tank style, and it will make Dark Conviction a far less useful talent for tanks. I'll leave it to the DW pros to determine the precise drop in value of crit for DW'ers.

#777SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Sinidar
Ebon Plaguebringer bug - how bad is it?
Is the Ebon Plaguebringer bug bad enough to warrant a respec? I used to be the only Unholy DK in our raids, but recently our Blood switched over and now we're both putting out Ebon Plaguebringer. WWS still has me in the top 5 DPS for most fights, but it annoys me to know that I could be better if it weren't for some stupid bug.

Do you reccomend sticking with two Unholy DKs, or is it bad enough to warrant me changing to a Frost, Blood, or DW build? If so, do any of the alternative builds stand out, or are they close enough to let personal preference decide? From what I understand, 2H Unholy and DW are the strongest right now, but I really prefer 2H builds to DW.

Right now we generally have 1-2 Frost DK tanks, so the Frost buffs are a given in our raids, but no Bloods, Enhance Shammies, or MM Hunters; so no one is putting out the Abomination's Might type buff. I could go that route, but if Blood 2H is significantly worse DPS I feel like I might be better off just sucking up the DPS loss from Ebon Bugbringer and staying Unholy 2H.

I know one of us could spec into Crypt Fever, but since they're removing that option in 3.0.8 I don't really consider that a viable long term solution.

#778SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3AriochIV
Originally Posted by SecondrateSaint
When you have a multitude of talents that provide +x% to (stat), how is it calculated? Is it [percentage of initial stat], followed by [percentage of the previous total], etc..., or are the +% added and then applied ([+5%+2%+4%]=11% more of stat x)?
The various +% are summed and then applied.

WWS still has me in the top 5 DPS for most fights, but it annoys me to know that I could be better if it weren't for some stupid bug.

Do you reccomend sticking with two Unholy DKs, or is it bad enough to warrant me changing to a Frost, Blood, or DW build? If so, do any of the alternative builds stand out, or are they close enough to let personal preference decide? From what I understand, 2H Unholy and DW are the strongest right now, but I really prefer 2H builds to DW.

Right now we generally have 1-2 Frost DK tanks, so the Frost buffs are a given in our raids, but no Bloods, Enhance Shammies, or MM Hunters; so no one is putting out the Abomination's Might type buff. Blood 2H DPS is fine. Your trash dps is going to drop since your AoE isn't as good, but on bosses you might even see an improvement vs Unholy (I know I did). Also, that 10% AP buff is huge if no one is bringing it. Even if you see your own DPS stay the same or even drop slightly, you're contributing a huge buff to your melee. My own AP with Horn of Winter only is about 4300. It rises fast with raid buffs, and we have Fury warriors and Feral druids much higher than that. Abom's Might is adding an almost constant 400-500 AP to every one of your melees, vastly surpassing any damage you might lose from Unholy Blight or Gargoyle.

I've been raiding as Blood since early December using 51/13/7, and I routinely place top 5, and often top 3 in the meters. On fights that are friendly to my cooldown length I compete with our Fury warriors for the top spot (Gluth is very friendly to us, for example).

A treatis on Weapon Speed


Stat Weights:
(Approximate, courtesy of Methods)

The following is raid buffed for 2H specs pre hit and expertise cap:

StatUnholyBloodFrost
1AP1.00001.00001.0000
1STR2.48472.55702.3650
1CRT1.02071.28051.3212
1HIT2.46312.74852.9114
1Haste0.60460.63450.5619
1Exp2.16602.84812.0712
1AP-R0.59181.26930.9086
1AGI0.81500.91641.0008
1Armor0.02780.02940.0319
1dps (wpn)6.31698.43479.5283
Spec17/0/5451/13/717/54/0

And I would say that the core comparison would be Agility + Exp. vs Haste

#786SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Wuzzy-KirinTor

A treatis on Weapon Speed


Stat Weights:
(Approximate, courtesy of Methods)

The following is raid buffed for 2H specs pre hit and expertise cap:

1STR2.48472.55702.3650
1CRT1.02071.28051.3212

1AP-R0.59181.26930.9086
1AGI0.81500.91641.0008
1Armor0.02780.02940.0319
1dps (wpn)6.31698.43479.5283

Thanks! I had forgotten about the A treatis on Weapon Speed.

Hmm stat wise, if we break everything down into ratings such as listed in the table above, [Inevitable Defeat] has a 44.0139 advantage over [The Jawbone] in terms of stats. This is the equivalent of ~17.7 additional Str or ~7 higher base weapon DPS.

However, we run into a snag in terms of weapon delay, and therefore average weapon damage, when calculating strike damage. According to the A treatis on Weapon Speed, 0.3 weapon speed roughly equals to 1% overall damage raid buffed. Using that figure and multiply by 2/3 for the sake of expediency, we are looking at a 0.67% increase in damage for [The Jawbone]. Assuming 4400 DPS raid buffed, that comes out to be ~29.5 DPS.

So, how does one reduce it further so the two can be compared? >.>
#10000SourcePosted onundefined1.0000
#787SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Fireflash38
Originally Posted by Wuzzy-KirinTor
Thanks! I had forgotten about the A treatis on Weapon Speed.

Hmm stat wise, if we break everything down into ratings such as listed in the table above, [Inevitable Defeat] has a 44.0139 advantage over [The Jawbone] in terms of stats. This is the equivalent of ~17.7 additional Str or ~7 higher base weapon DPS.

However, we run into a snag in terms of weapon delay, and therefore average weapon damage, when calculating strike damage. According to the A treatis on Weapon Speed, 0.3 weapon speed roughly equals to 1% overall damage raid buffed. Using that figure and multiply by 2/3 for the sake of expediency, we are looking at a 0.67% increase in damage for [The Jawbone]. Assuming 4400 DPS raid buffed, that comes out to be ~29.5 DPS.

So, how does one reduce it further so the two can be compared? >.>
I am not seeing where you read that. From what I had read in the thread, BCB is normalized, ergo faster weapon is better (procs). Slower weapons are for PvP (burst).


Really, I do not think that there would be too much of a difference between the two, you would have to get a large amount of data off of Target Dummies to see any reliable difference.

Edit: If you were to test on a target dummy, I would reduce your rotation as much as possible (no RP dumping, no IT, just PS, BS, and SS [without glyph]). Hell, I would even just spam SS (no glyph) if it weren't for the necessity of including BCB (which is questionable, because it is proc based, and thus subject to RNG, making an accurate data collection poor).

I would try to limit the number of external variables as much as possible (no Runeforge, no external buffs).

I have a question concerning a tanking weapon.

I recently picked up [Cryptfiend's Bite] and I am currently using [Demise]. The top end dmg is hard to pass up for threat using [Cryptfiend's Bite] but I will losing hit if I do not use [Demise], and threat is already bad for DK's the way it is. What is a good way to determine which of these is more efficient to use?

#789SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Fireflash38
Originally Posted by MissnL1nK
I have a question concerning a tanking weapon.

I recently picked up [Cryptfiend's Bite] and I am currently using [Demise]. The top end and mitigation of [Cryptfiend's Bite] seem to be better but I will losing hit if I use [Demise], and threat is already bad for DK's the way it is. What is a good way to determine which of these is more efficient to use?

Sorry if something like this was mentioned previously that I did not see.
You would gain more threat by using the higher DPS weapon.

If you don't have problems with threat as is, no need to worry about it. If you are currently having threat issues, make sure you know about the bug that disables the % Threat Gains in Frost Presence after death. Just swap into blood and back again to clear it.
#790SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3phagadaena
I have a fairly simple question which may not have an entirely straightforward answer.

Two potential raiding DKs. One specced for Unholy tanking, other for Unholy DPS. The DPS has as close to perfect attendance as can honestly be expected of a human being. The tank's attendance will not be as high as the DPSers. Both are good players who pull their weight in a raid.

When running heroics I had the DPS yield the 3rd disease to the tank as much as he could and I noticed his DPS fell anywhere from 500-800 from what it normally is in said heroics with a warrior tank. I do not want to create a situation where one of the better DPSers is losing a good chunk of his damage, and I also don't want to create a sitaution where the warlocks are without Ebon Plague and the raid is without Unholy Aura more than need be.

My gut feeling is that the raider with the better attendance should probably be the Unholy representative, but I also realize that gut feelings sometimes get people into bad situations.

How should I handle this until the Ebon Plaguebringer issue is resolved?

How should I handle this until the Ebon Plaguebringer issue is resolved?
Honestly, if I was that worried about it (which I usually am), I would just voluntarily respec as needed. With dailies and stuff, respecs are much more affordable than before. If you played a druid or warrior before, you'll probably be used to respec'ing frequently.

While you go through the frequent respec'ing it's a good opportunity to try out various other specs and see for yourself which ones work for you.

#794SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
Semi-napkin math, see Proc Mechanics for variable definitions and such.

1127 strength unbuffed from my armory means a Fallen Crusader proc is worth 676 AP.

Fallen Crusader uptime on the mainhand with 1.6 speed and 1 strike every 5 seconds (averaging out a rotation with 2x PS 2x BS in 20 seconds):

p = ppm * 1 / swings per min = 1.2 / (60 / 1.6) = 3.2%
d = 15
v = autoswings per sec + strikes per sec = (1/1.6) + (1/5) = 0.825
u = 1 - (1 - p)^dv = 33.12% uptime, times 676 is 223 average AP.

Add in an offhand also with 1.6 speed and fallen crusader:

v = (2/1.6) + (1/5) = 1.45
u = 50.7% uptime, times 676 is 343 average AP, minus 223 is 120 AP gain from the offhand enchant.

Berserking on the offhand instead:

p = 3.2% as above, since berserking is also 1.2 PPM
d = 15
v = 1/1.6 = 0.625
u = 26.3%, times 400 is 105 average AP.

If I didn't screw anything up, the conclusion is clearly that berserking is worthless to us. Unless your gear is really really bad, and you don't get Kings, and you never summon your ghoul (who benefits from your STR, but not your AP). And if your gear is that bad, spend all the money on buying new gear instead of on mats for Berserking.
#795SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Caldar
General question.

With our normal 25 man raid group, I am the only DK in the raid. I typically spec unholy with some variaition of the standard 17/0/54 spec. This means that, at least on single targets, there is always the 13% magic damage buff but there is never the +10% AP or the 20% haste.

I am considering a respec for the benefit of the raid (I'm typically on top of the meters as Unholy and while that is nice for the epeen, in general I don't care about that if the entire raid is doing considerably better) and am wondering if Improved Icy Talons or Abomination's Might would be the better overall buff for the raid. We run 8 melee types on average.

I was thinking possibly something like the 31/39+1 DW build to gain Talons and keep Unholy Aura.

#801SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3richard
You can't really put a DPS number on unholy aura because it's very dynamic. On fights like patchwerk it is pretty much useless (saves maybe half a second running to him on the pull), whereas on fights like heigan, 4hm and any other fights that requires movement its value increases.
You kind of answered your own question already, because the variables are undefined, and they differ for every group.

#821SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
I'm currently dual wielding Reaper of Dark Souls in my main hand, and Avool's Sword of Jin in my offhand with a frost spec. I've been saving up emblems for Grasscutter. The issue here is that Grasscutter is offhand only, but is faster than Avool's. I don't particularly want to stop using Avool's sword, but do I really have a choice? It would seem dual wielding Avool in main hand and Grasscutter in offhand goes against all conventional knowledge about dual wield DPS, but Avool's DPS is more than Reapers, and its approx 1.1 speed faster.

Essentially what I'd like to know is if I should go ahead with buying Grasscutter and have a faster weapon by .1 in my main hand and a slower weapon in my offhand, or if I should scrap the idea and try to find something else, perhaps buy Mirror of Truth instead, because maybe its a DPS upgrade? (not really sure). Any help would be greatly appreciated - i'd prefer not to waste emblems on a sword that isn't good for my spec.
#822SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Darian_TruBlade
Originally Posted by Kelthuryon
It seems to have been demonstrated that the Blood Strike Glyph also benefits Heart Strike.

But I've seen many posters mention that they "heard" that Blood Strike Glyph would also deal bonus damage from attack speed reduction debuffs (like Frost Fever) on the PTR, effectively making the Glyph work on bosses.

Can anyone who actually ran some PTR raiding tests confirm ?
The reason why you may have heard that the Blood Strike Glyph will work off of attack/casting speeds reductions is due to a change to the Mage talent Torment of the Weak. That talent, like the Blood Strike Glyph, only works on movement slowing effects on live but is being changed to work off of attack and movement speed effects as well. As such many have been wondering if, as a side effect, the Blood Strike Glyph will also be affected.

Unfortunately there hasn't been any conclusive PTR testing to answer your question that I'm aware of, despite the fact that it's come up in the Blood DPS thread numerous times.

However, depending on your raid make up it can still work regardless as some movement speed slowing abilities can be applied on bosses due to a secondary effect. FFB, Infectious Wounds and Desecration are the most common sources of such effects. If you have someone providing one of those debuffs you can actually benefit from the glyph on Live.
#823SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
Naerys: You seem to be extremely confused somewhere. Let me break it down simply:

You want to attack as often as possible to proc Killing Machine as often as possible. This is so important that it's often worth it to go down 10+ DPS on a weapon in order to move from a slow (2.4-2.8) to a fast (1.5-1.6) weapon. Offhand hits versus mainhand hits are completely irrelevant; that is to say, you won't gain any KM procs by swapping your offhand with your mainhand.

Now, since you would be going from a 1.5 + 2.7 to a 1.5 + 1.6 (again, order doesn't matter for KM), you would be gaining significantly in addition to the increase in weapon DPS.


Note that this applies to this patch only. Next patch, speed becomes mostly irrelevant; just look for stats and DPS. Either way, Grasscutter is a solid upgrade. You might benefit more from Mirror though. You should also consider swapping your weapon hands, since your offhand is over 10 DPS higher than your mainhand, and offhand damage is halved. (Well, not quite halved with Nerves of Cold Steel, but still penalized.) Definitely swap if you don't have Frost Strike (cookie cutter DW build), but if you're messing around with a FS build, I'm not sure how the numbers stack up offhand.
#824SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Naerys
Kuro: Thanks for your quick response. I brought this up in my semi-serious raiding guild, and all I got was 'NO NEVER USE A FAST WEAPON IN MAIN HAND, ESPECIALLY IF YOUR OFFHAND IS SLOWER!' and I was put off because from reading through the threads on EJ, I figured it wouldn't be a problem. In any case, my build does have Frost Strike in it - going away from the theorycrafting norm to see how it turns out. So far, for the amount of low level gear I have, the DPS output is surprising. With a total of 4 low level items, 2 of them green, i'm doing about 1600-2.2k 5 man DPS depending on the group make up in heroics. It goes even higher in raids, and while that, by itself, is not an impressive number, just think what it will look like decked out in full epics.

I'll keep experimenting with my strange build and see if there is a DPS threshold based on gear. Thanks again for your input, I'll be getting Grasscutter in 10 emblems and then saving up for my T7 gloves and Mirror of Truth.


EDIT: Would it be better to throw Avool's sword main hand and use Fang on my offhand?

#825SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Iconoclasm
Another long time reader, first time post.
One concept that has a irked me since I started playing my death knight is the value of reaching the expertise cap. I've read a good amount of discussion on it, but i've yet to see a definitive decision or math to support it. Coming from a caster, I keep having the idea that expertise=melee hit, even though I know better. I recently came from a DW build to a 2h frost build. I am currently sitting at 17 expertise (one below my cap). Browsing through some of my recent WWS, Frost strike is 28% if my damage with oblit sitting close behind at 27%. Auto attacks come in at 22%.

I guess my real question is: Is it worth gemming/enchanting/gearing for expertise up to the cap (especially with frost strike leading damage)? Or is it just one of those stats that if gear has it, great, but don't try to stack it?

#833SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Septus

#838SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ashur25

People should really check other threads and blue posts. This is the 4th time it is asked/incorrectly posted as no cd

Howling Blast has a 5 sec cooldown. We added this back on late, so it may not have made the patch notes.

We are hearing some reports that the tooltip is not updating correctly, but if you try to use the ability twice in a row, you will find it will not work. We are investigating the inconsistency.

#840SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Megatron
Is there a superior leveling spec or is it just based on preference?
#841SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pfooti
Originally Posted by Megatron
Is there a superior leveling spec or is it just based on preference?
Speaking from personal experience, I found unholy to be excellent for 55-70, and blood to be superior from 70-80. Up to 70, your starting gear and relative power lets you AoE grind with unholy like a crazy person. Once you're in northrend, the mobs hit hard enough and live long enough that a heavy blood build for self-healing from blood worms and rune tap are pretty excellent. But that's not an empirical thing - I get the sense that all the builds are roughly equivalent for leveling.

CAVEAT: that's assuming you're mainly soloing and DPSing if you're in a group. If you're tanking a lot, picking up blade barrier and toughness is a really good idea.
#842SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Zungate
I levelled 55-80 as Unholy, and had no issues with downtime, not even when soloing big and evil group quests.
And mobs still went down fast enough, so I didn't consider respeccing.

But i agree with the above poster, for levelling all 3 specs seems to be about equal.
#843SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Alatar
Expertise value beyond 26?
Has anyone done any modeling to figure out how useful it is to stack expertise once you hit 26? I'm nervous because so much of our endgame gear has expertise and I'm already at the 26 cap.
#844SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Ashur25
Originally Posted by Alatar
Has anyone done any modeling to figure out how useful it is to stack expertise once you hit 26? I'm nervous because so much of our endgame gear has expertise and I'm already at the 26 cap.
If you're dpsing expertise beyond 26 provides absolutely no dps increase since 26 exp already negates dodge fully.

It's still somewhat good if you're tanking of course

#849SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Redroach
hmm... Since the patch is only ~12 hours old in EU and we didn't raid today, please forgive me if i can't provide a WWS, but:
I punched the Raid Target Dummy for around 10 minutes today and i've noticed (via recount) that Necrosis seems to be way off where it is supposed to be. Pre-3.0.8, Necrosis was in the order of around 2% - 2.5% of my total damage but today, it ended up being only 0.2% of total damage, with a damage range from 1 (!) to 76.
Both numbers are obtained with 5/5 necrosis (i actually re-skilled blood today to get vampiric blood).
So, this may just have been bad luck and 10 minutes sample-size is not a really big one, but, considering Necrosis should have been buffed and the fact that it was nowhere where you would expect it, this may have enough significance to at least ask about this in this thread.
Has someone observed similar numbers?

Pre-3.0.8, Necrosis was in the order of around 2% - 2.5% of my total damage but today, it ended up being only 0.2% of total damage, with a damage range from 1 (!) to 76.
Both numbers are obtained with 5/5 necrosis (i actually re-skilled blood today to get vampiric blood).

Necrosis can't overkill. You probably decreased the health of the heroic dummy to 1 hp early in your test and from that point onward necrosis only did 1 dmg

For what it's worth, Necrosis did 6.5% of my damage on Kel 10 man today (with 3.1k dps total)

Bad Connection
Greetings,

Cursed with a 26k connection speed at this time and wondering several things, I have seen people with similar gear and specs out damaging me by more then a small margin and wonder if it is my own rotations or my latency. I have sifted through piles of posts here but never quite find anything that helps with my particular scenario.

Question:

1. Will specs like the 32-39 be out of reach for someone with a 2-6k connection?

2. Are there any specs more forgiving to someone who has sometimes extreme cast delays due to slow connection?

3. While I realise this site is geared towards raiding I wonder what sort of numbers a 0-44-27, 17-0-54, 51-0-20 specs will have in heroics or on the dummies. (I see numbers for these in raid but haven't found very much info concerning a 5 man group)

#857SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
gynsu666:

I have no idea what a "26k" or "2-6k" connection is - dialup? I thought that would be 28.8k or 56k or one of those numbers. Or if you mean you ping between 2k to 6k, then it's hopeless; I've had the displeasure of attempting to play on a college network that got 1k-2k and on a satellite connection that ranged from 1k-4k and it's just not doable. If it's just dialup, you're probably no worse off than Aussies, who seem to manage quite well with normal rotations and the like.

Anyway, I haven't paid too much attention to the situation because it's clearly suboptimal play, but search for Unholy Presence. I recall several mentions in various threads of people pulling reasonable DPS in UP, just a bit lower than BP. I'd think UP would allow for quite a bit more latency/reaction time error with many setups since there's so much dead time normally.

PS>IT>HS>HS>HS>HS>DC>HS>HS>OB
Repeat Line 2

#861SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		gynsu666
Clarification
Originally Posted by kurokaze
gynsu666:

I have no idea what a "26k" or "2-6k" connection is - dialup?

My apologies, let me clarify. By 26k I mean connection speed of 26kbps dial up connection and by 2-6k I mean ping times. It isn't hopeless to play at that speed just very frustrating. 28.8/56k are max speeds but it is impossible to connect at a true 56k. In an effort to keep this as short I just included the speeds without reasoning behind them.

What I was trying to get at was finding a way to stay in the game but tailor my build towards a method that may not require exact rotations to be carried out in a set time. I have tanked all heroics but UP and tanked/off tanked Patchwerk so far. My thought is that auto attacks and dots work regardless of ping and looking to clarify that I guess. More or less, advice on what talents might work better with high ping times is what I am looking for.

#862SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Janraea
Originally Posted by gynsu666
Greetings,
Cursed with a 26k connection speed at this time and wondering several things, I have seen people with similar gear and specs out damaging me by more then a small margin and wonder if it is my own rotations or my latency. I have sifted through piles of posts here but never quite find anything that helps with my particular scenario.
Question:
1. Will specs like the 32-39 be out of reach for someone with a 2-6k connection?
2. Are there any specs more forgiving to someone who has sometimes extreme cast delays due to slow connection?
3. While I realise this site is geared towards raiding I wonder what sort of numbers a 0-44-27, 17-0-54, 51-0-20 specs will have in heroics or on the dummies. (I see numbers for these in raid but haven't found very much info concerning a 5 man group)

MORE POST:

My apologies, let me clarify. By 26k I mean connection speed of 26kbps dial up connection and by 2-6k I mean ping times. It isn't hopeless to play at that speed just very frustrating. 28.8/56k are max speeds but it is impossible to connect at a true 56k. In an effort to keep this as short I just included the speeds without reasoning behind them.

What I was trying to get at was finding a way to stay in the game but tailor my build towards a method that may not require exact rotations to be carried out in a set time. I have tanked all heroics but UP and tanked/off tanked Patchwerk so far. My thought is that auto attacks and dots work regardless of ping and looking to clarify that I guess. More or less, advice on what talents might work better with high ping times is what I am looking for.
If you're referring to a very high latency playstyle, go 2h, deep unholy and use unholy presence - PS,IT,SS,UB.SS - SS,DC,SS,DC.SS will get you a fair chunk of normal latency dps while leaving room for a one *second* (1000 ms) average latency. If you're latency is higher than that, or varies rapidly, you're playing the wrong class - rogue and feral druid are the only ones that can eat so much latency and still dps effectively.

If you need more information, pm me with more information about the range of your ping and I'll do some math for you. If you're referring to a modem speed, that number is unimportant to your dps, except that it implies your ping is probably higher than normal.

Edit: There is no way to do proper dps with a consistent 2k ping. But I recognize that you still want to play the game - the highest dps for crazy ping like that is either 2h unholy like I said, or 2h frost (antiseptic rotation), also in Unholy presence. A mutilate rogue is the only class/spec that can operate anywhere near full dps with that kind of ping.
Last edited by Janraea : 01/22/09 at 5:37 PM.

So i guess the questions are:
1. What spell do you use first when engaging AoE fight?
2. And how do you keep it going?

Do you go in and put on diseases -> pestilence, first and then UB, or perhabs the other way around? What about death n decay?

I've read quite a few of the Death Knight dps posts now and i dont seem to be able to find any which focuses on AoE. All the rotations in the thinktank seems to be about single target dps, and very little about AoE.
So i guess the questions are:
1. What spell do you use first when engaging AoE fight?
2. And how do you keep it going?

Do you go in and put on diseases -> pestilence, first and then UB, or perhabs the other way around? What about death n decay?
And what is the break point? How many mobs do we have to be fighting to actually be worth using one spell over of another?

Furthermore i'd like to say im just your standard Unholy spec taken fresh from the thinktank (exact spec), and atm it's just heroics im concerned about, but i'd believe same mechanics would be present in raids.
As unholy:
Death and Decay, IT PS Pestilence UB. That seems the highest potential for the initial runes. After this it depends on how long the pack lasts, another DnD with the IT/PS/Pest runes, and the first 3 runes probably on Scourge Strike+Bloodboil. As far as I can tell, any pull with more than 1 mob it's worth AEing. UB is better than Deathcoil if the mobs live 20s, even if it's just one, so obviously better if it's 2+. It's the same for tanking. There's no "guides" about AEing because there's not that many options anyway, and when you're AEing it's trivial stuff(trash).

#869SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3joypunk
I've been asked a lot recently to tank the whelp and fire adds when trying Sartharion with 2 drakes up. I've been told I should be able to do this with my DPS gear in Frost Presence, however when the whelps spawn I drop like a fly if I try and tank them all in my DPS gear.

I'm saving IBF for when they spawn and I'm trying to time it so Bone Shield isn't on cooldown and I can re-use it when the charges are gone.

Is there something I'm doing wrong or is it likely a healer issue? Should I be wearing my tanking gear instead? Or is our strategy wrong and should one of our tanks be picking up the whelps/fire adds?

Not sure how useful WMO reports are for this sort of thing, but here is a 10-man PuG where I was asked to tank the whelps/fire adds. First attempt was in DPS gear, the rest were in tanking gear.

WoW Meter Online : 1/21/09 - 10-man Sartharion


(Logged out in PvP gear so my Armory link won't be very useful.)
#870SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Telsak
It is a strategy problem. You really cannot be tanking sartharion whelps/elementals in dps gear and except to live.
The problem is two-fold. Firstly you *will* get crit by the adds, there is no but, if or maybe. Secondly, the deathknight super-cooldowns are no longer Super™ with IBF based of your defense value and bone shield dropped down to 20% so even trying to temporarily use them to brute-force tanking the whelps won't work.
I regularily tank the adds on our 3drake kills and it is a hairy business in full tank gear.
You most definately should not be in dps gear and try to tank them.
#871SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3blitzseed
spell penetration?
I have been seeing more and more Dks getting spell penetration gems in their gear. I want to know how this affects Dks damage.
#872SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Psykhe
Does [Effulgent Skyflare Diamond] reduce all magic damage by 2% (i.e. sartharions or malygoses breath attack or the arcane voretx damage) or does it only work with targeted spells (i.e. KTs frostbolts)?
#873SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by blitzseed
I have been seeing more and more Dks getting spell penetration gems in their gear. I want to know how this affects Dks damage.
It affects Death Knight damage in the same way it affects every magic class's damage. It lowers resists and therefore increases the overall damage done. Effectiveness varies by spec, of course.

Does [Effulgent Skyflare Diamond] reduce all magic damage by 2% (i.e. sartharions or malygoses breath attack or the arcane voretx damage) or does it only work with targeted spells (i.e. KTs frostbolts)?
Simply reading the tooltip indicates that it lowers ALL magic damage taken.
#874SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Darkside
It affects Death Knight damage in the same way it affects every magic class's damage. It lowers resists and therefore increases the overall damage done. Effectiveness varies by spec, of course.
At least in BC, spell pen mostly did 0 dps help, except for special bosses like Supremous that had a lot of Fire Resist. The devs may have removed spell resistance on bosses for Wrath.

Likely the DKs in question had spell pen for PvP, where you can resist Mind Freeze with Frost Resist from Mark of the Wild.
#875SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Flamingcloud

Sapphiron has a ton of frost resist, regardless no serious dk would have spell pen for pve.

#882SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Gort
Originally Posted by Darkside
Not true: Patchwerk Resists.

I haven't tried so yet, but I plan on enchanting my cloak with spell pen. and observing the change in my DPS.

What you observe is a level-based partial resist. NOTHING can affect a level-based resist. Spell penetration is 100% useless in all contexts bar PVP, and, for us, very probably even then.


Again, and I can't emphasise this enough, spell penetration is useless in PVE. Period. Ask any DPS caster. Never gem for it, never gear for it, never enchant for it. There is ALWAYS something better you can get.

#884SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Irise
Originally Posted by Griefknight
I have a quick question, what is the "best" frost rotation for a frost tank. (not VotTW) I mean best as in the most common and tested rotation that shows optimal results. I've currently been doing IT>PS>OB>BS>BS//OB>OB>OB//repeat.
The short answer is that it depends on your build.

Personally I use this build hence I try to use HB whenever the cooldown is up and Obliterate otherwise. It results in much better tps. One thing to note is that if you have an HB build then you should open with IT>HB>PS since PS can be parried and HB cannot.
#885SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by Irise
The short answer is that it depends on your build.

Personally I use this build hence I try to use HB whenever the cooldown is up and Obliterate otherwise. It results in much better tps. One thing to note is that if you have an HB build then you should open with IT>HB>PS since PS can be parried and HB cannot.
I don't see how that is a "HB" build when it looks like a basic deep frost build. I'm currently 11/50/10 and I'm almost the same spec as you. I'm still wondering what deep frost rotation does the most single-target TPS.
#886SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3MiklaDfar
Char Sheet - Attack Power Calc
I am trying to understand how the attack power number is arrived at on the Character Info sheet. I have done some work but continue to struggle. I have been using (assuming no buffs, consumables):

Char Sheet AP = 2*Str + Gear AP + Bladed Armor * Armor / 180

But this does not work. I can get the Yellow AP to work (Gear AP + BA*Armor/180), but the white AP does not equal 2*Str.

I know the Strength is correct (since it matches the Char Sheet). Am I missing some base stat, or a (passive) talent, race bonus or something?

Here are the exact numbers

Blood Presence:
1801 From Strength (900.5 Str, matches Char Sheet)
655 From Gear AP (part of tooltip yellow AP)
0 Buff - Blessing of Might or Battleshout
0 From Consumables
359 From Bladed Armor Talent (part of tooltip yellow AP) (12938 Armor)
1 Buff Multiplier from Abominations Might, TSA Or Unleased Rage
2815 TOTAL
3022 Char Sheet (2008 + 1014)
#887SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Zodiac
Your missing the % str talent modifiers that some talent specs give.
#888SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Irise
Originally Posted by Griefknight
I don't see how that is a "HB" build when it looks like a basic deep frost build. I'm currently 11/50/10 and I'm almost the same spec as you. I'm still wondering what deep frost rotation does the most single-target TPS.
I didn't know what spec you were comparing it against but simply put if you have Subversion then you are better off using Oblit for single target threat (other than KM procs). The build you and I are using doesn't have it so we are better off using Howling Blast as it will hit for more than Oblit at all times.

Edit: I should add that I am not sure if my Oblit and HB comparison holds at all gear levels and I am just speaking from personal experience. I think pretty much the rule of thumb is that if (a) if you have Subversion and Rime (b) Howling blast isn't doing 24% more damage than Obliterate THEN you should use Oblit for single target threat. With my current build/gear this is not the case and hence I use HB.
Last edited by Irise : 01/24/09 at 6:00 PM.

And how much slower will i be leveling? If needed, i could use a Frost leveling spec for now, then respec to a Frost tanking spec once i reach 80.

#891SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by Elnaith
Im leveled as Unholy thus far (im 75 now), but im considering switching to Frost for leveling and then tanking.My question is, how much better is Frost for Tanking pre-80? And how much slower will i be leveling? If needed, i could use a Frost leveling spec for now, then respec to a Frost tanking spec once i reach 80.
I believe that pre-80 and at 80 frost is the best tanking spec until you get to tanking 10man naxx and higher, at that point frost still does a lot of TPS but lacks health compared blood or unholy. I also leveled as frost from 55.
#892SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dirich
Originally Posted by Elnaith
Im leveled as Unholy thus far (im 75 now), but im considering switching to Frost for leveling and then tanking.My question is, how much better is Frost for Tanking pre-80? And how much slower will i be leveling? If needed, i could use a Frost leveling spec for now, then respec to a Frost tanking spec once i reach 80.
I disagree with the previous poster who answered you.

Tanking unholy is the easiest. Frost require "skill" or, better said, "timing".
An example: HoS event is damn troublesome if you are frost. You need to time your HB and pestilence with the weaves of mobs, but you must grow treath on mobs too since your dps-es are going wild. And no matter how good you are, unless you are overgeared (and can kill every wave before the next one) there will be a time toward the end when you'll be unable to time your attacks with the weaves (since the next one spawns when you are still in combat with the previous one) and you'll start trying to get the mobs back while they run wild in the room (mind, it can be done, but you need a perfect knowledge of the encounter).
You'll have the same problems when you don't know (or can't know) the timing of things. It's a limitation of us being a cd class, unholy on the other hand has UB and morbidity 3/3 which helps a lot solving those problems. Blood I never tried in aoe, but 3/3 morbidity has a sense in a blood tank spec so I guess it's a bit easier for blood than for frost.

As frost I use d&d only for opening, of course, since I need some initial aoe aggro in order to be able to spread diseases. The problem is that morbidity is a waste of points in such a spec, but without it you'll find that sometimes you either wait or you start a pull without d&d, which means a HB "wasted" (no frost fever on target) to get the time to apply diseases and do pestilence. (I don't take morbidity anyway, but I do spend 1 point in the 11th tier talent in frost, it's good cc in 5man and it spread frost fever, which is good even in raids).

If you do a lot of istances or play with a healer, level as unholy in order to maximize your aoe abilities. If you mostly solo, I don't know, when I leveled there was the old death strike glyph and it made things REALLY different (I aoe-ed packs of 8 mobs no problem - in solo and using pulls of 3 mobs to rec).
#893SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by Dirich
I disagree with the previous poster who answered you.
I don't see how unholy is "easier" then frost. I don't know if you read or posted in the DK tanking discussion thread when it was at page 10 but I did and the spec to tank with was frost until you had 45%+ avoidance because at that point unholy was better. I do realize that was pre3.0.8 but the only difference now is frost shines when it comes to threat and with the "nerf" to BS it makes unholy even less good-looking. I also forgot to add to my other post is that when tanking as frost you should always have 3/3 morbidity for heroics or pre80. I don't see how it is "wasted" points because it isn't like you need points in other places and morbidity is an amazing talent for all three trees.
#894SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kashir
Originally Posted by Griefknight
I don't know if the gear you have on your armory is what you DPS with or if that is your off-set but if it is then yes HB will do more damage. I'm just trying to find a OB rotation besides IT>PS>OB>OB>BS>BS//OB>OB>OB// but I don't think there is another one.
An easy 2H Frost rotation is: IT OB OB BS (rotating the last BS / OB depending on whether BR or DR comes up first). This requires a DR to start the rotation. For Frost, IT hits hard enough to make replacing PS worthwhile.

In 3.0.8, you also probably want to replace an OB with a HB whenever KM procs, or throw a FS in the middle. If you leave it to the end of each rotation, you might miss procs.
#895SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Dirich
Originally Posted by Griefknight
I don't see how unholy is "easier" then frost. I don't know if you read or posted in the DK tanking discussion thread when it was at page 10 but I did and the spec to tank with was frost until you had 45%+ avoidance because at that point unholy was better. I do realize that was pre3.0.8 but the only difference now is frost shines when it comes to threat and with the "nerf" to BS it makes unholy even less good-looking. I also forgot to add to my other post is that when tanking as frost you should always have 3/3 morbidity for heroics or pre80. I don't see how it is "wasted" points because it isn't like you need points in other places and morbidity is an amazing talent for all three trees.
Single target tanking is easy, problems may arise in aoe tanking.
Unholy roation for aoe is d&d IT PS Pestilence UB at the beginning. You may put down 1 d&d that is generating threat over time for you on evey mob in the area, and UB which does the same for every mob around you. And you recast d&d every cd which means it's up 2/3 of the time. So you just need to run near adds, if they are away from the d&d and you can aggro them all trough UB, than bring them on d&d for easy aoe threat.

As Frost your best tps in aoe is using HB. HB is a direct spell so it generates threat only on a precise istant. 3/3 Morbidity is an option, but it is "not needed" if you are good at playing frost and the points you save you can spend in blood to get more ap and/or 2h damage.
The problems arise from adds that "join the party" when your d&d is gone, and both pestilence and HB are on CD (or runes are). If they spread before you get your cd back it's gonna be troubles if they are more than 3 (Death grip, dark command and IT, than you have to start build a bit of threat on them or the healers will aggro them again). Once per minute I can use Hungering Cold and block the adds, spreading frost fever which means I get aggro on them and I can HB them soon for greater damage (aka threat). Once a minute is more than enough unless you run with noobs.
Morbidity makes thing easier, though I have no way to compare the two frost solutions we are talking about aoe threat wise, I know I can hold aggro on aoe over dps that are much more geared than me, and I won on tps on an almost full t7.25 unholy tank (altough it was pre patch and there's no way for me to know if it was a matter of frost presence bug or if he was slacking). No doubt, on the other hand, my build generates more single target threat than one with 3/3 morbidity, which is means more dps from me during bosses and that dps with better gear can unleash a bit more of their dps

So, in the end, without morbidity (may it or may it not be more tps than a build without), frost can do an excellent aoe work, it only asks for more skill/attention/timing/whatever and can unleash better tps/dps on bosses. Thus, I consider it unneeded in a serious frost build.
And it seems the community agree, considering the 2 standard frost build (now in need of an update maybe) have no point in morbidity too (DK tanking thread, first post).


Regardin the frost tank vs unholy tank matter, they are both capable tanks, and I can't tell which is better threat on single target or which has better survivability since many things changed with this patch. But I do not doubt they are both viable for endgame. Altough our friend is levelling and has a lot of HCs in fron of him before tanking naxx10 & co. Which means it's mostly a matter of playstyle that should lead his choice.

EDIT: minor spelling.
Last edited by Dirich : 01/25/09 at 6:58 AM.
#896SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3dreadai
The word is spelt 'threat'
Not treath or trath

#897SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Dirich
If you talk about my example with the t7.25 unholy dk, as I said there could have been many factors. The point is we both were there tanking and I had aggro (which proves that I had more tps than him). I can't show proof of it, but there is no point in me trying to sell you a false story.

Concerning the better threat on single target in a frost build that choose morbidity 3/3 over one that goes for ap/2h damage talents in blood, there's no need for math. It's self evident. If you have the same talents but for those 3 points, one build has X tps, the other one has the same tps but 3 points that will be spent in talents that give more ap and 2h damage and so more single target tps.
EDIT: There's of course the assumption that the build with 3/3 morbidity wouldn't use d&d for single target tanking too. Since it's an aoe ability it makes sense it provides less tps on single target than you could have by using single target skills. This, though, should be proved, but I think the single target unholy rotation is proof enough.
As I said, aoe wise I can't say anything without proper testing or math.

Which bring me to the point: what's the reason to ask for proof for something self evident or a proof about something that could have been caused by a well known bug or by slacking? (it would have made sense to ask for proof if I had talked in general about frost aoe tps vs unholy aoe tps, but mine was an isolated example)
The only thing that would need data to be discussed is the only thing I did not say anything about: aoe threat comparison.

#898SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3dreadai
Originally Posted by Dirich

(it would have made sense to ask for proof if I had talked in general about frost aoe tps vs unholy aoe tps, but mine was an isolated example)
The only thing that would need data to be discussed is the only thing I did not say anything about: aoe treath comparison.
Because that is the point of these forums, multiple posts recently have been stating 'Here is my spec, I am doing 3.4kTPS on Ebon Hold dummy, my rotation is 'Blah' and I think I do better ae threat than I did when I was unholy'

These posts are pointless assertions based on 'looking' at something. Like the guy who said that his attaks couldn't possibly be landing at the same time because his animations didn't show that and it was 'obvious' when there were pages of parses showing Dual wield attacks landing at exactly the same moment.

Baseless assertions do nothing other than muddy the waters. What might seem 'obvious' to you or me, might not be so to a first time visitor to the forum. If you provide evidence in the form of parses, recount screen shots or similar, we end up with a series of assertions which have a foundation in fact, with evidential support.

Oh and by the way, the word is still THREAT. It's not hard to spell.

#900SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by dreadai
Because that is the point of these forums, multiple posts recently have been stating 'Here is my spec, I am doing 3.4kTPS on Ebon Hold dummy, my rotation is 'Blah' and I think I do better ae threat than I did when I was unholy'

These posts are pointless assertions based on 'looking' at something. Like the guy who said that his attaks couldn't possibly be landing at the same time because his animations didn't show that and it was 'obvious' when there were pages of parses showing Dual wield attacks landing at exactly the same moment.

Baseless assertions do nothing other than muddy the waters. What might seem 'obvious' to you or me, might not be so to a first time visitor to the forum. If you provide evidence in the form of parses, recount screen shots or similar, we end up with a series of assertions which have a foundation in fact, with evidential support.

Oh and by the way, the word is still THREAT. It's not hard to spell.
I don't really see how recount or other similar information can prove anything really. I'm not even sure what you're arguing about either. I haven't used unholy since the patch, but even with the DnD nerf, I'd expect AE threat to be fine. It is easier to use than frost, mostly because once it's started, most of it is automatic, but the initial application is probably just as hard. You drop DnD, IT>PS one mob, pestilence them then pop UB. At that point, wandering plague, ub, dnd and disease ticks do the work for you, and you don't really need to target anything. You just respread disease/reapply dnd if needed.

As frost, the pull is just as annoying, but you do need to keep spreading frost fever and pressing howling blast everytime it's up. However the initial burst of frost is generally higher because it happens sooner. DnD, IT Pestilence Bloodtap HB. You don't have to plaguestrike, saving one GCD, and HB burst threat all at once. You do need Bloodtap up to be able to lay down the DnD however, but you can do it without any DnD, and cast it later for sustained threat. You can deathchill if the pack is important for guaranteed high threat burst, and randomly you'll get procs helping(rime will let you dnd even without bloodtap, km will guarantee the crit on hb).

With that said, in my experience(unholy prepatch and frost now), AE threat is still a non issue. People start AEing pretty much asap, and I still hold aggro on packs fine with either. So most of the discussion is moot.

As for morbidity, you have 2 spare points in a typical frost builds. Those 2points can easily go in morbidity for trash pulls(it's still 5secs more than a full morbidity, but viable nonetheless). Your other options are single threat mechanics, so it's a matter of taste. But it's not impossible, or hard, to get morbidity in a frost build, you're not sacrificing vital talents for it. With that said, I can do fine without it as frost, when it's pretty much necessary as unholy or blood.
#901SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Elnaith
Thanks for all the help guys, that cleared up my issues on Tanking. But i still have the question of whether or not Frost is up to par for soloing purposes. I imagine i would be doing plenty of instancing, but how much slower will my questing go?
#902SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Elnaith
Thanks for all the help guys, that cleared up my issues on Tanking. But i still have the question of whether or not Frost is up to par for soloing purposes. I imagine i would be doing plenty of instancing, but how much slower will my questing go?
The biggest unholy advantages are Pale Horse(mount speed) and Unholy Aura(run speed). You could enchant your boots to mitigate unholy aura, but you'd still ride your mount slower between various quest spots. Other than that however, frost would be fine for leveling, it won't be that much slower. One other issue that may rise is the lack of self healing, frost is the worst healing tree, so you might have to slow down on AEing and/or chaining mobs to death strike more. But if I had to compare frost to other classes, it's still very good. It's not the best of the best, but it's much better than lvling as a healing spec, or some of the normal specs too for other classes.

You could just run instances as unholy though, and level as unholy.
#903SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dkij
I'm wondering what the general opinion is about Haste, lately?

While it was discussed ad nauseum previously, it's been a while since. What I gathered was that haste/armor pen. were generally useless in most specs. Is that still the case?

Specifically, I'm blood, and while relying mostly on strikes etc. I do see on my recount numbers a large portion of my DPS being from white hits. Similarly, I suppose armor pen. would be somewhat useful for blood dps?
#904SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3richard
Useless is a big word, but both armor pen and haste aren't very desirable for DKs. 51/0/20 will probably see the most benefit due to Necrosis and BCB. Remember that armor pen will still affect Necrosis because it will increase your white hits and therefor Necrosis as well.

The DPS compendium covers the subject as well, but I don't think it's updated to reflect the buff to Necrosis: Death Knight: PvE DPS
#905SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kashir
I can think of two things in 3.0.8 which may increase the value of +Haste.

- Rune Strike has its threat increased slightly (about 12.5% overall). Not a huge buff for +haste.

- By all accounts, Killing Machine scales with weapon speed bonuses (Heroism, Windfury, etc.). Does it also scale with actual +Haste value?

#907SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ashur25
Originally Posted by Hyperaktiv
What do you have to back up your statement regarding haste ?
Haste only increases your white damage (+ associated talents). The problem is that white dmg is only ~25% of your dmg.

So Haste only increases 25% of your damage while things like Strength, hit, crit, weapon dmg and such increase 100% or nearly 100% of your damage
#908SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Hyperaktiv
Originally Posted by Ashur25
Haste only increases your white damage (+ associated talents). The problem is that white dmg is only ~25% of your dmg.

So Haste only increases 25% of your damage while things like Strength, hit, crit, weapon dmg and such increase 100% or nearly 100% of your damage
Haste affect Gargoyle's cast speed, Ghoul's haste, GCD on your spells (howling blast, icy touch, death coil, blood boil, pest), gives more leeway for tight rotations, and also, tests indicate that Str>AP>Haste for 0/3X/40-1 spec when special hit capped.
#909SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Dristig
Originally Posted by Hyperaktiv
gives more leeway for tight rotations
When did haste start affecting GCD (left out "for Death Knights")?
Last edited by Dristig : 01/26/09 at 12:50 PM.
#910SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3slant
Originally Posted by Dristig
When did haste start affecting GCD?
Patch 2.4. It only applies to spells, not melee abilities or strikes.
#911SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Hyperaktiv
Originally Posted by slant
Patch 2.4. It only applies to spells, not melee abilities or strikes.
Which I clearly stated. Thank you nevertheless.
#912SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dristig
I thought global cooldown couldn't go lower than 1 second though? So haste only affects spells not swings and only if you are not in Unholy Presence? I'm just trying to make sure I value it correctly.
#913SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dirich
Haste affects the GCD when you use "spell" abilities, when you use "physical" abilities, it doesn't affect it.

So if you have enough haste to reduce the GCD to 1 second and you cast Fire Blast than your GCD is 1 second. If you use Mortal Strike than it's still 1.5 seconds.

As far as I know DKs have both "spell" and physical abilities, so haste should affect them differently. Plus it affects the weapon swinging speed.

It's a bit long answer, but I wasn't sure to have correctly understood what you wanted to know, so I just wrote down it all.


EDIT: And yes, 1 sec is the lower bound for GCD.
#914SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by Dristig
I thought global cooldown couldn't go lower than 1 second though? So haste only affects spells not swings and only if you are not in Unholy Presence? I'm just trying to make sure I value it correctly.
Yes, but IIRC the spell-based specs that benefit from the haste reduction to GCD get better DPS from Blood Presence over Unholy.
#915SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Matkap

#916SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Matkap

Use the search feature before you ask questions, and yeah it works.
#917SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Psykhe
Originally Posted by Hyperaktiv
Haste affect Gargoyle's cast speed, Ghoul's haste, GCD on your spells (howling blast, icy touch, death coil, blood boil, pest), gives more leeway for tight rotations, and also, tests indicate that Str>AP>Haste for 0/3X/40-1 spec when special hit capped.
Also, haste increases the procrate of killing machine and the fallen crusader runeforge. With either effect a good deal of your dps or boost all of it.

Frost/blood specs get currently more dps when using unholy presence partly because of this.

I would assume this is because the dps gain from the replacement item budgets is greater than the dps lost from the occasional dodge, but Im not all that melee savy.
#919SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kermits-finger
I have a question regarding defense rating. I have been through DK Tanking Discussion, and I will admit that I may have missed what I was looking for, there is a lot of information in that thread.

I saw a player requesting a tank for a 10 man Naxaramas run and said the tank needed to have a defense rating of 600. I asked them why they required a defense rating of 600 when 540 was uncritible? They replied “just to make sure”… I began to think about it, wouldn’t it be a waste to spec for defense over 540 when you could be using those slots or enchants or what have you for increasing damage potential since that would go to increasing threat? Granted, the higher your defense rating the more it goes to increasing icebound fortitude, but is that extra bit that it grants worth passing the damage potential?

I guess what I am getting at is… “Is it better to increase defense rating as high as it will go, or is it better to stop at 540 and invest in damage specing since the higher your damage potential the higher the threat you generate?”

If I have inadvertently done something wrong I apologize, this is my first post...
#920SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raronikenshin
Originally Posted by Kermits-finger
I have a question regarding defense rating. I have been through DK Tanking Discussion, and I will admit that I may have missed what I was looking for, there is a lot of information in that thread.

They replied “just to make sure”… I began to think about it, wouldn’t it be a waste to spec for defense over 540 when you could be using those slots or enchants or what have you for increasing damage potential since that would go to increasing threat? Granted, the higher your defense rating the more it goes to increasing icebound fortitude, but is that extra bit that it grants worth passing the damage potential?

I guess what I am getting at is… “Is it better to increase defense rating as high as it will go, or is it better to stop at 540 and invest in damage specing since the higher your damage potential the higher the threat you generate?”

You answered your own question when you asked him, really.

The sole purpose of Defense for DKs is to become uncrittable. The +Dodge/Parry are icing on the cake. Gem/enchant for threat and survivability after you hit 540.


Question: How does a heavy Unholy DPS tri-spec fare? Something along the lines of this. I know it looks weird, but Nec and BCB only go well with IT, really. Give it a shot, or stick to a cookie-cutter Unholy DPS build?

Oh, and another question. Unholy AoE grinding - Blood or Frost pres? Unholy Presence is borderline useless, but I guess it'd go well with the above-mentioned build (which sadly has almost 0 AoE utility).

#921SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3◊ forostie

Edit: forgot to ask my question.
I don't understand what you are trying to do with this spec. If you are raiding, Crypt Fever would be useless (assuming you'd have an EP DK already in the raid, which you should). Obliterate is a fairly weak ability when it doesn't have its' buffing talents (Merciless Combat, Rime, Guile of Gorefiend, Tundra Stalker; alternately Might of Mograine, Blood Gorged) and with that spec you'd have to use it as your primary nuke. I'd stick strictly to Scourge Strike for any deep Unholy spec, if you want to Obliterate a Frost spec would benefit you much more (and more so than a Blood spec which is pretty average DPS at the moment).
#922SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by Raronikenshin
You answered your own question when you asked him, really.

The sole purpose of Defense for DKs is to become uncrittable. The +Dodge/Parry are icing on the cake. Gem/enchant for threat and survivability after you hit 540.

You couldn't be more wrong? Given that defense is barely below dodge in terms of avoidance, and IBF scales with defense, taking defense past 540 is not at all a bad thing.

There's no reason to demand a hard value above 540 (such as the 600 the previous poster had mentioned) but saying that the sole purpose of defense is uncrittability is plain misinformation.
#923SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3dreadai
I think that what they are trying to say is that there is no harm in having extra defence but you shouldn't gem for it past the crit cap as a dodge gem will provide more raw avoidance than a Def gem will.

Having 541 Defense puts your IBF at 41% and it scales pretty nicely from there, but it is (at best) an 18 second cooldown every minute. Anything that coincidentally adds to that is good, but aiming your gearing towards being nail hard less that 1/3 of the time is a bit counter productive when you could be moderately better the whole time.
#924SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by dreadai
I think that what they are trying to say is that there is no harm in having extra defence but you shouldn't gem for it past the crit cap as a dodge gem will provide more raw avoidance than a Def gem will.

Having 541 Defense puts your IBF at 41% and it scales pretty nicely from there, but it is (at best) an 18 second cooldown every minute. Anything that coincidentally adds to that is good, but aiming your gearing towards being nail hard less that 1/3 of the time is a bit counter productive when you could be moderately better the whole time.
Yes, in a gem situation X dodge > X defense. The problem is morons running around with misinformation about defense being useless after 540. 20 defense is superior to 10 dodge on an item in real world situations.

Also, trivialising IBF is kind of ridiculous. Let's assume the worst case 12 second duration

Scenario A: You use it whenever it's up over a long fight. 20% of the bonus damage mitigated counts toward your overall mitigation over the course of the fight. E.G. Increasing your IBF mitigation by 5% is roughly equivalent to increasing your overall mitigation 1%. (I have a feeling I'm slightly off on that, but it's close enough to prove my point)

Scenario B: You're saving IBF for a large known spike, or as an "oh shit" button. Well, if it's being relied to pull duty to reduce an abnormally threatening spike, chances the bonus mitigation is *really* useful. Now I know it's not backed up by the theory re: Scenario A, but saying that increasing the power of your oh shit button is trivial seems to be a bit of a ridiculous assertion.



What I find truly bizarre about this is that I can remember a year ago when people were complaining that relying on avoidance was too streaky/unpredictable. Now people are saying that a 1/5th uptime damage reduction is so unpredictable as to not be worth considering? I'm not advocating stacking defense, I'm just saying that it is consistently underrated in situations where you don't have perfect choice in how you're itemizing the points (not gems, basically.)

Assuming constant use of IBF @ 12 seconds, and the rather debatable assumption that 1% avoidance roughly equals 1% mitigation in usefulness (thus 1% IBF bonus = .2% avoidance), I'm curious about what the relative worth of defense is for DKs vs. Dodge.
#925SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3dreadai
I didn't say that, at all, or certainly to belittle IBF was not my intention.

I was making an example of how taking a superior dodge item over stacking defence past cap gives a bigger permanent advantage, I brought IBF in to magnify the point.
However you choose to use IBF can never impact how fucking awesome it is. 1min c/d on shieldwall, personally I hit it before every trash pull when it is available.
#926SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3snowee
Quick question about DW weapons (only just decided to try DW after not seeing a decent 2H drop for ages):
After the KM change, what is the best setup to use? slow/fast, fast/fast?
Currently have [Last Laugh], [Split Greathammer] and [Silent Crusader] any advice on what to MH/OH would be much appreciated.
Currently I am using LL MH due to its higher DPS, and SG OH as I think fast is best for OH, and I haven't seen slow/slow or fast/slow discussed, so I assume fast is better OH.
#927SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Alatar
Quick question about gargoyles and bloodlust: should we pop gargoyle just before bloodlust or just after? I have always thought you should pop gargoyle first, but it occurs to me that if you pop gargoyle after bloodlust, the "snapshot" that the game takes of my buffs when I pop I pop gargoyle would mean it gains the benefit of bloodlust vicariously.

Can anyone shed some light on this?
#928SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by snowee
Quick question about DW weapons (only just decided to try DW after not seeing a decent 2H drop for ages):
After the KM change, what is the best setup to use? slow/fast, fast/fast?
Currently have [Last Laugh], [Split Greathammer] and [Silent Crusader] any advice on what to MH/OH would be much appreciated.
Currently I am using LL MH due to its higher DPS, and SG OH as I think fast is best for OH, and I haven't seen slow/slow or fast/slow discussed, so I assume fast is better OH.
Originally Posted by Zurm
While I'm in no position to say for certain whether [Last Laugh] is or is not the best in slot for DW, there are a few things to keep in mind. First, while Last Laugh will have superior DPS and comparable ap/hit to most other 1H weapons, it will lack other stats (crit, expertise, armor pen, haste) where it has invested ilvl in defensive stats(defense, parry, and extra stam, in this case). Since white/weapon damage is such a small part of a DK's DPS when compared to other melee classes, it further "devalues" it. Finally, you probably want a slow MH nowadays for extra strike damage since you lose nothing in terms of KM/BCB/Necrosis, which further devalues Last Laugh because in the OH slot it's high dps is only worth 65%, while still offering sub-par stats.

Again, I'm not trying to say Last laugh is bad... I'm just trying to point out there's a lot to think about when determining how good it is when compared to items like [Hailstorm], [Split Greathammer], [Silent Crusader], or [Widow's Fury].
This was quoted from the last page of the "A treatis on weapon speed" thread.
