#934SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raronikenshin
Originally Posted by JALbert
Yes, in a gem situation X dodge > X defense. The problem is morons running around with misinformation about defense being useless after 540. 20 defense is superior to 10 dodge on an item in real world situations.
Of course 20 Def is superior to 10 Dodge. Edit: Apparently, 10 Def is too!

I never claimed it's useless, I meant it's not necessary past 540. A PuG is not more likely to get a 560 def DK than a 541 one. Also, notice how I said Gem/enchant?

Originally Posted by forostie
/snip
You're right. I think I was a little blitzed when I asked that.

Edit: damn you and your follow-up questions.

Originally Posted by JALbert
Assuming constant use of IBF @ 12 seconds, and the rather debatable assumption that 1% avoidance roughly equals 1% mitigation in usefulness (thus 1% IBF bonus = .2% avoidance), I'm curious about what the relative worth of defense is for DKs vs. Dodge.
Napkin math time.

From what I recall, at 540D it's 35%. Let's assume at 600 it's 40%.

60 Defense (~300 Defense rating) equates to an extra 2.4% Dodge and 2.4% Parry, a 2.4% chance to be missed and it reduces the amount of damage you take via IBF by 5% one fifth of the time (w/o glyph), so by 1% over a longer period of time.

You need 40 Dodge rating for 1% Dodge, so 300 dodge rating = 7.5% Dodge, which is less useful than 2.4% Dodge, 2.4% Parry, 2.4% chance to be missed and 1% damage reduction, if only slightly.

In conclusion, gemming for Defense is better than gemming for D/P, even if the numbers for IDF's reduction portion that is based on Defense are off, partially because IDF reduces all incoming damage, not just physical, by 1%.


Edit 2:
Originally Posted by Darkside
Try looking in your fucking spellbook.
Made me lol.
#935SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3overvolting
I have a question as a non-dk.

If you have an abundance of DKs in a raid how do you make best use of them?

Some of the raids I participate in involve 5-7 dps DKs, all of which are 17/0/54 unholy spec.

They're doing very poor single target dps and come bottom on patchwerk but usually on trash they top the meters AOEing. Unfortunately this is quite useless sometimes.
All of their AOE visual effects also get annoying to the rest of the raid who have to watch for grobulus fart clouds and other visual cues.

How would you make best use of having the privilege of bringing so many dps DK's to a raid? Should they be encouraged to spec blood for better single target damage? With just one as frost for the melee buff?
#936SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3foolish_fool
At least one of your DKs should be unholy, since it brings unholy aura and the spelldamage debuff. You should definitely have both the other raid buffs in some form, at the moment they may be brought by an enhancement shaman, but having a DK provide them instead will likely increase the damage of the shaman as they can thus take more beneficial talents. One idea may be to have one of them switch to tanking and have a warrior/paladin/druid dps, though that depends entirely on your raid group.

As to their damage, are you sure that they are well itemized/using the correct rotations? If they are performing badly as 2h Unholy, they may perform badly in any spec.
#937SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raronikenshin
Originally Posted by overvolting
I have a question as a non-dk.

If you have an abundance of DKs in a raid how do you make best use of them?

Some of the raids I participate in involve 5-7 dps DKs, all of which are 17/0/54 unholy spec.

They're doing very poor single target dps and come bottom on patchwerk but usually on trash they top the meters AOEing. Unfortunately this is quite useless sometimes.
All of their AOE visual effects also get annoying to the rest of the raid who have to watch for grobulus fart clouds and other visual cues.

How would you make best use of having the privilege of bringing so many dps DK's to a raid? Should they be encouraged to spec blood for better single target damage? With just one as frost for the melee buff?
Not more than one 17/0/54 DK, because Ebon Plaguebringer doesn't stack.

You should definitely have a Frost DK for IIT, and 1-2 (since you have 5-7 total) Blood DKs for Aura, Hysteria and Mark of Blood.

Direct the rest to Frosty DPS Discussion (no magic hat required), so they do decent single target DPS. It's extremely easy once you get the hang of the rotation.

But yeah, never have 5 DKs of the same spec in a raid. =/

I have a question regarding 17/0/54-dps.

Also it seemed that my Scourge Strike hit for a lot less than before, but this might just be me looking wrong, quite sure it used to crit at least for 8k on Patchwerk but this time around it usualy critted 6.7k-7.3k (and I have the aweareness glyph.).

#939SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3MadTexan
Are the +expertise talents reflected in the value shown on the character sheet or are they hidden in the same way that +hit talents are for other classes?
#940SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Swarly
Originally Posted by Raronikenshin
Not more than one 17/0/54 DK, because Ebon Plaguebringer doesn't stack.

You should definitely have a Frost DK for IIT, and 1-2 (since you have 5-7 total) Blood DKs for Aura, Hysteria and Mark of Blood.

Direct the rest to Frosty DPS Discussion (no magic hat required), so they do decent single target DPS. It's extremely easy once you get the hang of the rotation.

But yeah, never have 5 DKs of the same spec in a raid. =/
I believe it's already been concluded that the dps loss from having two UH DKs in raid is not quite as severe as everyone thought. If you want a more thorough explanation on that you can search through the UH thread.

As for the question of what to do with that many DKs in a raid, I'll agree that they certainly shouldn't all be specced UH and you should take steps to make sure you're supplying yourself with all the necessary raid buffs. Problems with single target dps would probably have less to do with them all being UH and more to do with player error as the EP bug alone shouldn't drop them all to the bottom of the meter. Switching specs won't necessarily increase their dps as UH is still quite strong (if not the strongest) 2H dps spec, so you might want to make sure that they are properly speccing/glyphing and using optimal rotations/priorities.
#941SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by MadTexan
Are the +expertise talents reflected in the value shown on the character sheet or are they hidden in the same way that +hit talents are for other classes?
To the best of my knowledge, the values are shown on the character sheet.

#945SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by Griefknight
I would imagine [Angry Dread] in both slots or Angry Dread MH with [Hailstorm] OH.
You would want a Hailstorm OH in this setup, in order to maximize BCB mainhand procs. However, the best DK OH right now is actually [Last Laugh], due to the higher DPS and strength.

[e]: kurokaze is indeed correct, I had done some testing earlier that seemed to indicate otherwise but looking over my numbers again, I see that BCB procs both OH and MH swings. However, since Cinderglaicer is a percentage, not a PPM (with I think a 5% proc chance), it is still better to use a fast offhand while dual wielding.
Last edited by Darkside : 01/29/09 at 5:35 PM.
#946SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
BCB procs on the weapon that causes the proc as of 3.08. There's no slow mainhand fast offhand benefit there. Faster is better for BCB, period. This outweighs the benefit that slow weapons provide to strikes, unless you have Frost Strike. The people who migrated to slow/fast after the patch, frankly, are either bad at math, misinformed, or lazy, unless their slow weapon is simply better (i.e., it's Angry Dread and they don't have Last Laugh). See a recent post by me in the DW thread for numbers.
#947SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kinolas
I had a question about Blood Worms.

I read the Blood thread and would have never thought about spec'ing into them until I saw some discussion about them helping to maintain over 75% health to keep that increase in damage.

Question is, from the early days of the expansion, I have heard that Blood Worms cause more problems then they're worth for raiding. IE they run off and attack other targets and that they can soak up heals and such. With that in mind I had a Blood spec in mind that excluded them, however upon reading the Blood thread I saw several people state that they no longer go off and attack mobs and such and that since they actually damage a mob it's a DPS increase while healing you. But what about the heal bit? Are Blood Worms still a "no go" for a raiding spec?
#948SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3AriochIV
My experience with Bloodworms is that they don't do enough healing past about level 70 to be noticeable, and if you're interested in self-healing, the points are better spent elsewhere. The only reason I've seen for people taking Bloodworms is that at least they provide some small amount of DPS, as opposed to Blood Aura or Vampiric Blood.

I have one point in Rune Tap, and full points in Vampiric Blood and Blood Aura (which is especially valuable to me because I DPS in Unholy Presence), and I have no trouble staying above 75% even in encounters like Sapphiron.

#951SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
Assuming all important buffs are covered (which is handled by a single enhancement shaman to cover both Blood and Frost buffs, as the unique auras are trivial), the DPS loss for stacking EP appears to be significantly less than the DPS loss between the top Unholy and the top Blood/Frost parses. Hell, I just posted nearly 6K DPS on a 3 minute Patch kill (virtually all of the 6k+ parses are 2-2.5 mins) while fighting for my EP stack and generally losing.

If you're that concerned, you can have some of them switch to 32/39 variants, but IMO that spec is a good bit harder to play well than 17/0/54 or even 0/20/51, and will probably require some gearing up in the weapon department.

#954SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raronikenshin
Originally Posted by Jeager
As a Frost or Unholy spec using HB or SS as your main attacks, is spell pen worth it? If so, how much?

And also, is it more for PvP or PvE?
Spell pen is absolutely useless for PvE, even for casters, except on some gimmick fights.

For PvP it's decent, as it reduces chance of MF and DG being resisted.

Unholy:
Plague Strike -> Icy Touch -> Blood Strike 2x -> Scourge Strike -> Unholy Blight -> Scourge Strike 3x -> Death Coil until RP is depleted

#959SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3oll

Major - Glyph of Ghoul, Glyph of Obliterate, and either ***Glyph of Icy Touch or Blood Strike

#965SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by Dotswtfownd
Swordguard Embroidery - Spell - World of Warcraft

How much AP is this tailoring enchant worth?
From the wowhead comments on the page you linked:

"It's an ICD, not GCD (difference is internal vs. global). 300 AP for 15 seconds every minute averages out to 75 AP."
#966SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dotswtfownd

From the wowhead comments on the page you linked:

"It's an ICD, not GCD (difference is internal vs. global). 300 AP for 15 seconds every minute averages out to 75 AP."
Thanks for verifying, there was some disagreement in the comments section. Oddly enough, that tailoring enchant looks to be arguably the best profession enchant min/max wise.

#969SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3huntcaudata
Originally Posted by Raronikenshin
Balance them. You don't think either of those, you think "I should have enough HP to not die against X, and enough avoidance that my healers don't run OOM in 10 secs flat".

And it's better to gem for Defense than Dodge, for avoidance.
This is patently false. Don't lie. Dodge gives more avoidance per point/item budget than defense, until you have upwards of 1000 dodge rating, then diminishing returns will even them out.

Defense does also improve IBF, but that is a seperate matter entirely.

#971SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
[Titansteel Bonecrusher] has better stats, sure. [Angry Dread] has 13 more DPS. [Crypt Lord's Deft Blade] has potentially better stats still than Titansteel, if you're at a particular point regarding preexisting haste, but again, you give up 13 DPS. The tradeoff is absolutely not worth it. The difference in stat values is worth around 3 AP - that's less than 1 DPS is worth on the mainhand.

#974SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert

The amount of dodge rating needed for defense to overtake it @ 540 defense is lower than 1000 rating anyway. IIRC around a 3:2 ration of defense rating to dodge rating was close to ideal for maximizing just avoidance.

#977SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Orlgin
I have a question about diseases and how the damage is calculated. The tooltip clearly shows the damage per tick and based off that data, we get the 0.055 coefficient for AP. A simple example:

A level 79 character has 2410 AP. He has Bone Armor, full Ebon Plaguebringer, Rage of Rivendare. He's also specced for Black Ice and Desecration. He also is in Blood Presence. He attacks a level 80 dummy. PS -> IT -> BB -> BB and lets the diseases expire.

He gets these results:
Blood Plague ticks: 339
Frost Fever ticks: 494

According to the tooltip,

Blood Plague: 30.7 + 133 bonus damage from AP
Frost Fever: 25.3 + 133 bonus damage from AP

Now how does 163.7 get to be 339 and 158.3 become 494?

I tried this first:

163.7 * (1.3 * 1.15 * 1.13 * 1.1 * 1.05 * 1.02) but the result was 325.7995 for Blood Plague.

158.3 * (1.3 * 1.3 * 1.15 * 1.13 * 1.1 * 1.05 * 1.02) but the result was 409.568 for Frost Fever.

The in-game numbers are just higher than any calculations I try. No debuffs on the dummy. No one was around.

So what am I doing wrong on my calculations?
#978SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• Embar
Originally Posted by Orlgin
I have a question about diseases and how the damage is calculated. The tooltip clearly shows the damage per tick and based off that data, we get the 0.055 coefficient for AP... [snip]
So what am I doing wrong on my calculations?
You are probably missing Impurity (1.25 multiplier to bonus damage from AP). So we get the following:

Blood Plague: (30.7 + 2410 * 0.055 * 1.25) * (1.3 * 1.1 * 1.13 * 1.05 * 1.02 * 1.15) ~= 391
Frost Fever: (25.3 + 2410 * 0.055 * 1.25) * (1.3 * 1.1 * 1.13 * 1.05 * 1.02 * 1.15) * 1.3 ~= 494

Frost Fever tallies with your in-game results, but Blood Plague doesn't. Playing around with the numbers a little, if you omit the multipliers for Desecration and Rage of Rivendare, you net a calculated value of ~338 for BP, which is closer to what you actually see.

My best guess is that RoR and Desecration are not contributing to your initial PS/BP ticks since the 'conditions' for both to be applied do not actually happen until after your BP tick is locked in. This result is not totally unexpected since shadow priest dots work in a similar fashion (SWP not gaining the 10% from shadow weaving if applied before the shadow weaving buff is stacked fully). It could be tested further by re-applying EP and checking to see if the ticks are now of the expected 391 size. However, it is interesting that Ebon Plague's +13% spell damage and +30% disease damage do not work in the same way - I suspect that it's because EP is a debuff, but desecration (and shadow weaving) is a buff.

I'm not specced into Desecrate/RoR, but I went to test Tundra Stalker and IT/FF in a similar fashion. The first time I applied FF, the size of my tick was 257. However, when I re-cast IT before the old FF expired, the new FF ticked for 284. When I hit PS before IT, the BP tick size was 205, and this did not change even after FF went up, until BP was reapplied, after which it was the correct 226.
Last edited by Embar : 02/01/09 at 2:43 PM.

#981SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
WotLK Diminishing Returns - Avoidance - TankSpot
#982SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Lazare
JALbert and Raronikenshin: You were wrong, and huntcaudata was correct. Please fail less.

At current gear levels dodge is better than defence once you are crit immune, and you should not gem for defence instead of dodge. You appear to be quoting from some outdated numbers meant for warriors, not DKs. Warriors get more avoidance per point of defence than we do, and the miss cap is currently estimated at 16%. The combination of these factors make defence far weaker than you seem to think it is.

Or if you'd like an example: Glancing around the Armory, and making allowances for raid buffs, a DK in top epics right now might have, oh... 689 defence rating on gear (enough to be crit immune), 1200 strength, 300 agility, 350 dodge rating on gear, and 350 parry rating on gear. Now that will vary a fair bit raid buffs, spec, gear choices, etc., but it hardly matters - plug those numbers into the DR formula and the comparison isn't even close - with those numbers dodge rating is 23% better.

For defence to win, you'd need something like 1200 strength, 300 agility, 780 dodge rating, 0 parry rating. That sounds great, until you realize that the gear needed simply doesn't exist. And Ulduar gear, when added, will have even more strength, pushing the target dodge rating back even further. If you could get tanking plate with agility instead of strength it might be feasible - except you wouldn't really want to use gear like that, even if it existed, which it thankfully doesn't.

In short: Gem dodge, not defence. It doesn't matter what gear you have, once you are crit immune the marginal benefits of dodge rating exceed that of defence rating. Whenever you have a choice go for dodge.


Edit: This post is talking about pure avoidance and ignoring IBF. In retrospect, that seems like a silly thing to do. Please refer to my later post for an explanation of why defence actually is better than dodge once you include IBF.
Last edited by Lazare : 02/02/09 at 10:25 PM. Reason: Mia culpa

#984SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3huntcaudata
Originally Posted by Darkside
WotLK Diminishing Returns - Avoidance - TankSpot
I'm not sure if this was meant to refute my statement, but it doesn't. This is where the numbers in my spreadsheet come from (not this thread exactly, but Tankspot, and they are the same numbers). Also, post 42 in that thread confirms what I'm saying (though for warriors this time), Dodge gives more avoidance than Defense per point (for any currently reasonable gearset).
#985SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by Lazare
JALbert and Raronikenshin: You were wrong, and huntcaudata was correct. Please fail less.

At current gear levels dodge is better than defence once you are crit immune, and you should not gem for defence instead of dodge.
He said nothing about current gear levels. He said Dodge was better until you had 1k dodge rating. In an utter vacuum, ignoring the effect on crits, Defense is still better for avoidance.

At the gear levels needed for uncrittability, Dodge is marginally better for sheer avoidance due to the fact that you already have 600+ defense rating. Read my post which already said this, read the link to Tankspot. I'm arguing semantics, yes, but it's an important distinction when you're thinking about how gearing and theorycrafting works.


Also, I don't buy that dodge > defense for gemming. The difference between gemming dodge and defense is quite small, and everyone seems to ignore IBF in their calculations.
#986SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3huntcaudata
Originally Posted by JALbert
He said nothing about current gear levels. He said Dodge was better until you had 1k dodge rating. In an utter vacuum, ignoring the effect on crits, Defense is still better for avoidance.

At the gear levels needed for uncrittability, Dodge is marginally better for sheer avoidance due to the fact that you already have 600+ defense rating. Read my post which already said this, read the link to Tankspot. I'm arguing semantics, yes, but it's an important distinction when you're thinking about how gearing and theorycrafting works.


Also, I don't buy that dodge > defense for gemming. The difference between gemming dodge and defense is quite small, and everyone seems to ignore IBF in their calculations.
I believe you are incorrect on almost all counts. I don't know why you would care whether gemming for defense is better if you have 0 defense rating, since you're obviously not a tank in that case. You are just arguing semantics, which is silly in itself, but you are also flat out wrong.

1) Even at 1 defense rating, Dodge is still worth more per point until Defense until 104 dodge rating (with 1 agility, 1 strength, 1 parry rating as well, since this is a hypothetical argument).
2) At any reasonable gear level, that is, 689 defense rating, Dodge is better than Defense until 732 Dodge rating. But, this isn't really reasonable gear. It's still gear with 1 Agility, 1 Strength, and 1 parry.
3) At an actualy reasonable gear level, for example 1000 strength, 100 agility, 200 parry rating, Dodge is better than Defense until 1108 Dodge Rating. This will vary, more strength will make Defense worse, more agility will make Dodge and Defense both worse, etc.
4) The point on which you are entirely, stupidly wrong, is "In an utter vacuum, ignoring the effect on crits, Defense is still better for avoidance." Not only is it not better in a vaccuum (no gear), it is not better at any reasonable gear level currently available.
5) The one point on which you are right is that this does not dictate gemming choices. Just because Dodge gives you more avoidance does not make it better. You may value overall damage taken (TTL), or Effective Health, or you may require a certain percentage impact on IBF. All of these are good reasons to consider gemming with Defense (or stam, etc.)

It is unfortunate that we're having this discussion in the simple question thread. To remedy that:

Q: What should I gem for when I am concerned with survivability?
A: It depends. Until gear changes significantly from that currently available: If you want to maximize avoidance, gem for dodge. If you want to buff IBF while getting good avoidance, gem defense. If you want to maximize Effective Health, gem stamina. Never ever gem parry.
#987SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by huntcaudata
I believe you are incorrect on almost all counts. I don't know why you would care whether gemming for defense is better if you have 0 defense rating, since you're obviously not a tank in that case. You are just arguing semantics, which is silly in itself, but you are also flat out wrong.

1) Even at 1 defense rating, Dodge is still worth more per point until Defense until 104 dodge rating (with 1 agility, 1 strength, 1 parry rating as well, since this is a hypothetical argument).
2) At any reasonable gear level, that is, 689 defense rating, Dodge is better than Defense until 732 Dodge rating. But, this isn't really reasonable gear. It's still gear with 1 Agility, 1 Strength, and 1 parry.
3) At an actualy reasonable gear level, for example 1000 strength, 100 agility, 200 parry rating, Dodge is better than Defense until 1108 Dodge Rating. This will vary, more strength will make Defense worse, more agility will make Dodge and Defense both worse, etc.
4) The point on which you are entirely, stupidly wrong, is "In an utter vacuum, ignoring the effect on crits, Defense is still better for avoidance." Not only is it not better in a vaccuum (no gear), it is not better at any reasonable gear level currently available.
5) The one point on which you are right is that this does not dictate gemming choices. Just because Dodge gives you more avoidance does not make it better. You may value overall damage taken (TTL), or Effective Health, or you may require a certain percentage impact on IBF. All of these are good reasons to consider gemming with Defense (or stam, etc.)

It is unfortunate that we're having this discussion in the simple question thread. To remedy that:

Q: What should I gem for when I am concerned with survivability?
A: It depends. Until gear changes significantly from that currently available: If you want to maximize avoidance, gem for dodge. If you want to buff IBF while getting good avoidance, gem defense. If you want to maximize Effective Health, gem stamina. Never ever gem parry.


I already said that Dodge will give better avoidance returns than defense at real world gear levels. What you said was "Dodge gives more avoidance per point/item budget than defense, until you have upwards of 1000 dodge rating." That was the only thing I was taking issue with. Now that we've both made it clear how that statement should be taken, that part of it should be done with.

Which you should gem for is still an issue.
#988SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Moke-Malorne

#989SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by Moke-Malorne
Hey i was just wondering how much +hit and expertise a Death Knight should have for end gaming tanking such as 25man Naxx and what not?
This is totally based on your gear set-up and there isn't a set amount. If you can't hold aggro get more expertise until 26, if you still can't hold aggro find a weapon upgrade, and if you still can't hold aggro find a new spec or rotation.
#990SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lazare
Originally Posted by JALbert
He said nothing about current gear levels. He said Dodge was better until you had 1k dodge rating. In an utter vacuum, ignoring the effect on crits, Defense is still better for avoidance.

At the gear levels needed for uncrittability, Dodge is marginally better for sheer avoidance due to the fact that you already have 600+ defense rating. Read my post which already said this, read the link to Tankspot. I'm arguing semantics, yes, but it's an important distinction when you're thinking about how gearing and theorycrafting works.


Also, I don't buy that dodge > defense for gemming. The difference between gemming dodge and defense is quite small, and everyone seems to ignore IBF in their calculations.
The impact on IBF is a valid point, and easy to miss if you look purely at avoidance (as, I admit, I did in my last post). Looking at the math, if you assume that 1% increased reduction on IBF is just as good as 0.20% avoidance, then that's enough to make defence better across the board. That's a big leap, but it seems plausible - and if anything I'd think that would be the baseline, since it assumes that you don't have the talent, that all incoming damage is physical, and that you have no ability to time IBF to coincide with a large spike.

At the gear levels discussed earlier - 698 defence rating, 1200 strength, 300 agility, 350 dodge rating, 350 parry rating - then dodge rating is 23.02% stronger than defence rating in terms of avoidance. If you calculate the mitigation from IBF using the above assumptions and treat it as if it was avoidance, then dodge is 13.50% weaker than defence rating. (I'm using a scaling value of 0.15% reduction per point of defence skill, as found in the DK FAQ.) Playing with the model, that result is just as resilient to gear decisions as the result was when ignoring IBF. A gear set otherwise identical to the above assumptions but with 1048 defence rating and 0 dodge rating would make dodge stronger - but you couldn't possibly assemble such a set, and anything less wouldn't be enough.


All that being said, just so long as we're talking purely about avoidance, you're still quite wrong, as the math at Tankspot shows. The discussion was about current gear, dodge is better until over 1k dodge rating (which you couldn't possibly obtain), and "in an utter vacuum", defence is still worse than dodge for avoidance. It's worse with no DR (i.e., naked), and it's even worse with the DR that actually applies (i.e., while wearing your tanking gear). And a few minutes playing with Wowhead indicates that it's also worse with any possible, viable set of gear currently in game, or which is likely to ever be in game. Everything you've said is wrong; dodge is simply more avoidance. You can speculate on what would happen if Bliz added a new runeforge enchant with 800 dodge rating on it if you like, but you could speculate on what would happen if they changed the rating conversion formulas too. Neither is going to happen, and without one of those, dodge is the best choice for pure avoidance now and for the forseeable future.

However, once you include IBF scaling, it's hard to see how you can avoid the conclusion that defence wins. You'd have to assume that 1% increased damage reduction on IBF was worth only 0.11% avoidance for dodge to still win. Or to put it another way, IBF would have to be up for only 11% of all incoming damage - when just hitting the button every cooldown should average 20%, worst case. Unless I'm missing something basic, I don't see how dodge can still win.

Revised conclusion: Gem for defence instead of dodge given a choice. It's always less avoidance, but IBF more than makes up for it. (Whether you should even be trying to decide between gemming for dodge or defence in the first place is, of course, an entirely separate question.)
#991SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Chairon
Alternative DK Stat Weight Calculation
I have been cooking up a hypothesis on an alternate way of calculating the DK stat weights on how they affect DPS. My goal is to get some insight on how viable this new method would be.

Let's say one was to take all the significant stats a DK has and statistically model them on how they will affect output DPS.

1) Strength
2) Attack Power
3) Critical Hit Rating
4) Agility
5) Armor Penetration Rating
6) Haste Rating
7) Weapon DPS

Once gathered, could you use all these as predictors in a logistic regression to determine an outcome variable, namely DPS?

I propose collecting multiple sustained DPS parses, then separating each predictor into 5 different dichotomous bands (0 if the DPS predictor does not fall in the range, 1 if it does).

Once each predictor is defined by one of these bands, we could then place them in a regression to model the continuous variable, DPS.

A model summary would generate respective beta coefficients for each of the prediction variables. The relative weight for each predictor would be the individual standardized beta coefficient divided by the sum of all the beta coefficients.

Areas of concern with this method:

1) I'm not quite sure what type of regression model I should use. I initially thought I could use a binary logistic regression, but since DPS is a continuous variable, would a linear regression be better suited?

2) Data collection. The DPS parses would all have to be under the same conditions. Perhaps a target dummy?

Any feedback would be appreciated. I have been using the commonly accepted stat weights up to this point, and will continue to do so. I'm just wondering if there are alternative ways to look at the core of our DPS.

Edit: Also added weapon DPS
#992SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ foolish_fool
I am quite certain that you will find that type of modeling to be a statistical nightmare, once you begin. There are so many variables to take into account even in the setting up of such an experiment, not to mention the complex interaction between factors that do not act linearly. You could make simplifying assumptions, but that would greatly decrease the validity of what you are actually trying to achieve. You would likely end up having to write a simulator just to get sufficient consistent data: in which case you may as well just use said sim to calculate stat weights.

#994SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kashir
Originally Posted by Lazare
However, once you include IBF scaling, it's hard to see how you can avoid the conclusion that defence wins. You'd have to assume that 1% increased damage reduction on IBF was worth only 0.11% avoidance for dodge to still win. Or to put it another way, IBF would have to be up for only 11% of all incoming damage - when just hitting the button every cooldown should average 20%, worst case. Unless I'm missing something basic, I don't see how dodge can still win.
Death Knight tanking is reliant on cooldowns. The most dangerous period is when our cooldowns are down, while the safest period is when IBF is up (~35% mitigation is better than anything but Lichborne).

Taking your figures, we could still make the argument that a constant 0.11% avoidance (during both the safe and dangerous periods) is worth more than 1% mitigation during the safe period. In other words, IBF is "good enough" already; what we need is a safety-net when IBF, UA, BA, VB etc. are not active.

Dodge and defense are both excellent stats, it's very rare that you'll have to make a 1:1 decision between the two, and even if you make the "wrong" decision it's not going to matter much.
#995SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by Kashir
Death Knight tanking is reliant on cooldowns. The most dangerous period is when our cooldowns are down, while the safest period is when IBF is up (~35% mitigation is better than anything but Lichborne).

Taking your figures, we could still make the argument that a constant 0.11% avoidance (during both the safe and dangerous periods) is worth more than 1% mitigation during the safe period. In other words, IBF is "good enough" already; what we need is a safety-net when IBF, UA, BA, VB etc. are not active.

Dodge and defense are both excellent stats, it's very rare that you'll have to make a 1:1 decision between the two, and even if you make the "wrong" decision it's not going to matter much.
If you're worried about dying to a spike while off cooldowns, then avoidance isn't going to help you either. At that point you're looking at Stam being the best option.
#996SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Chairon
Originally Posted by foolish_fool
I am quite certain that you will find that type of modeling to be a statistical nightmare, once you begin. There are so many variables to take into account even in the setting up of such an experiment, not to mention the complex interaction between factors that do not act linearly. You could make simplifying assumptions, but that would greatly decrease the validity of what you are actually trying to achieve. You would likely end up having to write a simulator just to get sufficient consistent data: in which case you may as well just use said sim to calculate stat weights.
I think that I could do a linear decomposition to determine the interactions between the predictors. Are you saying that gathering accurat data would be next to impossible?

#999SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by Ritualist

I really don't see any change whatsoever when I alternate between the two. I thought I would mention that our mages are arcane so Razorice doesn't benefit us much as others.

My Armory
Beserking is NEVER an option for a Deathknight. If you don't like the performance of Cinderglaicer or Razorice, go 2x Fallen Crusader (it will probably increase the uptime by 60% or so), but never ever get a "normal" enchant. Runeforges are infinitely better.

DK Tanking Hit and Expertise Caps
Simple question ----------------------

I am getting mixed advice on tanking caps for hit and expertise. I have great DPS gear but want to start saving up for tanking spec.

Getting 540 defense is the first part to worry about Which I don't even have that with just blues. (I have Rep rewards, crafted, and some drops that have DEF) I am a blacksmith so I can add 3 gem slots for hit or dodge or whatever.

So if I try to get hit cap and expertise cap I will loose dodge or defense.

Someone said hit was not really as important, about 200 is ok which I think is bull. That's 6.10 (Aprox) hit. Then they said but get about 24-26 expertise is next priority, which I also think is bull. And yes this was with a 2H not a DW...

I have experimented with expertise and find that 8% chance to hit (I almost always have a draenei in my group) and 12ish expertise is fine when I am DPS in a 25 man. Maybe three attacks at most will get dodged in a fight, maybe 1 depending on how long the fight is.

Can I apply the same theory to tanking? I am looking to tank 5 man heroics or 10 man Naxx to start and I don't want to be squishy. Is 26 expertise more important than hit, and is the claim that 6% chance to hit is all that's needed valid in any way?

What should I be going for in tanking stats?

540 Def
??? Avoidance (Total added together from Dodge, Parry, and where ever else since DKs have no shield)
?? Hit
?? Expertise

Where can I go for more info -------------------------------

Can you point me to a thread that has updated (3.0.8) tanking advice? I have seen some threads but it is hard to find the info I want on the first page with latest changes to DKs and hard to wade through 54 pages of info.

Where should I be for these things:

1) Avoidance (Parry and Dodge) and which is easiest to raise up to start off with? Pros and cons of dodge vs parry.
2) Stats on gear. Agility gives Crit and Dodge, Str gives AP and Parry.. Which will get avoidance quickest without lowering threat. (In otherwords having high crit but low AP, or vise versa)
3) Which is better for generating max threat? AP or STR and I say that because some bonuses are calculated off the STR stat or Armor from items but don't calculate a bonus from total AP. Pros and cons of white damage and IT, PS, BS, FS...

#1002SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
It hardly matters at all. You're going to encounter almost no pieces with gear with sockets on them and what you do get you'll end up replacing in two levels. Leveling as a DK is the easiest thing you'll ever do, just grab the cheapest gem you can find and be on your way.
#1003SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Just gem bold bloodstones in everything if you do run into socketed gear, but while there's a few in BC content, in northrend there's almost no socket gear at all, even when you run instances. You'd probably have enough if you cut like 5 of them.
#1004SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3◊ foolish_fool
Originally Posted by Chairon
I think that I could do a linear decomposition to determine the interactions between the predictors. Are you saying that gathering accurat data would be next to impossible?
Yes. Mainly because test dummy performance is not going to provide accurate enough data for you to calculate stat weights that are accurate in a raid environment, and because actual raid parses will vary immensely, not only on simple things like what raid buffs are present (which you could probably account for), but also vary by things like the other dps in the raid, as well as various "RNG" factors.
#1005SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Aihime
okay, so i've read the frost and unholy dps thread but frost says 9% for hit cap and for unholy it's 8%
which one is which?
#1006SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Arthian
The required hit percentage to hit the melee hit cap is now 8%. The confusion arises because it was previously 9% but changed with the introduction of Wotlk.

The dual wield hit cap (ie, your off hand has a higher chance to miss than your mh) and the spell hit cap are higher.
#1007SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Arthian
The required hit percentage to hit the melee hit cap is now 8%. The confusion arises because it was previously 9% but changed with the introduction of Wotlk.

The dual wield hit cap (ie, your off hand has a higher chance to miss than your mh) and the spell hit cap are higher.
While DW'ing, your offhand and your main-hand have the exact same percent chance to hit. The difference arises with special attacks, which have a hitcap of 8% and almost always use the main-hand weapon (one notable exception is BCB, which uses the offhand weapon).

#1021SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kashir
Originally Posted by Darkside

#1022SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Aellex
Huh, hope this hasn't been asked before in some other thread, but here we go.

Melee classes DPS from behind to avoid getting parried and etc etc, but is there some other benefit from doing this? I've had different people tell me no, and other people tell me there's an increased chance to crit from being behind a mob. Is it true? If so, does it apply to Death Knights?
#1023SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3zeheres
The main idea in attacking from behind is exactly what you just wrote there (to avoid being parried etc).

Originally Posted by Aellex
[..]I've had different people tell me no, and other people tell me there's an increased chance to crit from being behind a mob. Is it true?[..]
From my understanding one is capable to crit more from attacking behind inevitably for being parried less. Correct me if I'm wrong.

#1024SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Kashir
With Shadron + twilight torment, even the non-enraged elementals start to hit pretty hard. Good to know that Acclimation isn't completely wasted, thanks.
While Blaze damage is resistable, I'm about 95% sure their attacks don't proc acclimatation, like most elementals melee attacks. Only actual spells/abilities proc it, so if you're "lucky" and get hit by a Fire Cyclone, it might proc and help a bit, but it won't proc off tanking the blazes. Making it a very poor choice of talent, obviously.


Originally Posted by Aellex
Huh, hope this hasn't been asked before in some other thread, but here we go.

Melee classes DPS from behind to avoid getting parried and etc etc, but is there some other benefit from doing this? I've had different people tell me no, and other people tell me there's an increased chance to crit from being behind a mob. Is it true? If so, does it apply to Death Knights?
First don't start a post by "not sure this hasn't been asked before". There's a search feature, use it. With that said, I doubt anyone asked that before, because it's totally false. The only benefit of attacking from behind, besides obvious positionning requirements on stuff like backstab, is removing parry off bosses(and dodges off players). It is however a huge benefit, as boss parry rate is around 15%, meaning you do 15% less dmg from the front. There's also parry haste issues, so melee dps should always attack from behind. There's also no good reason to attack from the front unless you're extremely lazy.
#1025SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Aellex

While Blaze damage is resistable, I'm about 95% sure their attacks don't proc acclimatation, like most elementals melee attacks. Only actual spells/abilities proc it, so if you're "lucky" and get hit by a Fire Cyclone, it might proc and help a bit, but it won't proc off tanking the blazes. Making it a very poor choice of talent, obviously.




First don't start a post by "not sure this hasn't been asked before". There's a search feature, use it. With that said, I doubt anyone asked that before, because it's totally false. The only benefit of attacking from behind, besides obvious positionning requirements on stuff like backstab, is removing parry off bosses(and dodges off players). It is however a huge benefit, as boss parry rate is around 15%, meaning you do 15% less dmg from the front. There's also parry haste issues, so melee dps should always attack from behind. There's also no good reason to attack from the front unless you're extremely lazy.
The point of me saying that was that I did use the search function and couldn't find anything. Just a bit of politeness, and such. I was told that it was so old it was "assumed", so wasn't sure if it'd just been pushed off or blah.

#1026SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by zeheres
From my understanding one is capable to crit more from attacking behind inevitably for being parried less. Correct me if I'm wrong.
This is not true; attacking a mob from behind will lower your chance to be parried, which in turn will only increase your chance to hit. Your crit chance will remain unchanged. Read more about this and melee hit tables here: Melee Combat Mechanics
#1027SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dirich

#1030SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Endus
Originally Posted by Aellex
Huh, hope this hasn't been asked before in some other thread, but here we go.

Melee classes DPS from behind to avoid getting parried and etc etc, but is there some other benefit from doing this? I've had different people tell me no, and other people tell me there's an increased chance to crit from being behind a mob. Is it true? If so, does it apply to Death Knights?
1> Mob can't parry
2> Many attack types only affect what's in front of the enemy. Cleaves, breaths, etc. This is why even if you can hit the expertise hard cap and thus never have to worry about the boss parrying or dodging, you still want to be behind the boss.
#1031SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pyros
Originally Posted by Endus
1> Mob can't parry
2> Many attack types only affect what's in front of the enemy. Cleaves, breaths, etc. This is why even if you can hit the expertise hard cap and thus never have to worry about the boss parrying or dodging, you still want to be behind the boss.
Mobs can parry. The expertise hardcap is stupidly high, no one will conceive getting it. It takes like 490expertise rating to be hardcapped. That's why you attack from the back. The cleaves/breaths are obviously a bonus, but they only happen on certain mobs anyway, you still want to be behind every mob, even if they have no abilities.

Edit: Actually only bosses have such a high parry, on mobs you could probably hardcap expertise. If that's what you meant, then yeah. There's still no reason to stand in front of mobs when you can get behind.

#1047SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurokaze
Kelthuryon: Dual wield simply deals more white damage than 2H by a significant margin.

With 4000 raid buffed AP, no talents, no hit/crit, and ilvl213ish weapons:

2H deals 200 damage per second plus attack power contribution. Attack power contribution is AP/14 or 285.7dps. Damage contribution is 92% due to missrate. Total dps is (200+285.7)*.92 or 446.8dps.

Mainhand DW deals 150 damage per second plus attack power contribution. Attack power contribution is AP/14 or 285.7dps. Damage contribution is 73% due to missrate. Total dps is (150+285.7)*.73 or 318.1dps.

Offhand DW deals 150 damage per second plus attack power contribution. Attack power contribution is AP/14 or 285.7dps. Damage contribution is 36.5% due to missrate and offhand penalty. Total dps is (150+285.7)*.365 or 159dps.

Total DW DPS: 477.1
DPS delta: 30.3

Most hybrid builds can take Nerves of Cold Steel but not 2H specialization. NoCS adds roughly 16% damage contribution (3% mainhand, 14% offhand) or 69.7dps.

Total DPS delta: 100.0

Necrosis multiplies white damage by roughly 120% (actually more due to double-dipping from percentage damage buffs). Adding 35% crit multiplies by 135% (actually more due to the way hit tables work).

Total DPS delta: 162.0

The effects of BCB and hit gear are beyond the scope of this napkin, however suffice it to say that BCB has been continually proven to work better the faster your weapon is, and hit gear obviously works better when you can benefit from more than 8%.
#1048SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
It should be noted that Necrosis scales from Impurity, so it will actually add 25% extra damage before any extra debuffs.
#1049SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Orlgin
That is incorrect. While necrosis deals spell damage, it is an ability and not a spell. This means it gets it's damage boosted by Ebon Plaguebringer but not impurity. All effects that raise damage dealt by abilities such as Rage of Rivendare, Blood Presence, Bone Shield, Desecration, Tundra Stalker, and Blood Gorged raise it's damage.

Effects that raise all damage cause double dipping. It raises the damage of the hit and Necrosis uses that as a base damage, then it gets multiplied again by the modifier.
#1050SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kelthuryon
Originally Posted by kurokaze

A > B means that A can deliver more (or same as) tps than B even if A's gear is worst than B.
Last edited by Dirich : 02/11/09 at 2:36 PM.
#1053SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3EwokChilli
Searix, assuming hit&expertise cap, the 3.6 speed weapon > 3.4 speed weapon. Hence why Jawbone > Inevitable Defeat. Gladiator weapons don't have as much dps stats on them as normal pve weapons though, so probably would end up being a wash.

The trinket's unholy damage appears to be affected by some of the Unholy talents as I've seen a 2.7k crit without Cinderglacier up. What research I have done on the subject has had contradictory information: some think it has a % chance and no ICD but doesn't trigger on DoTs (15%). Some think it has a 45 second cooldown.

If someone has better information and has done more extensive testing, could you share the result?

#1062SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by EwokChilli
FC i believe is 1 PPM, but it can proc off of strikes and is affected by haste. So it has I believe 35-40% uptime based on spec. Has no ICD. With a 3.4 speed weapon, i think it came out to about ~7% chance to proc on each attack/strike.
It is not uncommon for DW specs with FC/FC to see uptimes > 60% on certain fights (Patchwerk, Loatheb etc).
#1063SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Cabal
Originally Posted by Darkside
It is not uncommon for DW specs with FC/FC to see uptimes > 60% on certain fights (Patchwerk, Loatheb etc).
Also from my own experience there is something weird going on, uptime on FC buff (unholy strenght) when using it on both weapons, can go from 43%

WoW Meter Online - The Best World of Warcraft Combat Log Analyse System!Fully support Wrath of the Lich King!

To 75%

WoW Meter Online - The Best World of Warcraft Combat Log Analyse System!Fully support Wrath of the Lich King!

This seems like too big of a uptime difference to me? Apart from a possible bug in WMO, shouldnt the range be much smaller?

#1065SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3MatthewDB
Ok after searching I was unable to find out if Icy Talons stacks with another DKs improved Icy Talon buff? Also is vendetta nearly useless at 80 since nothing gives experience anymore? Or does it count if the mob could give experience?
#1066SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by MatthewDB
Ok after searching I was unable to find out if Icy Talons stacks with another DKs improved Icy Talon buff? Also is vendetta nearly useless at 80 since nothing gives experience anymore? Or does it count if the mob could give experience?
Icy Talons will not stack with itself. Vendetta works at 80, however, it is a largely useless talent as you shouldn't really be taking damage while questing and you'll rarely land the killing blow in a raid setting.
#1067SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3MatthewDB
Originally Posted by Darkside
Icy Talons will not stack with itself. Vendetta works at 80, however, it is a largely useless talent as you shouldn't really be taking damage while questing and you'll rarely land the killing blow in a raid setting.
Will it stack with a shaman's windfury?

edit: thanks for the fast response I was considering vendetta only for heroic dungeon's purpose - (hiss, hiss I know.)
#1068SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Begotten
Originally Posted by MatthewDB
Will it stack with a shaman's windfury?
No, it does not stack

#1077SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Athielle
I am sorry if this is a dumb question but I have been reading a lot on DK Tanking and often times total avoidance is referenced. I have tried to locate how to calculate total avoidance yet I have been unable to find this. Is this just adding together both parry% and dodge%? I am trying to decide if I UH would be better for me to spec into rather than the frost spec I have currently.

Thanks!
#1078SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by Athielle
I am sorry if this is a dumb question but I have been reading a lot on DK Tanking and often times total avoidance is referenced. I have tried to locate how to calculate total avoidance yet I have been unable to find this. Is this just adding together both parry% and dodge%? I am trying to decide if I UH would be better for me to spec into rather than the frost spec I have currently.

Thanks!
Dodge + Parry + Miss + Base Miss + Blade Barrier =

For me I have... 26 + 19 + 5.6 + 5 + 10 = 65.6% ...I'm almost certain the base miss is 5% but if it isn't then obviously use the correct number.

I've met people who refuse to count miss as avoidance, I personally think it should be counted.
#1079SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Athielle
Thanks! I appreciate the answer.

I know where to find the values for Dodge, Parry, and Blade Barrier. How do I calculate base miss or miss chance?
#1080SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Griefknight
Originally Posted by Athielle
Thanks! I appreciate the answer.

I know where to find the values for Dodge, Parry, and Blade Barrier. How do I calculate base miss or miss chance?
The base miss is 5%(?) and the miss chance is from defense, mouse over defense and you can see it will say "Reduces the chance the enemy will hit you 5.6% or land a critical blow by 5.6%" that isn't the exact wording but you get my point.
#1081SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Athielle
Alright, Thanks again!

With your info I was able to determine my base avoidance is 41.7% w/o Horn of Winter and 44.15% with HoW
#1082SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3brahmabull754
Wandering Plague for Tanking
Is it really worth it, being that my chance to crit in tank gear is about 6% (would be 9% with Ebon Plaguebringer)? My DK is my alt and I want to use him to tank heroics and 10-mans for my guild's other alts. I'm used to deep unholy for dps/farming so I'd like to stick with it for tanking.
#1083SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by brahmabull754
Is it really worth it, being that my chance to crit in tank gear is about 6% (would be 9% with Ebon Plaguebringer)? My DK is my alt and I want to use him to tank heroics and 10-mans for my guild's other alts. I'm used to deep unholy for dps/farming so I'd like to stick with it for tanking.
FYI: Wandering plague uses your melee crit chance, not spell. It is an amazing skill for AoE tanking (Adds on Sarth and the like) since it pretty much procs once every could seconds, giving you all the threat you could ever want.

#1086SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Darkmoone
Quoted from the Unholy dps thread:

Originally Posted by Zurm
Strength/AP before any other stat. Your current trinkets are way better, and the current thinking is that it's better to just stack strength over hit/exp... with a rotation as open as the 2H unholy one, you have plenty of time to retry strikes if you miss.

I'm confused now, so as Unholy DPS we stack Str/AP in all our gems slots/enchants and forgo hit/exp?
#1087SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dirich
Why do you want to stack AP? Str gems give you the same raw ap, but they benefict from bok and various talents in blood and unholy trees, which ap doesn't.
Also in the TTT, in the DK DPS thread, there is the comparison between stats. For unholy, and unholy only, str is even better than pre capped hit. Expertise is the third stronger stat, if I remember correctly, but since gem wise exp and str are both red, there's no way you are going to gem for exp, since every red is going to be str (orange = str + hit, if you need hit and want the socket bonus, of course, etc. ).
#1088SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Darkmoone
So does that mean slot str in every slot regardless of hit and exp?
#1089SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by Darkmoone
So does that mean slot str in every slot regardless of hit and exp?
Get hit/exp capped first, then stack strength out your ears. Getting hit capped should be easy with the currently available gear, and expertise capping shouldn't be much harder, especially if you picked orc/human/dwarf.
#1090SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raskar
Hey guys,

I'm looking at replacing my [Greatsword of the Ebon Blade] with two [Footman's Longsword]. I'm specced for deep Frost, sort of an AOE burst DPS/tank build. It's not the greatest number-crunch wise, I'll admit, but it's been very good to me for leveling so far.

Really, though, with all I read about how critically important Strength is for Death Knights, how does Attack Power fair? I've been searching FAQ threads and such and haven't seen too much on it (unless I missed in, in which case, please provide me with a link so I can read it). Is AP useless for DKs, or does it hold its own with Strength to a point?

Thanks,
Raskar
#1091SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pindle
Originally Posted by Raskar
Hey guys,

I'm looking at replacing my [Greatsword of the Ebon Blade] with two [Footman's Longsword]. I'm specced for deep Frost, sort of an AOE burst DPS/tank build. It's not the greatest number-crunch wise, I'll admit, but it's been very good to me for leveling so far.

Really, though, with all I read about how critically important Strength is for Death Knights, how does Attack Power fair? I've been searching FAQ threads and such and haven't seen too much on it (unless I missed in, in which case, please provide me with a link so I can read it). Is AP useless for DKs, or does it hold its own with Strength to a point?

Thanks,
Raskar
Str scaled with buffs and talents (which can end up to a nice bonus) which is why it's preferred over AP. Only replace str gear with the rogue-ish type items (agi/stam/AP/etc) if the item quality is far superior.
#1092SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
Originally Posted by Raskar
Hey guys,

I'm looking at replacing my [Greatsword of the Ebon Blade] with two [Footman's Longsword]. I'm specced for deep Frost, sort of an AOE burst DPS/tank build. It's not the greatest number-crunch wise, I'll admit, but it's been very good to me for leveling so far.

Really, though, with all I read about how critically important Strength is for Death Knights, how does Attack Power fair? I've been searching FAQ threads and such and haven't seen too much on it (unless I missed in, in which case, please provide me with a link so I can read it). Is AP useless for DKs, or does it hold its own with Strength to a point?

Thanks,
Raskar
It's not useless, but strength convert to AP at about a 1 Str = 2.5 AP ratio (assuming BoK and FC), so you do the math.
#1093SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raskar
Originally Posted by Darkside
It's not useless, but strength convert to AP at about a 1 Str = 2.5 AP ratio (assuming BoK and FC), so you do the math.
Ah, that's a good conversion rate to have handy, thanks.

I'm searching wowhead with filters for any 1h axe/sword/mace that is green, blue, or purple between L58 to 65, MH, 1H, or OH, and I'm seeing scant/few viable results. [Edit: Another filter I added was Stam >1 + Str >1]

For DKs who DW, what do you find your initial replacements for [Greatsword of the Ebon Blade] or [Greataxe of the Ebon Blade] are?
#1094SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3frater
Just wanting a little feedback from you experienced DK Tanks out there.

I leveled up my DK alt, my main is a Prot Warrior, and i have started to tank some heroics and it has gone well so far.

I specced Unholy tanking as i felt AoE skills would be a nice change from my warrior. plus i hear the Unholy tank has a little more versatility DPS-wise so i figured i'd start there.

My Question:
So i think i have been doing pretty good with my rotations for threat, etc. but I have a little nagging doubt that i think comes from the fact that my history is in rage-based tanking.

~ I read the rotations that are suggested: IT-PS-BS-BS-SS SS-SS-SS
~ I do my best to follow those but towards the second half I find that i am not able to immediately use the SS every GCD. I am used to warrior tanking where every single GCD you hit oen of several options.

So my questions is, am I missing something? or are there actually times where DK tanks are waiting for runes to use the next ability in their rotation?

my DK armory is here
Armory - Dastardly
#1095SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Raskar
I'm searching wowhead with filters for any 1h axe/sword/mace that is green, blue, or purple between L58 to 65, MH, 1H, or OH, and I'm seeing scant/few viable results. [Edit: Another filter I added was Stam >1 + Str >1]
Since you are leveling, you want to use a 2H weapon because fights are short and the sustained damage of DW doesn't shine when stuff dies so fast when leveling. Plus Unholy has run speed + mount speed passive (if talented).

If you have some badges, I guess you could get a [Venerable Dal'Rend's Sacred Charge] (MH only).
#1096SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dirich
Originally Posted by Darkside
Get hit/exp capped first, then stack strength out your ears. Getting hit capped should be easy with the currently available gear, and expertise capping shouldn't be much harder, especially if you picked orc/human/dwarf.
Why do you tell him to do so? Str is better increase in dps than pre cap hit rating and expertise rating according to the TTT thread.
The only thing in addition to the dps value that comes to mind is exactly this aspect, but being the rotation on single target "SS spam" (a part from when the glyph fail so much that you need to reapply manually your diseases), you get no additional penalty from a miss/dodge/parry than the normal dps loss for the skill non landed.
There are a couple of things that I can think about why chosing hit nevertheless, but I totally can't find a reason for an unholy dps to chose exp over str.
Can you explain why you suggest hit/expertise before strength, please?
#1097SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Afabar
Originally Posted by frater
So my questions is, am I missing something? or are there actually times where DK tanks are waiting for runes to use the next ability in their rotation?
You made the point.
The second part of the rotation ( the 3 SS) unload all your runes in 3 GCD and have to wait 5.5 second until the first set of runes refresh. If you are using Rune Strike during your tanking rotation, you probably don't even have RP for Death Coil.
#1098SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3JALbert
Originally Posted by gox
What spec/tree gives an higher than expected dps for low end gear builds?

Example: As a warlock that starts to raid you would advise someone to go 0/41/30 because the talents make up for bad gear, allowing you to do better dps for your gear, than you would with the true "powerhouse" builds like 55/0/18 or 0/20/51.

Is there something similar with DK and dps.
For example: I see the "disease-less" blood dps spec, and people saying you need very good gear for it, is there something exactly opposite. Aka where you can do decent dps with bad gear, until you get better gear?
( I don't mean 6k dps, I mean just not 1500 dps)
If you're a good player, you'll do fine DPS in blues with any spec. If you're Blood, you'll probably want to stick to a diseased rotation until you're geared enough for diseaseless. Other than that, worrying about switching specs as your gear changes is honestly just going to hinder you in my opinion. Pick a spec that's fun (feel free to experiment between them) and learn how to play it well, and learn how to gear that spec. I put out 3300 DPS on 5 minute 10 man Patch with 2 epics and blue tanking swords. Play what you know, and play it well. There's no good DPS spec that's going to magically put out terribad numbers if you're at low gear levels and you know what you're doing.
#1099SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Bonz540
Originally Posted by Dirich
Why do you tell him to do so? Str is better increase in dps than pre cap hit rating and expertise rating according to the TTT thread.
The only thing in addition to the dps value that comes to mind is exactly this aspect, but being the rotation on single target "SS spam" (a part from when the glyph fail so much that you need to reapply manually your diseases), you get no additional penalty from a miss/dodge/parry than the normal dps loss for the skill non landed.
There are a couple of things that I can think about why chosing hit nevertheless, but I totally can't find a reason for an unholy dps to chose exp over str.
Can you explain why you suggest hit/expertise before strength, please?
Capping hit first and foremost is pretty universally accepted on these forums, despite the fact that on paper Str > all. Most prefer just to know that their attacks will land, even with a loose unholy rotation where a miss won't kill you.

After that, it's purely a player choice to cap expertise or just stack strength. Some prefer to get expertise capped, others prefer to gather the expertise as it comes on gear and not worry about gemming for it.
Last edited by Bonz540 : 02/18/09 at 3:28 PM.
#1100SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sevyvia
Originally Posted by Bonz540
Capping hit first and foremost is pretty universally accepted on these forums, despite the fact that on paper Str > all. Most prefer just to know that their attacks will land, even with a loose unholy rotation where a miss won't kill you.

After that, it's purely a player choice to cap expertise or just stack strength. Some prefer to get expertise capped, others prefer to gather the expertise as it comes on gear and not worry about gemming for it.
Well first of all, I'm sorry if I'm out of line, I don't post here often.



When it's in the TTT that Strength is better than Hit even when uncapped, it is not universally accepted, is it? There is an exception to the "rule". I don't see how you can say that it's a "rule" to cap hit when you, in the same sentence even, say that Str is better than everything?

What you're really dealing with here is that you personally like having your hitcap, which is fine, but it doesn't have anything to do with what's best in this case from what I can see. Recommending to cap Hit when Strength is better isn't really that nice.
#1101SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ foolish_fool
Mathematically, Strength is a better stat. Hit and Expertise are "nicer" stats, in that they make your rotation much more predictable/etc., meaning you can pay a little less attention to your rotation and a little more attention to staying out of the fire.
#1102SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Stoical
Originally Posted by foolish_fool
Mathematically, Strength is a better stat. Hit and Expertise are "nicer" stats, in that they make your rotation much more predictable/etc., meaning you can pay a little less attention to your rotation and a little more attention to staying out of the fire.
Personally, I'll always go with what's better and also pay attention to the fire. This is especially true now that missed strikes from death runes don't repop as non-death runes anymore, before that change I was much more inclined to cap hit/exp first.

However, there are plenty of strong DKs (Zurm comes to mind) who prefer knowing their attacks are going to land when they want them to land. It's a valid personal preference, but to say it's universal is a pretty huge overstatement.
#1103SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Timbalt
I remember reading that most PvP DKs put a small amount of Spell Penetration on their PvP gear.

Is this right?

If so, what is the magic number to gem for?
#1104SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Timbalt
I remember reading that most PvP DKs put a small amount of Spell Penetration on their PvP gear.

Is this right?

If so, what is the magic number to gem for?
Its a good idea to use some spell pen. Your spells can be resisted like Mind Freeze and Strangulate, etc. and you can get partial resists of Scourge strike and diseases.

Some Classes that can have spell resistances, Priests (just Shadow), Paladins (can be 130 shadow or frost), Druid (75 to all), Frost DKs (80 to all plus can get a stacking resistance), in addition there is a 20 SR cloak enchant.
#1105SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Timbalt
Originally Posted by frmorrison
Its a good idea to use some spell pen. Your spells can be resisted like Mind Freeze and Strangulate, etc. and you can get partial resists of Scourge strike and diseases.

Some Classes that can have spell resistances, Priests (just Shadow), Paladins (can be 130 shadow or frost), Druid (75 to all), Frost DKs (80 to all plus can get a stacking resistance), in addition there is a 20 SR cloak enchant.
So I should aim for 130? Or is that gimping myself too much?
#1106SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3♦ Darkside
My understanding of the situation is that the spell pen. enchant to cloak (Enchant Cloak - Spell Piercing - Spell - World of Warcraft) is generally all you need.
#1107SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dirich
Originally Posted by foolish_fool
Mathematically, Strength is a better stat. Hit and Expertise are "nicer" stats, in that they make your rotation much more predictable/etc., meaning you can pay a little less attention to your rotation and a little more attention to staying out of the fire.
Except for the fact this started with a post me and darkside answered, and the post was talking about Unholy DPS. And unholy dps for single target has a rotation which is for most of the time just a SS spam. So misses/dodges/parries really means nothing for the rotation. You can't screw it. The only case when such rotation is a bit sensible to such events is when you need to reapply diseases manually.

That's why I asked for darkside to explain me his reasons, since all I could imagine for him to give his answer was to rise the aoe dps on trahses too (I'm under the assumption the values in TTT refear to single target dps only and aren't correct for aoe too). But unholy aoe dps is just throught spells, so only hit is needed (and much more than the melee normal anyway).
So I ended up with partial explaination for hit and no reason at all for expertise.

#1109SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Bonz540
Originally Posted by Stoical
Personally, I'll always go with what's better and also pay attention to the fire. This is especially true now that missed strikes from death runes don't repop as non-death runes anymore, before that change I was much more inclined to cap hit/exp first.

However, there are plenty of strong DKs (Zurm comes to mind) who prefer knowing their attacks are going to land when they want them to land. It's a valid personal preference, but to say it's universal is a pretty huge overstatement.
Perhaps "pretty universally accepted" was a poor choice of wording...despite the fact that I worded it that way to account for those who simply choose Str over everything else. My main point was that I'd wager most do indeed prefer to know their attacks will land, especially since there's only 1 Patchwerk.

#1110SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Tanuke

It is not a meant to be a substitute for self help and a basic level of effort on your part. There are numerous threads, such as here and here in this very forum that deal with DK tank gearing. #1112SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Dirich
Tanking aoe as blood probably implies a lot of target swapping (so that HS hits 2 different targets everytime) since you have only 1 really strong aoe ability (d&d).
I always tanked as frost at 80. While I was Unholy while levelling. I can tell the second one is way easier to handle, but the first one is more fun, for me at least (plus it used to require more skill when there was still a cd on pestilence).
Anyway, I suggest frost, since everywhere everything is only aoe, aoe, aoe.
This is true in heroics and in raids, as of now.
For a frost spec I highly suggest the one I'm currently using (I am not going to respec, so you can be sure what you see is what I suggest you). You sacrifice 2% dodge but you increase your dps/tps AND get a nice +6% stam which you can combine with garg on weapon for a neat increase of stam, which is kind of all the pugs want from a tank (so you can find group to gear up more easyly).

Point is that epidemic is nice only for aoe, where you can throw in 1 more blood boil instead of needing to pestilence.
For single target rotation you are going to reapply your disease (notice the lack of the final "s") at every rotation.
Plus if you are frost all you need to cast is HB in order to get nice aoe dps, morbidity isn't needed.

AoE rotation is pretty standard: "pre d&d" IT PS Pestilence, than HB BB etc

Single target works best with 1 disease rotation. But you need 1 death rune in the opening, so you may need to use your Blood Tap if you haven't one from the last fight.
IT OB OB BS "Rime + Rune dump"
Rince and repeat.
Depending on your gear you may have better results with HB, but due to the limited amount of hit we have (we cap for the 8% melee miss), it's easy that the chance to miss of spells (HB) and the +9% crit chance for OB make s it so it's better, dps/tps wise, to use OB on bosses.

I use HB in place of the first OB on everything but bosses since that's what works for my gear. At the beginning probably you should use OB in every circumstance.

EDIT:
Glyph wise I use Obliterate, Rune Strike and Icy Touch. The latter being a must.
That's kind of an aggressive setup, but as of now I can sacrifice Glyph of UA without a problem.
Glyph of IF + UA + IT was what I used, but you'll find out glyph of IF isn't really vital (you just need to be careful with your rp usage). UA is nice. I swapped it out since I couldn't decide what was better between RS and OB glyphs, and eventually I found I'm ok with my current glyph configuration.


P.S.
Since tps isn't going to be a problem, you can go for Rune tap + imp rune tap + glyph of rune tap if you don't trust the average pug healer, at the Dark Conviction (aka crit), but tps has never been a problem for me untill now so you'll manage. The only ones that beat me tps wise are pally tanks.
Last edited by Dirich : 02/19/09 at 12:36 PM.
#1113SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		adolchristin
My death knight has been leveling as unholy and I'm getting close to 80. Over in the unholy DPS thread I notice the cookie cutter doesn't include outbreak and desecration in the talent build and the glyphs are ghoul; icy touch and scourge strike. Is there an increase to be had by dropping blood-caked blade and dirge and taking Outbreak and Desecration?

My reasoning is that with the PS glyph and the talent we can get a large boost to PS damage and since descration is a snare we'd get another 20% on BS. That seems like a lot to me; but cookie cutters are usually cookie cutters for a reason!
Last edited by adolchristin : 02/19/09 at 4:13 PM.
#1114SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3keltzed
Originally Posted by adolchristin
My death knight has been leveling as unholy and I'm getting close to 80. Over in the unholy DPS thread I notice the cookie cutter doesn't include outbreak and desecration in the talent build and the glyphs are ghoul; icy touch and scourge strike. Is there an increase to be had by dropping blood-caked blade and picking up and dirge and taking Pestilence and Desecration?

My reasoning is that with the PS glyph and the talent we can get a large boost to PS damage and since descration is a snare we'd get another 20% on BS. That seems like a lot to me; but cookie cutters are usually cookie cutters for a reason!
By Pestilence, do you mean the Outbreak talent?

The 2h unholy DPS builds I've seen don't take plague strike-based talents because the combination of extended durations on diseases and the scourge strike glyph causes you to not use plague strike very often. A typical 2h unholy rotation will go something like PS->IT->BS->BS->SS in the first 10 seconds, followed by three straight scourge strikes in the second 10, giving you four chances for the scourge strike glyph to refresh your disease rotation, in which case you carry on using scourge strike instead of plague strike and icy touch. Four 25% chances = just under 70% chance that one of them will happen, so it's very easy to go 30 seconds between uses of plague strike. Given all that, it's not worth putting talent points into boosting plague strike or talents that fire when you use plague strike.

A fair number of the dual wield specs out there do include Outbreak and/or Desecration, because they don't use scourge strike in their rotations, and therefore are plague striking enough for the talents to be worthwhile.
#1115SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3adolchristin
Originally Posted by keltzed
By Pestilence, do you mean the Outbreak talent?
Woops; yes indeed. I think I could have been more clear; I am wondering if taking Outbreak and Desecration and the PS and BS glyphs would be a DPS increase over the SS strike glyph. Glyphs would be PS, BS and Ghoul.

PS Would get 45% from Outbreak and 20% from the glyph if you IT first in your rotation and BS would get 20% from the glyph since desecration works as a snare. Are all of these dps gains beaten by another Scourge Strike if you get a SS glyph proc?
#1116SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by adolchristin
Are all of these dps gains beaten by another Scourge Strike if you get a SS glyph proc?
Yes, until PS is changed to do more weapon damage, SS glyph will be the highest dps gain for sustained dps. I would assume for soloing PS glyph may be better, but soloing is not the reason for these boards.
#1117SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Englisch

#1118SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Stoical

#1119SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3adolchristin
Another quick question; which is worth more personal dps 2/2 Dirge or 2/2 Unholy Aura. I know Unholy Aura is invaluable to a raid but how much personal DPS can we estimate it's worth?
#1120SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Stoical
Originally Posted by adolchristin
Another quick question; which is worth more personal dps 2/2 Dirge or 2/2 Unholy Aura. I know Unholy Aura is invaluable to a raid but how much personal DPS can we estimate it's worth?
Any decent PvE spec will pick up both Unholy Aura and Dirge if you're that deep in the tree. PvP specs often favor Unholy Aura.

We can't estimate how much personal DPS it's worth because it varies heavily depending on the fight and how much running you have to do. For example, on Patchwerk it's worth almost 0, but on Sarth it's worth a lot more. Even on the latter it will still vary based on your guild's strat and how unlucky you get on void zones and lava waves.

The only specific math I recall seeing on run speed is from the enhancement shaman TTT, and that came to the conclusion that run speed boot enchants were better than straight-dps boot enchants if you spent roughly 4 seconds moving between adds, running to the boss, etc., in a 5 minute fight, which is often enough that you should always go for run speed. Given that most fights that matter require and will probably continue to require a lot of movement for both survival and to get back on dps, that suggests that if you had to choose between the two, Unholy Aura will generally provide more benefit.
#1121SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ghwrin
It's probably been posted, but there's A LOT of information to sift though.

How exactly is Killing Machine currently working? I know it's based off of PPM, but is DWing affecting it, is weapon speed, is haste? I'd appreciate it if someone who actually knew for a fact and not someone who "thinks" they "might" know how it works responded. Thanks in advance.
#1122SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3teiglin
KM is 5 PPM (one per talent point) on mainhand white swings only. What that means is with no haste but hit/expertise capped, it will proc five times per minute on average. Base weapon speed does not affect the expected number of procs. Offhand swings do not have a chance to proc KM. Haste will increase the number of procs you get.
