#1846SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by coldbear
Feral dps (mostly) druid here finding myself constantly having extreme threat issues with DK tanks in my guild. My threat dump (Cower) is not a very good option for hard mode dps races, and holding back dps early and mid-fight is an issue on the hard modes we're starting to knock down. The warrior tanks are either better geared or give me Vigilance.

How can I help my DK tanks maximize their early-fight threat? The 2-3 DK tanks have somewhat widely ranging skill and gear levels. Depending on spec, what would the absolutely maximum early-fight (say, first 5-7 GCD's for the tank) threat generation look like for a Frost/Unholy/Blood tank, assuming MD and TotT are not available?

Again, holding back early dps in the first 30sec is a bad solution in a few hard mode fights, though certainly the answer to some of my problems (I myself am not terribly skilled, but have learned enough to capitalize on the current OP feral dps).

Also, thanks Frmorrison for the info on Hysteria/Blood damage. Helped solve a bit of drama.
While your best bet is definitely to check out http://elitistjerks.com/f72/t44638-s...nking_updated/ and DK Tanking Discussion for death knight tanking information I can help summarize a little bit.

First off, if you are doing HMs you need to be Blood or Frost, unholy is out of the question for fights which are threat sensitive. Frost and Blood both share superior raw Mitigation (Frost > Blood), Effective Health (Blood > Frost), and definitely on TPS, effectively making Unholy the worst choice in almost all cases. Frost may have higher base mitigation; however Blood has, by far, a larger benefit on Effective Health. For hard modes Effective Health means more breathing room for healers, and the large benefit Blood provides over Frost in this regards pushes Blood above Frost overall.

If Misdirect and Tricks of the Trade are not up for the tank then you, as a dps, need to understand that a DK needs his diseases up and to have about 5-10 seconds to finish the first half of his rotation before you should be able to go all out (similar to how mages need a few seconds to setup scorches to improve their primary nuke, etc.).

Threat rotations are pretty much identical to dps rotations, with the exception of runic power dump phases. The threat rotations are as follows...

As Blood you maintain a rather static rotation. Since all of Bloods cool downs use Blood Runes and you generally have 2 Bloods and 4 death Runes up most of the fight you can throw in the cool down pretty much anywhere, which is where I feel Blood really shines above Frost. When I say 'dump phase' that means use death coil, however, unlike dps, as a tank you *only* use death coil if you are high on runic power (over 60 is generally where I will use one), this is important because our two non-Rune cool downs are Icebound Fortitude and Anti Magic Shell, which both require 20 RP to use, this is also important because Rune Strike (another Runic Power ability) is by far our greatest TPS tool.

IT > PS > DS > HS > HS > Dump Phase
DS > HS > HS > HS > HS > Dump Phase

As Frost your rotation is much more of a priority system over a static rotation. The priority system is as follows... Keep Frost Fever (IT Debuff) up at all times, use Frost Strike on Killing Machine procs and when you will be Runic Power capped if you use a Rune ability, use Howling Blast on Rime procs, make Blood Runes into Death Runes with Blood Strike and use Obliterate whenever the disease is up and you have a Frost Rune and Unholy Rune pair or Frost Rune and Death Rune, or Death Rune / Death Rune (unless your disease is about to expire). Personally I use Howling Blast glyph, which means my rotation is greatly simplified as Howling Blast applies the Frost Fever debuff, making Icy Touch unnecessary. If they decide to use HB glyph they should consider the following rotation, with similar priorities to the above...

HB > BS > BS OB > Dump Phase
OB > OB > OB > Dump Phase

The main priority here is that you use Howling B in place of Obliterate whenever Frost Fever is about to go off. Another reminder here is that Rime procs reset the cool down on Howling Blast and make the next Howling Blast consume no runes. In the frost DPS topic there is a better explained idea as to how to use Howling Blast effectively in this rotation.

Another big threat boost relies on talents. The common specs used are present in both of the threads I linked above (since we are talking HMs, treat Suno's as a better guide than the standard tanking thread, considering it is high end oriented).

The next biggest one, and the one I find most common with death knights, is that they are manually triggering Rune Strike rather than macro'ing it to commonly used abilities. All spells your tank uses commonly should be replaced by a macro like this...

#showtooltip <Spell Name>
/cast !Rune Strike
/cast <Spell Name>

As an example to clear any confusion, it should be like this for Heart Strike...

#showtooltip Heart Strike
/cast !Rune Strike
/cast Heart Strike

The "!" before Rune Strike means that if the ability has been triggered (as Rune Strike is an 'on next melee swing' type attack, just like Heroic Strike / Bash) it won't deactivated by rapidly pressing buttons (where /cast Rune Strike will activate and deactivate the ability and reactivate it again based on button presses).

I hope this helps you a little bit with getting your DK tanks on the right track, and be sure to check out the two threads I linked above for further assistance, they are full of great information.

#1849SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3lewo
Last night at Ulduar, I've got a new weapon for my Dk but I'm not sure if it's better than my current weapon. I've checked at the forum, can't find much about weapon speed, as far as I know slower weapons are better for blood dk's as the abilities mainly depend uppon weapon damage. The weapon I accuired was Relentless Edge from Ignis 10men, and I'm currently using Jawbone.

#1852SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3crazy dodo
Originally Posted by Taidaisher
Does the hit percentage shown on my player frame take into consideration my racial bonus? For example, my current hit % is 8.03 (I think) does that mean, as a Draenei, I'm actually at 9, or does that mean I am at 7 + 1 from being Draenei?
It does not take the racial bonus into consideration. So you're at 9%

You can always check this by dividing your hit rating by 32.79 (at lvl80) for melee hit% and 26.23 for spell hit% (yes they are different)

The hit bonus does not show on your sheet (it only shows hit rating converted to hit), so you have 9.03% melee hit.

Originally Posted by Fingaz

#1857SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Wistful
PvE DPS advice appreciated
Hi there, not sure if this is the right place to post this.. and I know this is probably the 572195729 "I need help with my dps" post that you guys have read, but having said that, I would really appreciate some advice on improving my dps in raids.

First of all, some background info, am playing currently as a Blood (51/0/20) Blood Elf DK. I have been playing as a melee class (rogue) since Vanilla, thus, I am familiar with the basic rules of PvE dps. Have also been keeping myself fairly up-to-date on how to maximise PvE dps (eg. priority system, item weights for Blood, etcetc) by reading EJ fairly regularly.

Recently, I have been finding myself posting poor numbers at single target bosses (usually last amongst melee classes by a substantial amount) and am wondering where have I gone wrong.

With regards to my gear, I usually run with 4pc T8 with some other ArP pieces from Ulduar 10/25. I am aware of the 420ArP soft-cap (have Mjolnir Runestone) and Aesir's Edge hasn't been dropping for me. Am currently geared for hit cap but not expertise cap.

Below is a parse from one of my XT hard mode fights (which I feel is one of the best ways to judge sustained melee dps, barring Gravity/Light bombs and ignoring Heart DPS):

WoW Meter Online - Combatlog Replay

I understand that my rotation in that parse had some flaws (too few Heart Strikes / Death Coils and too many Death Strikes) in that parse as it was a rather frantic attempt for myself. With that notwithstanding, I am unsure as to why I am coming up with such numbers.

To hazard a wild guess, I noticed that the number of skills performed (DS, HS, DC, etc) from my 09:23 kill was similar to the number of other DKs with shorter kill times, eg. WoW Meter Online - Combatlog Replay or WoW Meter Online - Combatlog Replay.

FWIW, I am running on Oceanic ping (400 - 500ms) and have been finding few free GCDs even with the supposed loose rotation that Blood is supposed to have.

Thus, I would really appreciate any feedback if there are any fundamental issues with my playstyle, rotation or gearing before I can further pinpoint what is hindering my dps.

Apologies for the long post.

Cheers

#1858SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Xequecal
Is there any way to macro Rune Strike to Death and Decay? Simply making a macro with /cast Rune Strike /cast Death and Decay doesn't work, no idea why.
#1859SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3crazy dodo
Originally Posted by Xequecal
Is there any way to macro Rune Strike to Death and Decay? Simply making a macro with /cast Rune Strike /cast Death and Decay doesn't work, no idea why.
try
#showtooltip Death and Decay
/cast !Rune Strike
/cast Death and Decay
this will attempt to queue a Rune Strike (if you have available RP) before casting Death and Decay, you can use the same macro with any other skill (Obliterate, Icy Touch, etc.) depending on how you prefer to use up your RP
#1860SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3thedudeabides
Blood Tank: 3/3 Spell Deflection
Just getting into tanking on my DK, and i specced the Blood build from Suno's Endgame Tanking Thread here. This build picks up 3/3 Spell Deflection (in my build i drop hysteria and mark of blood for 3/3 DRM, but that's apart from my question).

However, i noticed when looking at many of the armory's of posters in the end of the thread, that they drop 3/3 Spell Deflection, and pick up either subverion, morbidity, or in some cases sudden doom + morbidity (dropping rune tap).

Why are tanks dropping Spell Deflection? With a parry of ~18-20%, that means about 1 in 5 spells will take 45% less damage. Are they dropping because the term "direct damage spell" doesn't apply to many encounters, or because the actual proc rate is so low (thus unreliable) or because they are trying to get more TPS?
#1861SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• emptyrepublic
Originally Posted by thedudeabides
Just getting into tanking on my DK, and i specced the Blood build from Suno's Endgame Tanking Thread here. This build picks up 3/3 Spell Deflection (in my build i drop hysteria and mark of blood for 3/3 DRM, but that's apart from my question).

However, i noticed when looking at many of the armory's of posters in the end of the thread, that they drop 3/3 Spell Deflection, and pick up either subverion, morbidity, or in some cases sudden doom + morbidity (dropping rune tap).

Why are tanks dropping Spell Deflection? With a parry of ~18-20%, that means about 1 in 5 spells will take 45% less damage. Are they dropping because the term "direct damage spell" doesn't apply to many encounters, or because the actual proc rate is so low (thus unreliable) or because they are trying to get more TPS?
Personally I take Spell Deflection myself given some of the content my guild and I are on at the moment. Many people prefer the "constant" effect that Subversion, Morbidity, etc provide given that Spell Deflection is a chance effect. In reality it's a personal preference. You are balancing potentially more mitigation against a specific type of damage versus an increase in overall threat. It depends what you and your guild are doing and your play style on which path you wish to take.
#1862SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by thedudeabides
Just getting into tanking on my DK, and i specced the Blood build from Suno's Endgame Tanking Thread here. This build picks up 3/3 Spell Deflection (in my build i drop hysteria and mark of blood for 3/3 DRM, but that's apart from my question).

However, i noticed when looking at many of the armory's of posters in the end of the thread, that they drop 3/3 Spell Deflection, and pick up either subverion, morbidity, or in some cases sudden doom + morbidity (dropping rune tap).

Why are tanks dropping Spell Deflection? With a parry of ~18-20%, that means about 1 in 5 spells will take 45% less damage. Are they dropping because the term "direct damage spell" doesn't apply to many encounters, or because the actual proc rate is so low (thus unreliable) or because they are trying to get more TPS?
Most people are dropping the talen because it has very little application in the current end-game raiding; almost no bosses use DD spells on the player (I actually can't think of any right now). On the flip side, many of the encounters in Ulduar are threat sensitive (Hodir, Vezax etc.) so grabbing extra threat talents like Necrosis, Sudden Doom etc. are extremely helpful.
#1863SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3thedudeabides
What constitutes a DD spell?
Originally Posted by Darkside
Most people are dropping the talen because it has very little application in the current end-game raiding; almost no bosses use DD spells on the player (I actually can't think of any right now). On the flip side, many of the encounters in Ulduar are threat sensitive (Hodir, Vezax etc.) so grabbing extra threat talents like Necrosis, Sudden Doom etc. are extremely helpful.
Thank you for the reply. For my understanding, can you give me a few examples from Naxx and Ulduar of what constitute a DD spell and what does not (even though you take spell damage?)

ie. blizzard from Saph, flame jets from ignis, eye beam from Kologarn, light/gravity bombs on XT (not that a MT should worry about those)
#1864SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
The biggest example would be Sarth's flame breath. This is the only notable example though, as pretty much every other DD spell in the game hits for tiddlywinks, so you don't have to worry about gearing around it. Examples of attacks that don't count would be Fusion Punch, Frozen Blows, XT Bombs and Plasma Blast (I think).
#1865SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Travex
How much does weapon speed affect DPS? For example, I am currently using Lotrafen (3.4 weapon speed) but would Aesir's Edge (3.6 weapon speed) be noticeably better? Don't want to take away Aesir's Edge from our tanks that have to go offspec quite a bit if the increase is minor. Blood DPS spec if that matters at all.
#1866SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Travex
How much does weapon speed affect DPS? For example, I am currently using Lotrafen (3.4 weapon speed) but would Aesir's Edge (3.6 weapon speed) be noticeably better? Don't want to take away Aesir's Edge from our tanks that have to go offspec quite a bit if the increase is minor. Blood DPS spec if that matters at all.
Lotrafen's rating with under blood EAP is 2979.545, Aesir's is worth 2929.344 points *before* sockets are taken into consideration. With double Bold Scarlet Ruby it is worth 3021.824, with a Bold Dragon's Eye and a Bold Scarlet Ruby it is worth 3070.954. I have found that ~100 EAP matters very little in the scheme of an average gear set which is worth over 11,200, so take what you will from that.
#1867SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Blodalv
How does the Blood talent tree correspond to Dual-Wielding? I've come to understand that the Blood tree is based almost entirely on physical damage. How does that affect choice of weapon, should I go for a fast mainhand and a slow offhand or vice versa? Anyone with experience trying this, please let me know.
#1868SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Blodalv
How does the Blood talent tree correspond to Dual-Wielding? I've come to understand that the Blood tree is based almost entirely on physical damage. How does that affect choice of weapon, should I go for a fast mainhand and a slow offhand or vice versa? Anyone with experience trying this, please let me know.
Actually blood is the least viable tree to dual wield with.

Blood has the most non-magic damage. And all our strikes (non-magic) are based on weapon damage. So blood would not be a smart choice if you want dual wield.

Frost is an option (gonna be the centric dual wield tree next build), since you can make a build that relies heavily on icy touch damage.

Unholy is, at this moment, most likely your best option. You can make a build that revolves heavily around death coil damage.

I am trying to decide between [Leggings of Innumerable Barbs] + [Crude Discolored Battlegrips] and [Heroes' Scourgeborne Legplates] + [Heroes' Scourgeborne Gauntlets].

My wow armory is The World of Warcraft Armory

Using the appropriate stat weighting, and similar gems/enchants, the Innumerable + Discolored comes out slightly higher (3% or so), but that doesn't take into consideration the 4 piece T7 bonus. How do I factor that? And any opinions on which combo is better for me?

Thanks in advance.
#1870SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3crazy dodo
Originally Posted by Khrala
I am trying to decide between [Leggings of Innumerable Barbs] + [Crude Discolored Battlegrips] and [Heroes' Scourgeborne Legplates] + [Heroes' Scourgeborne Gauntlets].

My wow armory is The World of Warcraft Armory

Thanks in advance.
It's really a comparisson for the gloves only as Heroes Legplates are better stats wise.
With the gloves the only question is will you be hit capped with Heroes as that's the only added benefit to the Battlegrips. the 4pc bonus is a definite must as it provides a lot of free RP, so if you can get the hit somewhere else go for both Heroes pieces.
#1871SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		blackmaji360
@ fingaz.

You are below expertise cap. next time u raid check and see if you have long strings of parries and dodges. expertise is more important for blood but you are currently low for even unholy. if you can get around 20-21 expertise you should see a noticable increase.

@ wistful

You didnt list your rotation so i cant really tell if your doing anything wrong. There is a dps forum dedicated specifically for blood. im sure you could find your answer there. but i am almost certain it is your expertise. expertise lowers the chance that u will be parried or dodged. for blood expertise is crucial since it is the most physical talent tree. as you near the cap you will see a substantial increase in dps.

#1901SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Moose65
3.2 Corpse Explosion Glyph

#1902SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sylari
Been pouring over the UH thread and haven't found an answer yet.

How/when does Wandering Plague calculate its damage? Does it re-calculate the DoT and proc or does it actually just do the DoT's damage again as the tooltip reads?

Mostly wondering because of 4pT9.. would a double proc ( crit + WP ) deal 300% DoT damage to the main target or 400% basically?
#1903SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Sylari
Been pouring over the UH thread and haven't found an answer yet.

How/when does Wandering Plague calculate its damage? Does it re-calculate the DoT and proc or does it actually just do the DoT's damage again as the tooltip reads?

Mostly wondering because of 4pT9.. would a double proc ( crit + WP ) deal 300% DoT damage to the main target or 400% basically?
The tooltip says it does whatever damage your dot did, upon it and all targets around it.

Wandering Plague does not make your dots crit, it simply has a chance (equal to your crit) to do the damage you did again to all mobs around you.

So if in 3.2 your dot crits, and then procs wandering plague it should do the critical damage to all mobs around you (so that makes 400% in that perspective).

People often mistake Wandering Plague for a talent that makes your DoTs crit, but that's clearly not what the tooltip states. (Not implying you did, because you stated you read the tooltip, more a general remark)
Pandemic (affliction lock) is a talent that makes dots crit, Wandering Plague is simply a talent to do the same damage twice. (There is a distinct difference in that )
#1904SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ebonplague
Actually two questions:

1. When I hit a Mob, particularly a boss, with Froststrike, they sometimes resist the Damage partially (mostly 25%, I think). Since this is a severe DPS loss, is there any way to prevent this from happening? Do I need spell penetration (if so, is it reasonable to go for it in PvE content?)? Do I need to be beyond the melee hit cap of 8%, or is the damage even related to the spell hit cap?

2. With 3.2 coming up, is it reasonable to aim for a +melee hit chance around 20% or is this just overshooting things? I guess +hit plays a bigger role in this build, the question I'm asking myself, however, is, if it's that important that I want it, even if I'm already at 10% hit or so.
#1905SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3dravok

#1906SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3seanthomas999
Originally Posted by Ebonplague
Actually two questions:

1. When I hit a Mob, particularly a boss, with Froststrike, they sometimes resist the Damage partially (mostly 25%, I think). Since this is a severe DPS loss, is there any way to prevent this from happening? Do I need spell penetration (if so, is it reasonable to go for it in PvE content?)? Do I need to be beyond the melee hit cap of 8%, or is the damage even related to the spell hit cap?

2. With 3.2 coming up, is it reasonable to aim for a +melee hit chance around 20% or is this just overshooting things? I guess +hit plays a bigger role in this build, the question I'm asking myself, however, is, if it's that important that I want it, even if I'm already at 10% hit or so.
1. all the bosses have some amount of resistances, these arent calculated through hit, but as you said it is spell penetration, dont gem for it, gemming for strength wil see a bigger increase, Frost strike and Scourge are considered as magic damage not mitigated by armour but resistances.

2. you havnt said wat spec you are going to try out, so i cant help there...
#1907SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Ebonplague
Actually two questions:

1. When I hit a Mob, particularly a boss, with Froststrike, they sometimes resist the Damage partially (mostly 25%, I think). Since this is a severe DPS loss, is there any way to prevent this from happening? Do I need spell penetration (if so, is it reasonable to go for it in PvE content?)? Do I need to be beyond the melee hit cap of 8%, or is the damage even related to the spell hit cap?

2. With 3.2 coming up, is it reasonable to aim for a +melee hit chance around 20% or is this just overshooting things? I guess +hit plays a bigger role in this build, the question I'm asking myself, however, is, if it's that important that I want it, even if I'm already at 10% hit or so.
1. You can't overcome that, not even by spell penetration. This is a resistance based on level difference, since the boss is 3 levels higher than you. Spell Penetration only works on actual resistance, which you won't see often in pve content.

2. Assuming any random dual wield build. More than special hitcap is overkill.

Get to the special hitcap (8%), between special and spell hitcap (17%) hitrating is ok but not better than most other stats. After the spell hit cap your hitrating will only improve white melee hits, and hitrating becomes a very bad stat.

Treat dual wield hitcaps like you would 2H. Try to get above 8%, anything more than that is dps wise not smart going for.
#1908SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Slider_1128
Originally Posted by seanthomas999
1. all the bosses have some amount of resistances, these arent calculated through hit, but as you said it is spell penetration, dont gem for it, gemming for strength wil see a bigger increase, Frost strike and Scourge are considered as magic damage not mitigated by armour but resistances.
I was under the impressioin that spell pen was still something we wanted. Granted I have been reading the pvp forum and this one so im not sure where it comes from but i remember people saying the magic number is around 70 to 75 spell pen. I have this on my DK with 2 gems of 20 spell pen and the back enchant to cloak of 35. Should i be regemming? Can anyone show the difference in the math?

Thanks in advance
#1909SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Slider_1128
I was under the impressioin that spell pen was still something we wanted. Granted I have been reading the pvp forum and this one so im not sure where it comes from but i remember people saying the magic number is around 70 to 75 spell pen. I have this on my DK with 2 gems of 20 spell pen and the back enchant to cloak of 35. Should i be regemming? Can anyone show the difference in the math?

Thanks in advance
PvP is rarely the same as PvE. In PvP, there is Mark of the Wild and Shadow Resist, talents, and Paladin Auras. It is good to have some spell penetration in PvP, but you want 0 in PvE because mobs don't have those player buffs.

Also having capped weapon skill helps with partial resists.
#1910SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Spell penetration is only useful in PvP, because that is the only place you will encounter resistances from sources other than the level gap. Many teams (esp. those with druids, mages or priests) will have a decent amount of spell resistance, severely reducing your damage. In this one limited case, spell pen. gems are actually ideal, up till a point (as you already seem to know). In PvE content, they are worse than useless, though.
#1911SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sylari
Originally Posted by Foxx2405
The tooltip says it does whatever damage your dot did, upon it and all targets around it.

Wandering Plague does not make your dots crit, it simply has a chance (equal to your crit) to do the damage you did again to all mobs around you.

So if in 3.2 your dot crits, and then procs wandering plague it should do the critical damage to all mobs around you (so that makes 400% in that perspective).

People often mistake Wandering Plague for a talent that makes your DoTs crit, but that's clearly not what the tooltip states. (Not implying you did, because you stated you read the tooltip, more a general remark)
Pandemic (affliction lock) is a talent that makes dots crit, Wandering Plague is simply a talent to do the same damage twice. (There is a distinct difference in that )

#1913SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3richard

#1917SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dubious
Tanking Def Cap vs Tooltip?
Quick tanking question. I have hit the defensive 540 cap according to the tooltip, wanted to be sure that I am not using old info. I am currently showing 540 cap without going all the way to 689 defense rating, should I make sure to hit 689?

As Moogul pointed out, make sure you have 689 defense rating, and don't let the tool tip fool you if it shows 140 defense for less than that amount of rating.
From [FAQ]Working theories of raiding at level 80
#1918SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
689 rating is for Pally and Warrior. Since smart DKs use the 25 Defense (not rating) enchant, you need a lot less Defense rating. Also the badges Sigil gives over 10 Defense.

#1926SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3ksb1082
3.2 Patch Notes indicate that the Blood-Caked Blade Talent - The damage from this talent is no longer normalized to weapon speed. #1927SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
BCB will now have hits that are directly dependent on your white hit paperdoll damage. In this sense, slow weapons will tend to hit for more, as they have a higher base damage than faster weapons.

#1930SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
Originally Posted by DrEnzyme
Is Glyph of Blood Strike activated by the tanking slows? (Thunderclap/IT/Infected Wounds) like Torment the Weak for Mages? I.e. Is it usable on bosses?
No. Stuff like the Frostfire Debuff or Infected Wounds will proc it, however, and are applicable.
#1931SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lyssa
Originally Posted by stampy
Does pestilence + glyph of disease work properly with tundra stalker and improved icy touch?
Imp IT: Pestilence with the glyph doesn't actually cast Icy Touch, it just refreshes the disease.
Tundra Stalker: Yes.

#1941SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Alyse
Originally Posted by blitzseed
hello, i'm running the 0/17/54 unholy spec and i was just wondering if the [Sigil of Awareness] is still the best Sigil to use or will the new [Sigil of Virulence] take it's place?
As unholy 0/17/54 using OB, the Sigils from best to worst will most likely be Sigil of Virulence > Sigil of the Vengeful Heart > Sigil of Awareness.

Sigil of Virulence has an 80% procrate and no ICD (as far as I'm aware of). STR will affect all your damage, including pet damage, and thus will most likely trump the other sigils.

#1943SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• Asphyxialol
They are not recorded separately, they are recorded as being the same attack, as if you were using a 2h, same with WMO, I have not checked with my WoL from tonight to verify whether it combines them or not.
Last edited by Asphyxialol : 08/07/09 at 4:42 AM.
#1944SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• Darkside
WoL will record the hits from both hands separately (World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis), while recount will not.

[edit] Let me clarify: Recount will show all Obliterate etc. damage as if it were from the same source. However, when displaying average/min/max hits, it will display data from the individual hands (i.e. your min hit will have come from your offhand and your max from your mainhand).
Last edited by Darkside : 08/07/09 at 5:05 AM.
#1945SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sylari
Originally Posted by Asphyxialol
They are not recorded separately, they are recorded as being the same attack, as if you were using a 2h, same with WMO, I have not checked with my WoL from tonight to verify whether it combines them or not.
Hm, must be bugging then, was testing it on a dummy and got a 3237 MH 1953 OH doublecrit and the mod displayed the 3237 as my highest recorded crit for that session.. will keep messing with things I guess.

- Frost Strike

#1954SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lyssa
Naerys - in essence, every GCD you look at your runic power, your avaliable runes, your procs and then you decide what to do. In theory the rotation you posted is the one you should be following, in practise you'll probably weave in frost strike between obliterates in the second rotation for instance. And yes "KM Rime" means casting Howling Blast when you have both procs up (a non-KM HB is a waste of a GCD, so you delay Rime procs until you get a KM proc).

MikkiDI - it's probably to ensure FF gets the tundra stalker buff (if you started the fight with IT).
#1955SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside

Originally Posted by leladax

Originally Posted by Paratrooper1508
Real dumb simple question here, does improved icy touch stack with windfury? I ask because I'm dual wield frost and wondering if imp frost presence is really the best place to put those 2 points. Imp IT talent line still gives you 5% haste, and if the Enhance dies you still get the buff. 5% haste is better than 6% stamina.
#1962SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Vashar
What should end game tanking stat weights look like for a DK? Stat weights would help when considering stuff such as aiming to get a 239 Furious Axe due to it's massive stamina instead of other weapons which may have a good mix of other useful stats (for threat). Also useful to gauge how well an item is itemized... something might have 6 more sta and 4 expertise, but another might have 6 def 6 str and 4 hit. Which to choose? A sta stacker would choose the prior... how many would choose the latter?

How does this set of stat weights look for a typical 5x/8/1x Blood tank: WoWhead.com stat weights (numbers are arbitrary... just providing a template)

Going by these stat weights, the 239 Furious Weapons aren't even an option due to how low AP is weighted (would trade 1 sta for 6 AP).
Last edited by Vashar : 08/09/09 at 9:13 AM.
#1963SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ministera
I just came back to the game after a 6 month break, and I ran into a startling issue today. In my tank gear, I have 540 defense (5.6% less chance to be crit), yet while tanking a couple instances I have been getting crit by mobs. Yes, regular mobs. Did something change while I was away? 540 is still the magic number, right? I can't find any answer to this anywhere else

There were no extenuating circumstances of buffs/debuffs that I was aware of.
#1964SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Vashar
What should end game tanking stat weights look like for a DK? Stat weights would help when considering stuff such as aiming to get a 239 Furious Axe due to it's massive stamina instead of other weapons which may have a good mix of other useful stats (for threat). Also useful to gauge how well an item is itemized... something might have 6 more sta and 4 expertise, but another might have 6 def 6 str and 4 hit. Which to choose? A sta stacker would choose the prior... how many would choose the latter?

How does this set of stat weights look for a typical 5x/8/1x Blood tank: WoWhead.com stat weights (numbers are arbitrary... just providing a template)

Going by these stat weights, the 239 Furious Weapons aren't even an option due to how low AP is weighted (would trade 1 sta for 6 AP).
There are no set in stone tanking weights. Why? Because tanking can go multiple routes. You can go for maximum effective health, mitigation, avoidance, threat, etc. In addition to this there is diminishing returns on the two dominant stats for tanks - dodge and parry rating. Most tanks carry around a few extra pieces to swap out variant on the fight. As an example I used to go for maximum effective health when I would tank HM Steelbreaker, because threat was not an issue and living through Fusion Punches was. For Normal Vezax I had a balanced set of threat gear and effective health, as casters standing in Shadow Crashes can put out a good... 16k+ TPS. For HM Vezax you put on maximum effective health gear because threat is a non-issue as casters are not casting unless they have a crash under them.

Pure avoidance sets are next to unheard of. Why? Effective health is superior, it gives you more cushion for your healers to top you off. Avoidance is risky, you can have a string of 10 dodge / parry / misses, or you can get hit 3 consecutive times and die. Consistency is key when it comes to tanking, especially with stress on healers. Letting them know what to expect is beneficial to the raid. That all being sad, my primary tanking set has a mixture of effective health and threat generation gear.

If you are interested in what kinds of items to look for in end game terms take a look here: http://elitistjerks.com/f72/t44638-s...nking_updated/

At the bottom of the first post it has a set of gear for effective health, avoidance, threat, and then pre-heroic hard mode gear (ie gear to get you ready for hard mode, generally balanced but pretty much effective health oriented).
#1965SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Ministera
I just came back to the game after a 6 month break, and I ran into a startling issue today. In my tank gear, I have 540 defense (5.6% less chance to be crit), yet while tanking a couple instances I have been getting crit by mobs. Yes, regular mobs. Did something change while I was away? 540 is still the magic number, right? I can't find any answer to this anywhere else

There were no extenuating circumstances of buffs/debuffs that I was aware of.
540 Defense skill is the magic number for a boss. Normal mobs you can get away with 535. Other than debuffs, the only way to get crit with 540 is sitting down and letting the mob hit you.
#1966SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Vonhagen
Pawn Values for Blood and Unholy DPS
Figured since I typed these up for a friend, I'd share. Please note that the string for Unholy is based off of the "Naxx" gear weightings.

BLOOD DPS
( Pawn: v1: "Blood DPS": ArmorPenetration=2.75, CritRating=1.56, Dps=9.89, Strength=2.89, Agility=1.37, ExpertiseRating=2.47, HasteRating=1.5, HitRating=2.51, Ap=1, Armor=.03 )

UNHOLY DPS
( Pawn: v1: "Unholy DPS": ArmorPenetration=.729, CritRating=1.234, Dps=6.337, Strength=2.981, Agility=.85, ExpertiseRating=1.38, HasteRating=1.276, HitRating=1.968, Ap=1, Armor=0.00 )
Last edited by Vonhagen : 08/10/09 at 1:20 AM. Reason: title clarification

#1968SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Clat
Which build is highest DPS against single target in v3.2 ? (Assuming BiS before v3.2, from Ulduar 10/25)
2H Blood or DW Frost/Unholy ? or ???

Since all DK talent has been reset, I believe this is what everyone want to know.
I've been trying to solve this myself by browsing WMO/WWS report generated after v3.2.
But I havn't seen any DW build popped yet. (I might have missed it)
I've been reading every post and I know the optimize theory/build/rotation is still under discussion.
But it is time a Guru come to guide us.

Is current high ARP makes blood undefeatable, or DW Frost+OB Rotation utilized Hit/Haste to make it top DPS build now?
What is the trend and future? What do v3.2 items leading us to?
Personally I run with a very solid Blood set (~440 Armor Penetration, ~4600 AP, ~28% Crit, 296 Hit, 17 Expertise, and Runestone) and even with less than optimal DW gear my double Vulmir DW setup is out performing Blood the more and more familiar I become with the spec. If you trust simulators then DW frost is miles ahead of Blood (placing my DW setup about 1k dps above my Blood setup in Kahorie's Simulator). From everything I have seen Frost DW > Blood > Unholy DW > Unholy Obliterate in terms of personal DPS. The DW Frost setup has a large portion of its damage affected by Armor Penetration (just like 2h Frost OB heavy builds did in 3.1), so the transition from Blood to DW Frost is easy to make and effective.

#1972SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Theldon
Originally Posted by Almin
Is it worth it to watch if it procs to cast to produce threat? Many boss fights, I won't be able to do this so I'm asking if it's worth watching Rime buff to produce threat with.
I won't be able to fully answer your tanking question as my experience in that area is very limited, but an add-on I use to monitor procs is TellMeWhen. This will display an icon of the proc anywhere on your screen. I find this much easier than constantly checking your buff bars, and could solve your dilemma of howling blast usage.
#1973SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by crazynarutard

Try to use a sim/Rawr.

Using my alt's gear with 17% ArP and 17/54, Bandit's is still better than Grim/Runestone (this is assuming you didn't need the melee hit from Grim, otherwise Grim would be best). However, it was a small dps difference between Runestone and Bandit's.

#1975SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Krovacs
Is Sigil of the Vengeful Heart or Awareness better for a 2h blood spec in 3.2? Also as a bonus, is it just me, or is the new Triumph badge sigil completely terrible for Blood?
#1976SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
Vengeful heart is still better than Awareness for Blood in 3.2. Nothing has changed in regards to either Death Strike or Death Coil for Blood between 3.1 and 3.2, so the value of the sigils are the same as always.

And, yes, the new sigil from Triumph emblems is completely useless for Blood, seeing as you use neither Obliterate or Scourge Strike. Common sense ^.-

1) Necrosis
2) Sudden Death
3) Subversion
4) Might of Mograine

#1978SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Chross
Hey guys, question concerning expertise.

I already know that 26 is expertise skill is the number I need to be striving for. My only concern is that in order to reach that number I'll have to be switching out quite a bit of strength gems. I currently do not have a lot of items with expertise as a base stat. My question is: How much freedom do I have when gemming for expertise? Does everything else go out the window until I hit 26 expertise? Regardless of how much strength I'm losing? Or depending on my gear, would it be more beneficial to not necessarily push expertise but opt for more strength?
#1979SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Chross
Hey guys, question concerning expertise.

I already know that 26 is expertise skill is the number I need to be striving for. My only concern is that in order to reach that number I'll have to be switching out quite a bit of strength gems. I currently do not have a lot of items with expertise as a base stat. My question is: How much freedom do I have when gemming for expertise? Does everything else go out the window until I hit 26 expertise? Regardless of how much strength I'm losing? Or depending on my gear, would it be more beneficial to not necessarily push expertise but opt for more strength?
Gemming for strength is a better investment in raw dps. The trade-off, however, is that your strikes will be less consistent which will throw off your rotation a bit and jumble you up (in particular with blood, as we use so many single rune abilities in a given rotation). It is best to aim to pick up something with expertise on it, but it isn't worth regemming your gear from str to exp.
#1980SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Doogie
does the Relentless Earthsiege Diamond - Item - World of Warcraft increase in critical damage include spell damage? im currently 0/17/54 spamming death coils and was wondering if it was best to use this meta.
#1981SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Doogie
does the Relentless Earthsiege Diamond - Item - World of Warcraft increase in critical damage include spell damage? im currently 0/17/54 spamming death coils and was wondering if it was best to use this meta.
Yes, you want to always use a 3% crit damage meta.

Regarding the previous question of which threat talents to get, most Blood tanks likely get MoM because the crit damage helps with AoE and single target threat (others are single target only) and the talent is most "fun" of the four talents.
#1982SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3halfpint
The 3% damage boost applies. It has been stated that the crit from agi does not affect your spell crit rate. The plus to getting the RED is you only have to sacrifice one slot fulfill the meta requirements.

The difference is, is it more worthwhile to go with 1 less mixed color gem at the expense of some spell crit rating? (This is a rhetorical question that is left up to you to answer; in reality, we're splitting hairs here over less than 1% damage difference.)

EDIT: In comparison to the chaotic skyflare diamond*
#1983SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Travex
Someone just told me that my Horn of Winter interrupts them from eating... I've never heard of this before, is that true? o.O
#1984SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Gollardo
I'm sorry if this has been asked over and over again. But with the new DW Frost Spec, why is BCB better than Subversion? Wouldn't it be better to get extra 9% crit on your main ability then a talent that gives 1.2% more damage in an encounter? Thanks in advance!

Rhome
#1985SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3marvis
What's about Sigil of Virulence? Is that better than SoVH for Blood or SoA for Unholy and Frost?
#1986SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Gollardo
I'm sorry if this has been asked over and over again. But with the new DW Frost Spec, why is BCB better than Subversion? Wouldn't it be better to get extra 9% crit on your main ability then a talent that gives 1.2% more damage in an encounter? Thanks in advance!

Rhome
You are misguided by the number. 9% more crit on obliterate does not even come close to something like 9% more dps.

9% crit on obliterate equals about 6% extra obliterate damage. (Ask if you want extended math on this, or look it up, i posted it somewhere around page 50 in the DW thread)

6% extra damage on an ability that is ~33% of your dps means about 2% more dps for 3 talent points.
That means about 0.66% per talent point.

It's a bit more ( about 0.8% ) since it also affects bloodstrike, and the thread reduction is nice too.

But blood caked blades is not 1.2% dps, its a bit more. I think you forget to count it hits on both weapons.
It averages around 2.4%, which is 0.8% dps per point as well.

I personally prefer Subversion, because of the thread reduction, but mostly because its more stable. BCB has the tendency to be 5% of your dps on one fight and 1.5% on the next.

But don't overestimate subversion, just because 9% crit seems to be a lot, it doesn't mean the talent is that good.
#1987SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Soilantgreen64
Originally Posted by Foxx2405
You are misguided by the number. 9% more crit on obliterate does not even come close to something like 9% more dps.

9% crit on obliterate equals about 6% extra obliterate damage. (Ask if you want extended math on this, or look it up, i posted it somewhere around page 50 in the DW thread)

6% extra damage on an ability that is ~33% of your dps means about 2% more dps for 3 talent points.
That means about 0.66% per talent point.

It's a bit more ( about 0.8% ) since it also affects bloodstrike, and the thread reduction is nice too.

But blood caked blades is not 1.2% dps, its a bit more. I think you forget to count it hits on both weapons.
It averages around 2.4%, which is 0.8% dps per point as well.

I personally prefer Subversion, because of the thread reduction, but mostly because its more stable. BCB has the tendency to be 5% of your dps on one fight and 1.5% on the next.

But don't overestimate subversion, just because 9% crit seems to be a lot, it doesn't mean the talent is that good.
One thing to add, a lot of people have said they don't even notice the threat reduction from Subversion or that it doesnt make a difference. If you come from a background of playing a Blood DK, and then try to switch to DW w/out subversion, you will notice the difference. When raiding as Blood I dont even display Omen, but I found myself having to pay attention to my threat as 0/53/18. I tried out a 3/53/15 build as well, and was much more comfortable with the threat, though theoretically it is less DPS.
#1988SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Soilantgreen64

If you come from a background of playing a Blood DK, and then try to switch to DW w/out subversion, you will notice the difference. When raiding as Blood I dont even display Omen, but I found myself having to pay attention to my threat as 0/53/18. I tried out a 3/53/15 build as well, and was much more comfortable with the threat, though theoretically it is less DPS.
The dps loss from dropping BCB is next to nothing. It was a bit overrated on the simulators because we often applied too much haste.

#1991SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Leadfoot77
What is the Frost tree equivalent of the major cooldown Gargoyle/DRW of the unholy/blood trees? I have spec'd into the new 0/53/18 DW Frost build but it seems there is no big cooldown ability here?
#1992SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Leadfoot77
What is the Frost tree equivalent of the major cooldown Gargoyle/DRW of the unholy/blood trees? I have spec'd into the new 0/53/18 DW Frost build but it seems there is no big cooldown ability here?
Frost doesn't have a major burst cooldown analog to either of those abilities; the closest thing it gets is Unbreakable Armor. However, DW Frost makes up for this by having a very high sustained damage output and an "execute" set of abilities.
#1993SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
@Masaru: For Obliterate Unholy, Sigil of Virulence > Sigil of the Vengeful Heart > Sigil of Awareness.

@Leadfoot: Frost doesn't have a major RP cooldown like Gargoyle or DRW. They do, however, have Unbreakable Armor which, with it's 25% strength, is a fairly sizable cooldown for dps, and is as close as it gets.
#1994SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Leadfoot77
Originally Posted by Consider
@Leadfoot: Frost doesn't have a major RP cooldown like Gargoyle or DRW. They do, however, have Unbreakable Armor which, with it's 25% strength, is a fairly sizable cooldown for dps, and is as close as it gets.
ty for the reply. There is a lot of discussion right now in the DW thread about whether to take UA or not due to the complexities of working it into the rotation without messing up your runes. There may or may not be some macros that can make it worthwhile - but I haven't read that far into the thread yet
#1995SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Leadfoot77
ty for the reply. There is a lot of discussion right now in the DW thread about whether to take UA or not due to the complexities of working it into the rotation without messing up your runes. There may or may not be some macros that can make it worthwhile - but I haven't read that far into the thread yet
Once you know the rotation better it's probably worth it. It can only be popped at certain parts in your rotation though, which makes it a bit less flexible.

I think the only cooldowns frost really has that you can effectively pop when burst is needed are Raise Dead and Unbreakable Armor, both are quite mediocre compared to DRW and GG though.

#1997SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3◊ Bryne
Frost's AOE threat is better, but blood will have superior single-target threat. Both are with 2H - DW tanking is suboptimal and has poor threat generation. For frost DPS, DW will probably win out.

The three specs are probably closer now than ever in tank viability and DPS, so as always, you should take into account what buffs you need to bring that your raid group might otherwise be missing.
#1998SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3leladax
Originally Posted by Shujima
I've been reading the posts here for days now and can't seem to find a solid answer to my query. Hopefully you guys can help me.

I'm not sure which will yeild the better results for Frost spec: DW tanking vs 2h tanking and secondly, (for my dual spec) DW DPS vs 2h DPS.

Due to the fact that I work 50 hrs a week and have 2 kids, I'd like to keep it constistant to save time (farming, gemming, etc) so DW tanking with DW DPS? or 2h with 2h?) but that's not such a big deal.

I guess what I'm asking is (all things being equal) which will yeild the highest TPS/DPS respectively post 3.2. I can figure the specs out from there on my own, but any help would be really appreciated.

Anyway, thank you.
I'm going to give 2 cents, nothing more. According to the latest version of the simulator, common values show DW DPS Frost to be the best (in 3.2). However, this is definitely not a consensus opinion so don't take this as a definite answer in any way. Personally I see a utility advantage in frost DPSing: It's simple to use compared to Unholy - i.e. less error prone - and in my humble opinion more fun than blood.

In tanking I wouldn't go to DW easily, even if my MS is tanking and usually frost. The main reasons are a) Stoneskin Gargoyle - which is optimally used on 565 defence (540 base + its own but undiminished 25) b) Leaving talent points that would be otherwise used in DW free for important utility tanking talents - at least to my experience - such as reduced CD in DnD.

#2002SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kyou
DW Frost stat weights
I was looking at the stat weights for DW Frost under the DW thread. One thing I noticed was that Hit was significantly weighted, even more than Strength. I know that Hit is absolutely needed until the special hit cap, but is it really worth more than Strength past that cap?
#2003SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Chaotic.Soul
I recommend you give it another look over:

Strength 261
Hit 388
Spell Hit 120

"Hit" is referring to the worth of hit until the special cap.
"Spell hit" is referring to the worth of hit until the spell hit cap.
There is a worth beyond that for capping white attacks however, it isn't shown in the weights.

So to answer your question: No. It is worth less than Strength past 8%.
#2004SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Xokati
Hello
Is Spell Deflection talent reduce Phase Punch and big bang Algalon 10 dmg?

br
Xo
Last edited by Xokati : 08/16/09 at 9:33 AM.
#2005SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		leladax
Originally Posted by Chaotic.Soul
I recommend you give it another look over:

Strength 261
Hit 388
Spell Hit 120

"Hit" is referring to the worth of hit until the special cap.
"Spell hit" is referring to the worth of hit until the spell hit cap.
There is a worth beyond that for capping white attacks however, it isn't shown in the weights.

So to answer your question: No. It is worth less than Strength past 8%.
Let me add, for his needs it's 5% hit only since he's using a DW spec that bufs hitting by 3% even in specials (this will be shown as 5% on the character pane).

Also, Expertise is more valuable that Strength until it's 26 (this will be shown as 26 on the character pane even with Tundra Stalker (unlike Hit bonus that doesn't seem to reach the char pane)).

It appears that the priorities in DW Frost are: Hit skill until 5% (value as it appears on the char pane) -> Expertise skill until 26 (value as it appears on the char pane) -> Strength.
Last edited by leladax : 08/16/09 at 9:46 AM.
#2006SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Chaotic.Soul
Originally Posted by Xokati
Hello
Is Spell Deflection talent reduce Phase Punch and big bang Algalon 10 dmg?

br
Xo
Big Bang's tooltip explicitly states it is Physical damage and as such is not effected by Spell Deflection. Phase Punch is Arcane so it may be reduced. I don't have first-hand experience to back this up.
#2007SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pessadilla
My guild tried doing general hard-mode today; I was tanking General on my Dk, and a Warrior was picking up the add. Dps was riding me in threat, like they should on this fight, I was trying to maintain the single target rotation during the fight (from blood; Suno's thread), but I have 1 question. Im not sure what gives more threat, 2 Heart Strikes, or 1 Death Strike.
#2008SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
2 Heart Strikes will out-threat 1 DS. The only exception is when you can guarantee that 1) the DS won't overheal at all, and 2) there is only one mob (multiple mobs = healing aggro from DS splits).
#2009SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pessadilla
Originally Posted by Consider
2 Heart Strikes will out-threat 1 DS. The only exception is when you can guarantee that 1) the DS won't overheal at all, and 2) there is only one mob (multiple mobs = healing aggro from DS splits).
Thats exactly why I'm asking; during Vezaxx fight, you are constantly getting damaged, you cannot guarantee it wont overheal, but there are no other adds (at least not until the saronite spawns, and by then all dps will switch to it), and it certainly helps the healers. If 2 HS produce more threat, I rather stay with them, because my main concern in the fight is threat, but if a DS + the healing of it produces the same threat, then I think it would be wise for me to do it instead.
#2010SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Diomed

#2011SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Diomed
So, with my gear should I go 2 1h Frost build, 2h Unholy (personal DPS) or 2h Blood (raid boost)?
The first thing is to cover what buffs are missing from your group. If you don't have a source of 10% AP, 2H Blood is an outstanding choice. Assuming all DK buffs are covered (10% AP, 20% melee haste, or 13% magic damage), pick which one you like best.

Since you get 3% free hit with DW, that may be the best pick (since you may not be hit capped) if you don't have to bring a raid buff.
#2012SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3coca
I was wondering what people are going to do with their triumph badges. Are you guys saving it for the T9.25 gear? Or are you going to spend it on the T9 gear? Having a hard time wondering whether I should use it now to up my dps a bit or wait and use it on the T9.25 gear instead. If I spend it on the T9 gear which pieces do you guys recommend to get first? I'm Blood 2H spec right now and I think that armor pen on the helm is real nice.
#2013SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3HamSlammer
For DW Frost, should you place the slower of the two slow 1handers in a specific slot, MH or OH? I currently use a 2.6 in my MH and a 2.5 in my OH, both of them have equal DPS. I figure you place the higher top end weapon in your MH unless there's any extenuating circumstances (Racial weapon proficiency for instance).

#2015SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Zaryne
I've been searching this thread for a while now, and i can't really find anything about my question. I didn't want to ask a question that had already been asked. But im reletively sure that it hasn't been asked. If it has, I'm sorry, and delete this post to any admin that see's it. If not, my simple question, probably very noobish xD, is :

Whats the better Pally Blessing for a Dps Dk (Blood).. I don't know if being blood has any relevence to the type of blessing, but just incase it is. The blessings im reffering to are [Greater Blessing of Might] and [Greater Blessing of Kings]. Ofcourse im only asking this question for those times that there are no two pallies. Like 5 Mans and such. Anyone's help would be appreciated, and especially someone that can tell me exactly why they decided on one.
#2016SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
For Blood, 1 str = ~2.9 AP.

Unimproved Blessing of Might gives 550 ap. This means that, for Kings to be better, you would need to have at least 1897 strength or more.

Improved Blessing of Might gives 688 ap. This means that, for Kings to be better, you would need to have at least 2382 strength or more.

So, with your gear, Blessing of Might is probably going to be superior in the majority of cases, but those are the values at which BoK would surpass it, for future reference.
#2017SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by HamSlammer
For DW Frost, should you place the slower of the two slow 1handers in a specific slot, MH or OH? I currently use a 2.6 in my MH and a 2.5 in my OH, both of them have equal DPS. I figure you place the higher top end weapon in your MH unless there's any extenuating circumstances (Racial weapon proficiency for instance).
In the event that both weapons are of equal average DPS values, use the slower weapon in the MH. Any top end variance makes negligible difference.
#2018SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3TiaMaster
Without CDs such as Gargoyle and Army - I went from having 3100 sustained dps using Unholy OBLIT build (0/17/54) on target dummy with not very intelligently gemmed gear using a 212 dps, 2.6 speed two handed axe, to...

2500 sustained dps using the new DW frost build (3/51/17) using Titansteel Bonecrusher and Aredar's Battlestar. I am very familiar with Frost rotations (priority, really).

But for the life of me I can't see how DW Frost is on top of the current, soon-to-be-nerfed UH Oblit build. SHould I switch to DW UH Oblit build? (0/18/53)

#2019SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Grunge
How important are the DPS stats on a weapon for DW Frost, mainly considering S6 PvP T1/T2 weapons vs easily obtainable alternatives (ala Aledar's Battlestar)?
#2020SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by TiaMaster
Without CDs such as Gargoyle and Army - I went from having 3100 sustained dps using Unholy OBLIT build (0/17/54) on target dummy with not very intelligently gemmed gear using a 212 dps, 2.6 speed two handed axe, to...

2500 sustained dps using the new DW frost build (3/51/17) using Titansteel Bonecrusher and Aredar's Battlestar. I am very familiar with Frost rotations (priority, really).

But for the life of me I can't see how DW Frost is on top of the current, soon-to-be-nerfed UH Oblit build. SHould I switch to DW UH Oblit build? (0/18/53)

Help? I REALLY was excited about going back to frost DW
It's said throughout the forum that DPS testing on dumies is a poor method of testing, with one of the main reasons being that necrosis doesn't work. This has an even larger effect on DW, because of the increase in damage from your melée hits, and consequently necrosis. Also don't forget that you need to focus on quite different stats for DW. Expertise, hit and armor pen play a different role. You can't just equip two 1h weps with your 2h gear and expect to rock the DPS meters
#2021SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by Grunge
How important are the DPS stats on a weapon for DW Frost, mainly considering S6 PvP T1/T2 weapons vs easily obtainable alternatives (ala Aledar's Battlestar)?
Weapon DPS has the highest EP of any stat, so very important. Only if the stat benefit of the lower DPS weapon outweighed the higher DPS weapon by a pretty large amount would you swap. But that shouldn't really happen.

#2031SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Vhaeraun
Originally Posted by Kavoc
Seeing as it doesn't proc from DS it wouldn't be as good. Unless of course you are using OB, but unless it has changed since I went DW, DS is better in blood.
I agree that DS > OB in 51/0/20 blood spec, but you can use an OB just before using IT and PS.

The cycle I use is : OB IT PS HS HS dc - HS HS DS HS HS dc dc
The advantage of that cycle is that OB have a +25% bonus with the deseases, and you delete them just before re-applying them. I agree when you say that OB < DS, even with the deseases, but you gain 200 strengh, which is really interesting.

You don't need an OB spec, and the 200 strengh bonus is permanent if you apply OB every 20 sec..
In my opinion that sigil is the best for a blood spec (but I can be wrong xD).

I can also ask : 140 exp. rat. = 6.5%. But is 138 = 6.25% or 6.4% ?

Edit 2 : in short, what I'd like to know is that if expertise works as an affine function or as a step function ?

#2033SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Paratrooper1508
For dual wield frost, and just in general, can someone give a reliable breakdown of which trinkets should be used? I am currently running FoTFF and Greatness, but with the new stuff out there (and old stuff that I'm not thinking of), what should dual wielders be using?
#2034SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
This depends on what you have stat wise and what you need. For questions like that I would recommend downloading and installing this program (http://elitistjerks.com/f72/t71378-z...izer_v2_1_0_a/) and paying attention to the specific spec threads to find the weights to use in the event they are different from the default weights.

Regarding expertise, you're rating will only go up every ~8 ish rating, which means anything from point one and up is worthless if it isn't 8 points (as an example 173 expertise rating is 21 expertise, but I drop down to 20 expertise from 172 to 165 expertise rating, making anything over 165 essentially 'worthless' as it doesn't add a point of expertise).
#2035SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• mutagen
Originally Posted by Asphyxialol
Regarding expertise, you're rating will only go up every ~8 ish rating, which means anything from point one and up is worthless if it isn't 8 points (as an example 173 expertise rating is 21 expertise, but I drop down to 20 expertise from 172 to 165 expertise rating, making anything over 165 essentially 'worthless' as it doesn't add a point of expertise).
This is incorrect, as discussed here, here and elsewhere. While the character sheet display only changes with large chunks of expertise you benefit from each bit of rating up to the caps.
Last edited by mutagen : 08/22/09 at 10:25 PM. Reason: Additional references
#2036SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by mutagen
This is incorrect, as discussed here, here and elsewhere. While the character sheet display only changes with large chunks of expertise you benefit from each bit of rating up to the caps.
My apologies for the misinformation then. I hadn't seen anything about that in the DK forums and was operating under the previously assumed information regarding expertise and its effect on dodge / parry and the character screen.
#2037SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Bloody_sorcerer
Are there any DKs that actually have 4T9 yet? So far I've only seen rumors that the crit chance of diseases is going to be a flat 15%, which, when the spell effects of the 4T9 bonus are compared to similar effects (most notably pandemic), it seems that the effect is more likely there to cause diseases to crit for 200%, rather than 150%.
#2038SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
It's literally impossible for anyone to have 4p t9 yet. With the limited amount of emblems which one could have received by now (I believe you should be up to something like 76 if you haven't spent any/done every available boss each week in both 10 and 25/done the heroic daily each day) and with hard mode tokens not yet being accessible, it just isn't possible.

The crit chance is not 15%. That was someone who doesn't/didn't know how to read spell descriptions and codes on Wowhead. The crit rate should just be whatever yours is - although whether it is your melee or your spell is still undetermined (although either way, the set bonus is incredible for any spec, and most likely making 4p t9 BiS).

The crit modifier being 200% is a pretty safe bet, whether or not it works off of melee or spell crit. If it's melee, it's 200% by default. If it's a spell, it's affected by Runic Focus, and thus still 200%.
#2039SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Bloody_sorcerer
Are there any DKs that actually have 4T9 yet? So far I've only seen rumors that the crit chance of diseases is going to be a flat 15%
The 15 someone is referring to the spell ID that allows DoTs to crit. Irregardless of whether spell or melee crit is used, both those stats have crit depression versus bosses. Melee crit is reduced by 4.8% on bosses, spell crit may be around 3%.

Note ther Ret Pally bonus is very similar (allowing a DoT to crit) and it is only 2 piece requirement, so most likely both set bonuses work similiar.
#2040SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mpiu
Any AEP / EP for t9 set bonuses out yet?
#2041SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Mpiu
Any AEP / EP for t9 set bonuses out yet?
The simulator version 1 program will do weights for all the set bonuses. It takes 5-15 minutes to run the program, so you could use someone else's numbers if you are lazy. People have been posting results in the spec-specific threads.

I'm currently blood DK and I'm still debating on whether I should spend my badges on the vendor helm or the tier 9.25 helm (with the trophy). One have alot more armor pen 86 while the other one have alot more expertise. Right now the BiS thread list it as having the vendor helm instead of the 9.25 helm. #2043SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
When it comes to badges you have to remember that you will be pushing out 60 badges a week in a full heroic / regular clear week of 10m and 25m coliseum (15 triumph each), so you will be overflowing with badges in a matter of a few more weeks. Personally I would say hitting the 4pc t9 quickly is worth more than getting the off piece (which is comparable). In addition to this, the t9 helm is more of a 'universal' helm than the badge off piece helm is due to the stat weight of armor penetration, making it useful if you choose to respec, where the badge helm would not.

#2046SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Meygaera
Originally Posted by shopshopshop
Just a guess, but could it be because the DRW might not inherit ArPen?
That wouldn't explain why his DC is hitting so low. My only guess for DC is partial resists. Other factors include: the DRW doesn't benefit from buffs after you cast it, so if your trinket happened to proc after you cast DRW then that would cause a minor discrepancy. Lastly for the heart strikes specifically, it be because you didn't cast diseases with DRW up so it's heart strike didn't have its own disease bonus.
#2047SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Tromit
Threat Problems
Hi all, lon time reader yada yada (:

So since 3.2 I have been having problems with my threat. Ass all of us I lost a ####load of HP and i think im taking alot more damage now in basicly the same spec! I have tried bloodtanking more than once and failed. Is there anyone who have been having the same problems?

And anyone whoo have a solution!
#2048SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Arcdragon
Originally Posted by Tromit
Hi all, lon time reader yada yada (:

So since 3.2 I have been having problems with my threat. Ass all of us I lost a ####load of HP and i think im taking alot more damage now in basicly the same spec! I have tried bloodtanking more than once and failed. Is there anyone who have been having the same problems?

And anyone whoo have a solution!
I can't comment on your damage intake, I've found no problem with damage mitigation but then I am blood spec with improved blood presence. I find that the buff to disease damage adds to my self healing. I've always considered the self healing aspect of blood tanking to be a major part of its mitigation--and it works.

As for your threat you are below hit cap by almost 2% and you are at only 17 expertise. You should aim for at least 26 expertise and even then you can benefit from more as a tank. 26 expertise helps to prevent your attacks being dodged but it does not completely remove parries.

A draenei can add to some of your hit, as would a shadow priest or boomkin but if you do not have these in your regular raid composition, you should invest in some hit gems until you have gear with hit on it.
You definitely need some expertise gems as ensuring your attacks are not dodged or parried will add to your threat.
Always ensure you have horn of winter up and remember Unbreakable Armour can be used as a threat cooldown as well as a mitigation cooldown. Use your best judgement to discern when to save it and when to use it.

Are you keeping frostfever up? That gives 15% more damage to all your abilities including Rune Strike.

Bladerune 80 dk tank
Last edited by Arcdragon : 08/25/09 at 5:23 AM.
