#2050SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Afabar
Originally Posted by Meygaera
That wouldn't explain why his DC is hitting so low. My only guess for DC is partial resists. Other factors include: the DRW doesn't benefit from buffs after you cast it, so if your trinket happened to proc after you cast DRW then that would cause a minor discrepancy. Lastly for the heart strikes specifically, it be because you didn't cast diseases with DRW up so it's heart strike didn't have its own disease bonus.
- Since 3.1, damage done by DRW is reduced by 50%.
- DRW do not benefit from glyph.
- DRW do not benefit from Blood gorged.
- DRW do not benefit from sigil.
- DRW do not benefit Blood Presence

Taking as sample this random log WoW Meter Online - Combatlog Replay
Average non crit Death Coil of this player is at around 3100 and DRW at 900 and he don't have glyph of dark death.
From this 3100, I remove Blood gorged, Blood Presence, 2 point in morbididy, then remove sigil and divide by 2.
((3100/ 1.10*1.15*1.10 ) - 380) /2 = 923.
It looks like correct.
#2051SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		norg
I need a bit of info for the BiS thread, but it's possibly too dumb a question to ask in the Blood DPS thread. I couldn't find a recent answer anyway.

The current Blood BiS sets all have static ArPen at around the 420 mark, which then obviously comes close to the hard cap once Mjolnir Runestone procs. But what I want to know is, is it worth my while adding in a secondary set for Blood where you do not have Mjolnir?

Presumably it would involve getting as much static ArPen as possible from gear, then gemming ArPen to the hard cap and gemming strength after that. However I know when I was still playing around the time 3.1 hit, for Blood specs ArPen had a stat weight quite close to strength but it was not advisable to gem for it. However according to Zerack's optimizer, its stat weight now seems to be way above str, so is that still the case?

edit: okay, in the build I was looking at last night, the ArPen value was like double the str value, but in the new optimizer build it now has a weight slightly lower than str again. So I guess the second question is now: Is the old advice to gem for str over ArPen still correct then, even if you're aiming to reach the hardcap without trinket procs?
Last edited by norg : 08/25/09 at 8:01 AM.
#2052SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Arcdragon
Originally Posted by Tromit
Yes i think along the way I might have been blindsided by the need to gem Stamina (: Hit and expertise i will go get some gems and change to blood, Just haveing problems getting Blood to hold aoe aggro! So is it better to for ex. gem for defence so i can change my rune to swordshattering , after i reach hit & expertise cap or should I keep gemming Stamina?

Regards
I consider swordshattering a pvp rune. Stoneskin Gargoyle gives you much more freedom to gem for hit and expertise. One you have enough hit and expertise you can gem for stamina and or avoidance, if you so wish.

for blood aoe, death and decay (I spec into morbidity)and blood boil work fine for me except in the arena part of Thorim on 10 man. I change to frost just for the aoe. Thankfully I only ever had to do it once. I love heart strike as its a cleave.

Be sure to communicate with your raid, tell them to give you two seconds to spread diseases and hit the mobs with a blood boil. If you stay frost, you can rival a paladin with aoe.
#2053SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Arcdragon
I consider swordshattering a pvp rune. Stoneskin Gargoyle gives you much more freedom to gem for hit and expertise.
Actually, no "good" DK uses Swordshattering for PvP (that is partly because IT and DC are so good atm).

Regarding threat issues, all DKs have two taunts (Death Grip only works a few seconds, but it is usually enough), and the dps need to learn to wait 2 seconds for diseases to spread.
#2054SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Soilantgreen64
Originally Posted by norg
I need a bit of info for the BiS thread, but it's possibly too dumb a question to ask in the Blood DPS thread. I couldn't find a recent answer anyway.

The current Blood BiS sets all have static ArPen at around the 420 mark, which then obviously comes close to the hard cap once Mjolnir Runestone procs. But what I want to know is, is it worth my while adding in a secondary set for Blood where you do not have Mjolnir?

Presumably it would involve getting as much static ArPen as possible from gear, then gemming ArPen to the hard cap and gemming strength after that. However I know when I was still playing around the time 3.1 hit, for Blood specs ArPen had a stat weight quite close to strength but it was not advisable to gem for it. However according to Zerack's optimizer, its stat weight now seems to be way above str, so is that still the case?

edit: okay, in the build I was looking at last night, the ArPen value was like double the str value, but in the new optimizer build it now has a weight slightly lower than str again. So I guess the second question is now: Is the old advice to gem for str over ArPen still correct then, even if you're aiming to reach the hardcap without trinket procs?
Before we were pretty easily soft capping ArP, it was proper to gem str until you hit around 6200 raid buffed AP, then people would start switching to ArP. Mainy because ArP in small amounts isn't very good, but it gets better the higher your AP, and is really good when you can stack it, soft cap it, etc. I would say this standard would hold true for people without the ArP proc trinkets.
#2055SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3TigrisFrostmane
Question: What's the rotation for 3/13/55?
#2056SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
Same as it is for 0/17/54.
PS - IT - Ob - BS - BS - DC - HoW// Ob - Ob - DC - Ob - DC

You can throw an extra DC in at the end, if you have extra RP from AMS, a resto druid, a disc priest, or whatever. As well, you also have the option of switching your first two Blood Strikes with your first Obliterate, however if/once you have SoVirulence. Although the Desolation affecting a Blood Strike and an Oblit might be superior to the SoVir proc affecting the two Blood Strikes, due to the 10 second ICD of the Sigil, using it before the Blood Strikes means it has a chance to proc sooner than it would if you did that first Oblit after the BSes, which leads to directly higher uptime (while Desolation's uptime is the same with either order). Minute differences either way, but still.
#2057SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3TigrisFrostmane
Same except for one less DC from the loss of Chill of the Grave, obviously.

Thanks.
#2058SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Albrechtt
I've been tanking on my DK for a while now, and I've noticed recently that I'm one of the hardest tanks in my guild to heal, especially on Algalon, despite being one of the best geared. Is there something I've been doing wrong (I follow the rotation as perfect as I can get it, have plenty of expertise, not hit capped but that's not much of a problem here) or is the nerf to DKs just really that bad?

Note that I don't spec into IIT because the other tank brings it so there's really no point in having it.
Last edited by Albrechtt : 08/26/09 at 1:30 PM.
#2059SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		leladax
Originally Posted by Albrechtt
or is the nerf to DKs just really that bad?
It's the 2nd or 3rd time I notice someone talking about Algalon being hard to be tanked by DKs. It's most probably right; as a fast hitting boss it makes avoidance and block more valuable.

Noting: In my opinion what should not be overlooked is the armor nerf. A point of armor is approximately equivalent to a point of health for physical damage (meaning indestructible potion is like giving +3500HP when tanking physical damage (plus easier healing)). Hence death knights lost not just HP from blood, not just HP from presence, but also effective HP from armor when tanking physical.
Last edited by leladax : 08/26/09 at 11:48 AM.
#2060SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Raspeh
Originally Posted by Consider
For Blood, 1 str = ~2.9 AP.

Unimproved Blessing of Might gives 550 ap. This means that, for Kings to be better, you would need to have at least 1897 strength or more.

Improved Blessing of Might gives 688 ap. This means that, for Kings to be better, you would need to have at least 2382 strength or more.

So, with your gear, Blessing of Might is probably going to be superior in the majority of cases, but those are the values at which BoK would surpass it, for future reference.

This is only considering the Strength component though... I realize other stats are not nearly as good as strength, but perhaps only having say 1895 STR (using such a small difference for example) would still merit kings, because of agility's crit (and stam might be helpful for incoming aoe fights). I wonder at what point kings would surpass might taking into consideration agility's small role.
#2061SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
Agility is worth about 1 AP (slightly less for Unholy, slightly more for Blood, but regardless). I have 129 agility (base agi + 10 from chest enchant + 10 from Nightmare Tear), which is probably what most people have (unless they are enchanting their cloak with agility, but that's their mess up). HoW bumps that up to 284.

That means BoK would give you an extra 28 agility, or the equivalent of 28 ap. 28 ap is the same as ~9.33 strength.

How does that change things?

Unimproved Blessing of Might gives 550 ap. This means that, for Kings to be better, you would need to have at least 1887 strength or more.

Improved Blessing of Might gives 688 ap. This means that, for Kings to be better, you would need to have at least 2372 strength or more.

In other words, you would need to have 10 less strength then if you ignore the agility contributions. Really not that big of a deal =p
#2062SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3teiglin
Originally Posted by Consider
Agility is worth about 1 AP (slightly less for Unholy, slightly more for Blood, but regardless). I have 129 agility (base agi + 10 from chest enchant + 10 from Nightmare Tear), which is probably what most people have (unless they are enchanting their cloak with agility, but that's their mess up). HoW bumps that up to 284.

That means BoK would give you an extra 28 agility, or the equivalent of 28 ap. 28 ap is the same as ~9.33 strength
Don't forget that you get another 155 from HoW (or 178 from talented SoE). Many people also use an agi weapon/cloak/neck/ring, as it is quite possible for the four dps stats to outpace the higher value of strength. While it's rarely optimal, it can serve a good interim place too when people don't have the BiS strength item.

Not that this changes things a lot more (might/battle shout will still always be a larger dps increase than kings), but you'll always have 300 or so agi in a raid even without agi gear.

IT-PS-HS-HS-DS -DUMP- DS-HS-HS-HS-HS -Dump-

IT-PS-HS-HS-HS-HS-DS-DUMPx1-HS-HS-DS-DUMPx2

Is this a lesser dps rotation? I still have room for dump phases and my DS still always have atleast 25 RP. DS-IT-PS-HS-HS--Raise Ghoul-DC-HS-HS-DS-HS-HS -Dump

#2065SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Arcdragon
Originally Posted by Albrechtt
I've been tanking on my DK for a while now, and I've noticed recently that I'm one of the hardest tanks in my guild to heal, especially on Algalon, despite being one of the best geared. Is there something I've been doing wrong (I follow the rotation as perfect as I can get it, have plenty of expertise, not hit capped but that's not much of a problem here) or is the nerf to DKs just really that bad?

Note that I don't spec into IIT because the other tank brings it so there's really no point in having it.

Try putting points into improved blood presence. Sure, people might laugh at you and I have no doubt many will laugh at me saying this but I have it and people find me to be one of the easiest tanks to heal. Remember that they buffed disease damage. I now see my self healing from diseases alone to be more healing than what I'd get from having a shadow priest in my group (I usually don't, my guild is strict ten man).

Also it scales with vampiric blood.

The self healing you gain from the damage you do, combined with the heals from death strike mean I mitigate alot of damage by healing myself. The very least you can do is try it, also you might want to consider using four pieces of T8.5 if you have it, the 4pc set bonus is nothing short of amazing. At least it is to me.

I find I have a little less health but better survivability since 3.2.

I noticed you do not have mark of blood, this is an amazing tank cooldown that can also be used to heal others during encounters with frequent raid damage. If you chain vampiric blood with mark of blood, your healer can practically go afk for the duration.
#2066SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3leladax
Originally Posted by Arcdragon
improved blood presence
I've thought of that too and I'm not laughing at you; I even contemplated of using bloodworms for the same reason but that may be an overkill.

However, there's a high limitation in those methods: you have to assume it's for fights where there is minimal overhealing and the HP bar is largely on the 50-90% side. This is very hard to happen in most hard hitting bosses, especially if it's a 25-man with several healers spamming at once.

It may be more beneficial in 10-mans and when the Healing arrangement is generally less on the overhealing side.

#2068SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		leladax
Originally Posted by frmorrison
Bloodworm AI isn't the best since sometimes they attack from the front (causing parry haste). Assuming like the previous poster you didn't trust your healers, I would think maxing Rune Tap would be the first choice, then Mark of Blood, then imp Blood Presence.
I realize the technical superiority of RT, however it has a utility disadvantage, it not passive. This may be of course a personal preference but I prefer passive improvements to active ones unless the active ones are significantly better after flatting out the gains over time. Since 4 points are needed before RT is considerable help, I'd 1st go to Mark of Blood since it's 1 single point for 80% HP healing over a relatively short time. Its CD is long but it can be considered another 'soft o-shit' CD like Vampiric Blood. It won't save from a severe enrage but it's decent healing help. I'd prefer RT first but 4 points make it too expensive. I'd rather go to 4 threat points when it's merely a CD and not a passive improvement.

#2072SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Blackteddy
Is baseline T9 2PC worth breaking up T8.5 4PC for?
#2073SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
For what spec?

Looking at your armory, you're Unholy. For Unholy, 4p t8 and 2p t9 have almost identical EP values (within 10 of each other, depending on the rest of your gear). As such, when you factor in the added stats, it's almost certainly an upgrade. So, yes, it is worth breaking 4p t8 for, but more for the increase in stats than anything else. The set bonuses (boni?) just cancel one another out.

That, and 4p t9 is a must have.

#2075SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sanctimony
Leveling DK Spec and Presence

DPSing while leveling is very different from DPSing while raiding. Your targets typically don't survive through a single set of runes (fights will last on the order of 5 seconds unless AOEing), so things that are important to sustained DPS become irrelevent. This, in addition to the fact that you typically have a chunk of downtime while you're finding the next mob to kill make burst damage king. As such, once you have unholy presence, you're almost always better off in it than blood presence, especially when you take into account Improved Unholy Presence. Napkin math time.

Autoattack damage is equal in both presences. Special abilities will hit for 13% less in UP, but you'll get to use up to 50% more of them due to the 1s GCD (if all your runes refreshed before you reached the next mob, 9 seconds out of combat.) In the worst case of constant combat, you'd get 10% more attacks off due to IUP. Ignoring sources of damage that are flat-out reduced in UP (diseases, D&D, and (somewhat) death coil) and assuming a linear relationship between time spent out of combat and abilities you can use in combat, for the two presences to reach parity you'd need to spend roughly 0.7s ooc between fights. In practice this time will be longer, but not by much: damage contribution from diseases is minimal, and you're more GCD constrained than RP constrained for death coil due to Butchery.

You want to level unholy spec, largely due to the movement speed bonuses of On a Pale Horse and IUP. Your spec shouldn't necessarily look anything like a raid spec; I used something like Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft. A couple of notable omissions from this spec: Epidemic, Unholy Blight, Bone Shield. Your targets will die too quickly for your diseases to wear off (or do much damage) or for UB to do its thing. Since you're constantly going to be hit, BS is going to have minimal uptime and mitigate minimal damage. Butchery provides a nice extra chunk of runic power, and Runic Power Mastery helps you avoid wasting runic power. Only notable glyph is Death Grip, which is by far the best major glyph for leveling.

It can also be handy to activate the dual-spec feature and to use a self-healing tank spec like Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft for soloing group quests. General idea is to use all frost and unholy runes for death strike for self healing, and to use pestilence to refresh your diseases when necessary.

Please excuse my crimes against parentheses.
#2076SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3leladax
When you have to tank massive incoming of ads (e.g. Thorim or the encounter in Halls of Stone) do you go only with Death and Decay (in reduced cooldown) and Blood Boil or do you risk it and try to always also apply diseases? I found that if the healing is imba applying diseases is optimal but if it's absolutely imperative to hold agro at all times by everything Blood Boil and Death and Decay only may be better though I am concerned damage(threat) is minimized. I wanted to hear your opinions.
#2077SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Romple
Diseases are your bread and butter. Sometimes I have to get some threat on mobs RIGHT NOW and I might neglect spreading diseases (I"m blood spec) in favor of a quick blood boil. However if you have the time you definitely should always spread diseases. It amplifies all of your abilities (including blood boil) and hence all of your threat. This is one reason blood ae threat isn't as good as unholy or frost. It basically takes 3-4 GCDs just to set yourself up. By contrast, Frost can put a disease up on all mobs with Howling Blast.

Originally Posted by Braiinchild
Hi there, I have a few questions moderately specific to my own Death Knight- I'm sorry if these have been answered, I was unable to find them in this thread or the other threads.

My alt DK:
The World of Warcraft Armory

I have literally no Expertise. Statweighs show that for my particular spec, Expertise is worth a good deal more than Strength, but I have been told I should gem for pure Strength regardless.

What is the Expertise cap, and what should I be gemming for given my extremely low Expertise?
It's quite easy to search for the expertise cap within the forum, I'm somewhat surprised you didn't find it.

However, as DW frost, expertise to the soft cap of 26 is a higher DPS increase than strength. As such, you should gem / enchant EXP until you reach that cap before for STR. The same goes for HIT.

Originally Posted by frmorrison
All properly DKs have 5 or 6 expertise, you have 5. Strength is higher on the stat weights, however I would recommend using Rawr to make sure that strength is better.
I think you'll find that all 'properly' Frost DW DKs aim for 26 EXP, and not "5 or 6".

Please be cautious about giving innacurate advice in this thread - a lot of people who are looking for answers come here.

Originally Posted by Sakuratei
In preparation of doing some rough math on SoA versus SoV for DW frost, I'd like to find out how the following abilities scale with AP:

Icy Touch
Blood Plague
Frost Fever
Howling Blast
White hits

Thanks in advance.

#2085SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sakuratei
Originally Posted by reflexdk
I think you'll find that all 'properly' Frost DW DKs aim for 26 EXP, and not "5 or 6".

Please be cautious about giving innacurate advice in this thread - a lot of people who are looking for answers come here.
I'm fairly sure he meant 5 or 6 from talents. As for gemming expertise, the general opinion is split. If you want your rotation to be smooth and eliminate all possible dps losses from a dodge, you cap Expertise (using gems if necessary).
If you want to go for theoretical max dps, you gem pure strength and take expertise as you go from gear, gambling with your rotation being performed successfully.

You can find more info about this if you search through the DW frost thread.

Edit: Thanks for the link, Reflex.
#2086SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3leladax
Many simulation setups show higher DPS with expertise. It's not just a utility advantage - such as Spell hit - if that is the case.
#2087SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by Sakuratei
I'm fairly sure he meant 5 or 6 from talents. As for gemming expertise, the general opinion is split. If you want your rotation to be smooth and eliminate all possible dps losses from a dodge, you cap Expertise (using gems if necessary).
If you want to go for theoretical max dps, you gem pure strength and take expertise as you go from gear, gambling with your rotation being performed successfully.

You can find more info about this if you search through the DW frost thread.

Edit: Thanks for the link, Reflex.
I'm not so sure he was, but let's hope the mods give him the benefit of the doubt too

I'd have to disagree with you I'm afraid. As per the stat weights indicated here, EXP until cap is a much higher EP than STR, and consequently a higher theoretical DPS increase. It's worth noting, however, that this is in a high level raid environment of course.

Once the soft cap has been reached, EXP drops right down in EP, and of course STR exceeds it by a long shot.
#2088SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Chawps
Question About New Unholy Blight
Before 3.2, Unholy Blight seemed far easier to understand -- if its up, its doing X dmg to any target w/i X yards. Since 3.2, I am unsure of the mechanics of the talent. Could someone map out the mechanics of UB for me please according to the following:

(A) Does the 20% additional damage change based on the damage done by the DC that proc'd it? Or is it 20% of the damage DC in the tool tip?

(B) Does the next DC reset the duration of the UB or does it extend it?

(C) If all it does is reset the duration, is it worth choosing a secondary (and sometimes a third if available) to DC to maximize UB damage?

(D) Assuming (A) is the specific DC and (C) will boost dps, is it worth insuring a DC crits before moving on to the next target?

(E) Is UB such a small % of overall dps now that the above is more or less irrelevant?
#2089SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3slant
Unholy blight works like ignite, "banking" damage and resetting duration when repeatedly applied. You won't lose damage if you spam deathcoils and you won't gain damage applying the debuff with trinket buffs up and then trying to "roll" it. Think of it as a flat 20% bonus to all death coil damage if your target lives for 10 seconds. The link below goes a bit more in-depth into the mechanic.

Unholy blight is not a major source of damage in most builds, but it is more than worth one talent point over the alternatives.

Mage Guide to Ignite – Frosty Magecraft | Spicytuna

#2092SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by reflexdk
I'm not so sure he was, but let's hope the mods give him the benefit of the doubt too

I'd have to disagree with you I'm afraid. As per the stat weights indicated here, EXP until cap is a much higher EP than STR, and consequently a higher theoretical DPS increase. It's worth noting, however, that this is in a high level raid environment of course.

Once the soft cap has been reached, EXP drops right down in EP, and of course STR exceeds it by a long shot.
An individual a few posts back nailed it on the head. Simulators calculate out long hours of combat, ie simulated maximum sustained DPS, where expertise has shown to be the best, as it increases the minimum value of your DPS, but not your maximum (as you mentioned, there is a cap to when expertise becomes essentially worthless). Strength, on the other hand, increases the theoretical maximum dps one can put out in the event he can pull a lucky string of no misses / dodges in a fight (while not being hit / exp capped).

EP values aren't everything, you have to use your head on some of the stuff here, the EPs are calculated over the course of a 100+ hours (generally around 1,000) - not your average 3-4 minute burst encounter like we currently have in game. As for frmorrison, he was stating 5/6 expertise from all properly spec'd dks, I personally raid with him and know that he wouldn't have said something to the effect of 5-6 expertise is all you need, he simply left out 'spec' in his post.
#2093SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3geo_a4
Originally Posted by reflexdk
1) Physical
2) Physical
3) NA
4) If the socket bonus is beneficial, or your HP is high enough, you can gem avoidance (dodge / parry). To be honest, it all depends on what you're tanking, what you've got and what you lack
well im 35k self buffed as a blood tank at the moment, 24.76% dodge, 20.96% parry. my melee hit is 216 (6.59%), is it worth gemming to hitcap myself as a tank or just leave as is? i'm aiming to be doing uld10 hardmodes
#2094SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Xokati
Anyone have made some anlyse whitch glyph boost more threat? Rune Strike or Death Strike? I`m thinking about Standard blood tank build with rotation IT-PS-DS-2xHS-RDump-DS-4xHS-RDump.

#2095SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3leladax
I wouldn't easily sacrifice HP for taunting only. In most scenarios I'd first use Glyph of Dark Command if I'm nervous about it (maybe a good idea if twin-tanking is needed on a new boss, e.g. Gormok Impaler).

Game designers have managed to make effective HP the king in tanking lately and it will need quite a critical need that can not be overcome otherwise to sacrifice it.

i.e. I'd only go to something other that stamina after crit cap if:
a) DPSes constantly steal agro, requiring threat through hit, expertise or remotely, strength
b) Where tanking is aimed (in a rare scenario) at multiple targets where avoidance is more useful or in another rare scenario a boss is so rapidly attacking with low dmg hits that avoidance becomes superior,
c) Frost resistance or other specialized resistances are needed.
#2096SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Romple
Does Death Grip act as a taunt the same way Taunt does? I'm still not entirely sure on Taunt mechanics. Does it give you a large amount of Threat to give you aggro or does it just temporarily give you aggro? Same with Death Grip.
#2097SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		slant
Both dark command and death grip are true taunts. They set your threat equal to the mob's highest threat target + 1 and force the mob to attack you for 3 seconds.

Also, unless something has changed recently, taunts are indeed on spell hit chance, not melee hit. So you need 17% to never miss a boss, -3% with a shadow priest/boomkin, -1% with a draenei, -3% with virulence; 10% overall. That comes down to 263 hit rating for alliance and 289 for horde. Interestingly, 263 hit rating is also the melee special hit cap at 8% (melee and spell hit scale differently).
Last edited by slant : 09/02/09 at 1:06 PM.
#2098SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		leladax
Originally Posted by slant
Both dark command and death grip are true taunts. They set your threat equal to the mob's highest threat target + 1 and force the mob to attack you for 3 seconds.
Which means an interesting minor fact is that Developers actually wrote in Death Grip's tooltip the full extend of a taunt not found on the actual taunting ability: It acts like a negative spell on the target for 3 seconds.
Last edited by leladax : 09/02/09 at 2:28 PM.
#2099SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by Asphyxialol
An individual a few posts back nailed it on the head. Simulators calculate out long hours of combat, ie simulated maximum sustained DPS, where expertise has shown to be the best, as it increases the minimum value of your DPS, but not your maximum (as you mentioned, there is a cap to when expertise becomes essentially worthless). Strength, on the other hand, increases the theoretical maximum dps one can put out in the event he can pull a lucky string of no misses / dodges in a fight (while not being hit / exp capped).

EP values aren't everything, you have to use your head on some of the stuff here, the EPs are calculated over the course of a 100+ hours (generally around 1,000) - not your average 3-4 minute burst encounter like we currently have in game. As for frmorrison, he was stating 5/6 expertise from all properly spec'd dks, I personally raid with him and know that he wouldn't have said something to the effect of 5-6 expertise is all you need, he simply left out 'spec' in his post.
I understand, however I'd argue that the EP variation between the two is large enough to negate relying on a reasonably lucky string of hits. EXP will still give a higher net DPS increase until cap than STR.
#2100SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by slant
Both dark command and death grip are true taunts. They set your threat equal to the mob's highest threat target + 1 and force the mob to attack you for 3 seconds.

Also, unless something has changed recently, taunts are indeed on spell hit chance, not melee hit. So you need 17% to never miss a boss, -3% with a shadow priest/boomkin, -1% with a draenei, -3% with virulence; 10% overall. That comes down to 263 hit rating for alliance and 289 for horde. Interestingly, 263 hit rating is also the melee special hit cap at 8% (melee and spell hit scale differently).
You are correct on the taun mechanic, and it's worth noting that once you've taunted, the second highest player in the agro table then needs to exceed your threat by an additional 30% in order to pull agro again.

WOW Head reports both Dark Command and Death Grip are physical abilities...
#2101SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sarianah
When 4piece T9 becomes available will 3/13/55 take the lead in terms of personal dps?
#2102SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lagan
Hi,

I've looked around in the various tanking threads, but am still lost. The DPS threads have stat values for Strength / Armour Penetration, etc : AP. Are there any numbers for tanks for those stats, and threat, mitigation, etc?

thanks.
#2103SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
It is hard to create stat weights for tanks, since some of it is personal preference. In general, you want the highest item level "tank" piece in each slot. When you have choices of the same item level, then you must decide what stats you prefer (I like to get the tanking set bonuses, while others don't care for it).

Generally Suno makes a list of the "best" tanking gear if you have trouble deciding which ones to go for when their are choices.
#2104SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3leladax
Regarding threat strictly, one can assume stat weighting is similar to the tree used. e.g. Blood DPS stats for threat in blood tanking. However a better job could be done if one used the simulator on the actual tanking talents.
#2105SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Romple
Doesn't Rawr model TPS?
#2106SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Romple
Doesn't Rawr model TPS?
Yes, there is a scale that you can change for how much value you feel threat is worth gearing for.

In addition, Rawr will give you stat weights based on your current stat weights. I don't agree with how Rawr weights stats (it undervalues expertise).
#2107SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3

In addition, Rawr will give you stat weights based on your current stat weights. I don't agree with how Rawr weights stats (it undervalues expertise).
It undervalues expertise because the formulae Theck has done aren't properly modeled in it yet. Unless someone has updated it in the newest version?


For anyone curious about what he's done, here's a link. Note for everyone here that the math isn't optimized for DK's, but it gives us a rough idea of just how useful Expertise can be.

#2111SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Blackteddy
The full 4 set is baseline T9, would it still be worth getting with the stat bonus'?
#2112SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
If you take t9 BiS set pieces you either off set chest or helm - considering more builds prefer to off set the helm I used Shoulders, Chest, Gloves and Legs for calcs. For the purpose of this 'theorycraft' we will consider t8 4pc and t9 2pc equal (even though t9 2pc beats t8 4pc for every spec), so we are comparing dropping t8 2pc for t9 4pc without the set bonus (ie pure itemization).

Going from t8 to t9 nets the following:

78 Sta
86 Str
406 Armor
82 Armor Pen
109 Crit
21 Hit
-55 Expertise
-40 Haste

The t8 2p is worth ~120 ap to UH, ~90 ap to DW Frost, and ~70 ap to Blood, so for t9 to out perform t8 2p without calculating the t9 4p you would have to beat...

Unholy - 287 ap
Frost - 326 ap
Blood - 300 ap

Now, the bonuses above total...
Unholy - 633.38 (gain of 346.38)
Frost - 697.24 (gain of 371.24)
Blood - 749.09 (gain of 449.09)

So, yes, regardless of the set bonus functioning correctly at the current time the t9 4pc ilvl 245 set (shoulder / chest / gloves / legs) are dominant over t8. Once they fix the bonus (assuming it isn't intended) the values will go up even more. As for the weights used I used the 3/13/55 2h UH, my personal 3/51/17 frost weights through multiple 1,000 hour sims in the simulator, and an updated version of my personal blood stat weights (factoring in fixed arm pen value) as the values. I can post those weights if you would like to do your own testing (different off pieces, like plated leggings of ruination, etc.).

The end result is, however, that t9 is clearly dominant despite the 4pc being broken, so it is very much so worth the investment.
#2113SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Blackteddy
I meant the 232 T9. I don't have any 245 T9 as I don't have the trophies.
#2114SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
You would need to do your own math then. The stat weights are in Zerack's Gear Optimizer program, you can go to Wowhead to compare the two sets stats and see if they are still a bonus for you on an individual level (which pieces you intend to upgrade, what 239 loot you may have that is better than the 232 loot, etc).

You simply take the t8 2pc bonus, and then add whatever stats the t8 has over the 232 t9 (should just be expertise and haste), and then use that as your base value that the other set needs to exceed to be an upgrade. Then you take the bonus t9 provides over t8 and muliply those by the specific values listed in the optimizer and subtract the initial value you achieved from the t8 2pc and t8 raw bonus to see the effective attack power you receive from the upgrade (and without 239 loot it should be a very solid upgrade).

edit: Also - I forgot to mention any socket differences between the two sets and didn't factor having them socketed (they both have 6 sockets - t8 has 1 red, 1 yellow, 4 blues and t9 has 3 red, 2 yellow, 1 blue - in the end from a raw itemization format on sockets the t9 should be a bonus anyways, especially considering the 4pc mentioned above all have str socket bonuses on t9).

#2117SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reflexdk
Originally Posted by shopshopshop
For Blood DPS, during burst phases longer than diseases last:

I usually build up 60 RP to go into the phase with DRW ready. Then I IT+PS and blow my death runes on heart strikes, then blow ERW/BT for more heart strikes. My question is what to do when diseases run out and there is <10s left on the phase. Is it better to reapply diseases and continue as normal or simply ignore diseases for the remaining time and cast HS/DS/DC depending on your rune situation.
This slightly towards the extreme end of "maxing your DPS" isn't it?

However, blowing your available runes on the hardest hitting strikes during these last few seconds should net more damage than applying IT / PS and using one, maybe two disease-buffed strikes.

It all depends on what you have available in terms of RP / runes.

#2120SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Krovacs
Why does nobody talk about Frost 2H anymore? Blizzard releases one new talent in 3.2, Threat of Thassarian, and all of a sudden Frost is the DW tree. I personally hate DW. I don't enjoy the aesthetic of it, and I don't really like the playstyle either.

But I love the Frost tree. I'm just wondering if anyone has put any effort into testing a viable 2h Frost build in the 3.2 patch?
#2121SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Papertigers
Originally Posted by Krovacs
Why does nobody talk about Frost 2H anymore? Blizzard releases one new talent in 3.2, Threat of Thassarian, and all of a sudden Frost is the DW tree. I personally hate DW. I don't enjoy the aesthetic of it, and I don't really like the playstyle either.

But I love the Frost tree. I'm just wondering if anyone has put any effort into testing a viable 2h Frost build in the 3.2 patch?
Simply put, after the SotVH frost strike damage reduction (which was the bulk of 2h frost damage) 2H frost is no longer competitive or viable. EJ (as a whole) does not care for aesthetics nor what's necessarily enjoyable. Instead it is focused on what benefits the raid, which is essentially not 2h frost atm.

If you enjoy 2h frost, go for it. You just wont see it being discussed solely because it is no longer viable.

Sigil of Virulence
#2133SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by drothar
For DK tanking, let's say 5000 AP raid buffed (I think mine is around there), would the +20 hit or the +2% threat enchant yield more overall threat increase? (Assuming below melee hit cap).

And if we want to satisfy a red gem socket, would 10 strength or 10 expertise be better for threat after 26 expertise/dodge cap is reached?
2% is the best threat enchant (even with 0 hit and 0 expertise) and you get 10 parry rating as well.

The best threat stat is expertise (pre 26 cap), then strength, then slightly below strength is expertise post 26 cap. Note expertise will reduce parry haste (more bosses have it on than turned off), which reduces damage taken somewhat.
#2134SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3keebz

#2136SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by keebz
1) Question about Horn of Winter: Sometimes when I put it up, it doesn't show up with all the other raid buffs - this is usually in the heat of battle (say perhaps halfway into a boss encounter). I don't see it and I was told once that another member did not see it either...so is there a bug/glitch (you get the stat increase but not the actual buff icon), or is there just something else (a totem?) that can overwrite Horn Of Winter? I know I use it for the RP generation since I am Unholy but I was just wondering...maybe some others have noticed that from time to time as well.
If a shaman puts out SoE totem (any shaman, doesn't matter if specced into Improved SoE), HoW won't show up, since the totem is potentially stronger. You still get the RP, though. Depending on the fight (e.g. fights, where melee are not always within range of elemental / restoration shaman's totems) it may be advisable to tell those shamans to use a different totem and let you supply the buff. In case of an enhancement shaman, the shaman should supply the buff, since it is stronger and his totems are usually always within range for the melee.
In any event you always get the RP, though.

#2139SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lyssa
@Coragun:
The proc for both is called the same, is the same, and they won't stack if they proc together, one will just refresh the other. Thus, quite pointless to wear both.

Then consider the value of 84 crit vs 84 resilience for PvE purposes..


@Lu Bu:
They don't run off aggroing new packs if that's what you mean. If you're currently fighting a pack and the mob you were attacking dies, they will go after some other mob in the same pack though.
Re: healing I checked a recent combatlog and under Healing Recieved for my bloodworms it says: Glyph of Holy Light 70.7%, Judgement of Light 22.8%, Protection of Ancient Kings 6.4%, Circle of Healing 0.0%.
Checking a recent singletarget parse shows them doing ~100dps over 6 minutes to Algalon. So yes, they are a dps increase, but they do eat aoe heals.

#2141SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3

No, they don't stack and they never did. I tested it a few months ago when I first got the Anvil, and I tested it again today. Same result.

SS right at 'is refreshed'
Buff gone

The three Unholy Strength buffs, while called the same, aren't the same buffs (200 strength, 180 strength, 15% strength) so they do indeed stack.

#2146SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Goggage
Hi all,

Hopefully this is not a stupid question.

My DK recently dinged 80. I notice in the consolidated blood guide that the primary stat for DK is strength. Like other classes we have a hit cap of 263 and the guide instructs to gain hit from equipment and not to gem for it.

The problem I have is finding DK kit with hit on it, for example if you take a glance at my character, Sammantha, you will see that very little of it has hit. I am now approaching the point where I have accumulated enough emblems of conquest to start purchasing the Conquerer's Darkruned Battleplate and even this doesn't have hit.

Yesterday I ran OS25 and was managing to DPS around 4.5k at 99 hit. I have now gemmed to hit gems to test. My hit has increased, but not capped, yet I have not noticed a significant increase in DPS.

Finally the question! Should I ignore hit and return to strength gems or go all out and purchase epics and get to hit cap come hell or high water?

Thanks.
#2147SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Diello
As a blood DK Str and ArP will always be worth more than hit on a point-by-point basis so you don't want to gem for hit. There are cases when it can make sense to use a str/hit orange gem to get a socket bonus, but generally you just gem for Str or ArP.

The question of how much of one stat you should give up to gain another is why we have stat weights in the first place. You can plug all the stat weights into Lootrank or Wowhead and find out what is generally better for you, but you'll have to keep the hit and expertise cap in mind.
#2148SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Goggage
Thank you for your quick response. Good job we have a JC in the guild!
#2149SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Bifurcamet
Originally Posted by Diello
As a blood DK Str and ArP will always be worth more than hit on a point-by-point basis so you don't want to gem for hit. There are cases when it can make sense to use a str/hit orange gem to get a socket bonus, but generally you just gem for Str or ArP.

The question of how much of one stat you should give up to gain another is why we have stat weights in the first place. You can plug all the stat weights into Lootrank or Wowhead and find out what is generally better for you, but you'll have to keep the hit and expertise cap in mind.
In practice, i can subscribe your conclusions in unholy presence, however if you miss a couple of plague strikes in blood presence, your dps may drop by around 10% or even more if you panic and screw up your rotations because of it.
#2150SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Foxx2405
Originally Posted by Bifurcamet
In practice, i can subscribe your conclusions in unholy presence, however if you miss a couple of plague strikes in blood presence, your dps may drop by around 10% or even more if you panic and screw up your rotations because of it.
That is totally accounted for. As a matter of fact that is the whole thing that gives hit rating its value. If you miss a plague strike you dont discard that, you just redo the attack and drop the attack with the least DPGCD (Dmg per GCD), which in most cases is RP dump.

That doesn't take away that the decreasing that chance by 1 rating is worse dps (even counting the rotation messing up), than adding 1 strength which increases all your abilities.

What does need a footnote in my opinion however, is that these numbers are generated with simulators which in most cases react in the ideal way to something like a miss. A person might not react the same way.
Imagine a busy fight with a lot of stuff going on, someone hits plague strike which misses, but he doesnt notice until he used icy touch and obliterate because of dodging fires. In this case he not only lost a GCD worth of dps (which the simulator accounts for) but also a multiplier on that obliterate (the sim didnt make that slip-up). This is not the same as panic by the way, I see panic as a lack of skill or confidence.

Most simulators run under ideal circumstances (granted you can add latency, but discicion wise they always chose the best option); and they should to be able to provide the best data. However if transfer that data to the real thing you often notice that it doesn't fully transfer equally. In a non-ideal situation expertise and hitrating will gain ground on strength, which is good enough of a reason for a lot of people to aim for the spell hit cap and expertise cap, even though those stats are strictly seen inferior to stacking more strength.
Last edited by Foxx2405 : 09/22/09 at 10:18 AM.

I've never really tried Frost before and I've got some questions about Acclimation. Has anyone tested Acclimation on Anub'Arak and Leeching Swarm? Does it typically proc off AOE abilities such as that?
No, it doesn't work on Anub. Usually it only works on direct attacks, but then there are some exceptions.
#2154SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3SpoonfulOfMacheath
So my tank lead has been after me lately to start stacking expertise. He alleges that the reason myself and our warrior tank get instagibbed on heroic Beasts is that we are not stacking enough expertise. While he (a druid tank) can tank heroic beasts (namely I'm talking about gormok here) without any problem. Although I think that as a bear tank who can reach upwards of 85k health with CDs going and around 65k normally he can survive simply because he has a massive amount of hp in comparison to his other MTs.

My question is this;

Should I, as a dk tank, be stacking expertise upwards of the soft cap? I know soft capping knocks boss dodges off the table, but is getting even more to try to knock parry off the table (and by proxy parry-hasting which is the reason according to my tank lead all his tanks are getting instagibbed) necessary for a dk tank?


My gut feeling is no as it feels like I would be gimping myself too hard for other stats to reach said cap.
#2155SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Bloody_sorcerer
Originally Posted by SpoonfulOfMacheath
So my tank lead has been after me lately to start stacking expertise. He alleges that the reason myself and our warrior tank get instagibbed on heroic Beasts is that we are not stacking enough expertise. While he (a druid tank) can tank heroic beasts (namely I'm talking about gormok here) without any problem. Although I think that as a bear tank who can reach upwards of 85k health with CDs going and around 65k normally he can survive simply because he has a massive amount of hp in comparison to his other MTs.

My question is this;

Should I, as a dk tank, be stacking expertise upwards of the soft cap? I know soft capping knocks boss dodges off the table, but is getting even more to try to knock parry off the table (and by proxy parry-hasting which is the reason according to my tank lead all his tanks are getting instagibbed) necessary for a dk tank?


My gut feeling is no as it feels like I would be gimping myself too hard for other stats to reach said cap.
Your tank lead should pay more attention to in-game fixes; most notably, Gormok doesn't parry-haste any more, so stacking expertise will not reduce the likelihood of instagibbing.
#2156SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foxx2405
Originally Posted by SpoonfulOfMacheath
So my tank lead has been after me lately to start stacking expertise. He alleges that the reason myself and our warrior tank get instagibbed on heroic Beasts is that we are not stacking enough expertise. While he (a druid tank) can tank heroic beasts (namely I'm talking about gormok here) without any problem. Although I think that as a bear tank who can reach upwards of 85k health with CDs going and around 65k normally he can survive simply because he has a massive amount of hp in comparison to his other MTs.

My question is this;

Should I, as a dk tank, be stacking expertise upwards of the soft cap? I know soft capping knocks boss dodges off the table, but is getting even more to try to knock parry off the table (and by proxy parry-hasting which is the reason according to my tank lead all his tanks are getting instagibbed) necessary for a dk tank?


My gut feeling is no as it feels like I would be gimping myself too hard for other stats to reach said cap.
Parry gib is a non-issue on beasts as Gormok doesn't gain hasted attacks from parrying.
In general parry gib isn't as much of an issue as people make believe, especially not for a DK that tanks with a slow 2H.

The biggest reason he does survive when you guys don't is most likely because he has more cushioning with his large healthpool.
Your best bet is to stack up on stamina gear, as it is the only thing that "mitigates" the bleed damage.

Expertise is still a good stat, but moreso to boost your TPS. Especially on timer sensitive fights like beasts (get gormok down before the worms come), a string of parries/dodges is annoying.

#2162SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sarjin
Originally Posted by Montmartre
If dual wielding of some form is the answer, what relatively easyily obtained weapons should I go for?
[Aledar's Battlestar] from Eadric the Pure is nice, bit annoying with the double RNG though to get the right boss and then have the weapon drop. [Tankard O' Terror] drops of Coren Direbrew and should be extremely easy to get.

To go a bit higher end, Anub'arak drops a couple of slow one handers on 10 man, and isn't hard at all to do. And finally the revisited Onyxia drops new versions of Vis'kag and Deathbringer on either difficulty which won't be that hard to obtain.

For Unholy Im using the PS-IT-SS-BS-BS-DCdump rotation on single targets, pestilencing, d&d'ing when 5+ mobs are around (FChamp, Anub, Ony whelps). Where's the problem? What im doing wrong? Any suggestions?

#2165SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		crazy dodo
Originally Posted by rotflcopter
Howdy,

recently switched from DW Frost dps to 2H Blood (51/0/20) & 2H Unholy (17/0/54). Tested both specs both on dummies & raid environment (ToC25,ToGC25, 6k+ ap raidbuffed) and I found that 2H Unholy leaves me with 2.5-5.5k dps loss comparing to 2H Blood (5k dps with a lot of target switching up to 11k dps while AEing).

For Unholy Im using the PS-IT-SS-BS-BS-DCdump rotation on single targets, pestilencing, d&d'ing when 5+ mobs are around (FChamp, Anub, Ony whelps). Where's the problem? What im doing wrong? Any suggestions?

Armory link: The World of Warcraft Armory (yes I know im exp overcapped)
could be a number of things

Are you refreshing Bone Shield (2% dps)
Are you using your cooldowns: Gargoyle, AotD
Are you using different gear for unholy (less arpen, more crit/haste)
Do you have 4pct9 which is where Unholy shines
How good is your rotation, are you letting RP go to waste
Are you using the correct Sigil, Glyphs (your profile shows you as Blood/Frost)
Heart Strike cleaves, for 2 targets it will pull ahead unless you substitute one BS for Pest in your unholy rotation
Last edited by crazy dodo : 09/25/09 at 9:30 AM.
#2166SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ruik
Hey, I have a simple question about Glyph of Disease and how it 'rolls' with % damage modifiers. For example, if I grabbed ToTT from a Rogue at the start of a fight, and then applied my diseases, would they be 15% stronger the entire fight, assuming I never fail to reapply them using GoD?
#2167SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3crazy dodo
Originally Posted by Ruik
Hey, I have a simple question about Glyph of Disease and how it 'rolls'. Basically, I'm wondering, if I grabbed a ToTT from a Rogue at the start of a fight, and then applied my diseases, would they be 15% stronger the entire fight, assuming I never fail to reapply them using GoD?
Every time you reapply the diseases, your current buffs are taken into consideration (basicaly a brand new disease each time, glyph or no glyph)

So to answer your question, that would be a no
#2168SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ruik
Originally Posted by crazy dodo
Every time you reapply the diseases, your current buffs are taken into consideration (basicaly a brand new disease each time, glyph or no glyph)

So to answer your question, that would be a no
Really? Theres alot of talk in the Blood DK Thread about applying diseases with all your procs up, then rolling them with GoD as they keep the same strength. Was that changed in 3.2.2?
#2169SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by crazy dodo
Every time you reapply the diseases, your current buffs are taken into consideration (basicaly a brand new disease each time, glyph or no glyph)

So to answer your question, that would be a no
That's incorrect. GoD doesn't reapply the diseases, it merely refreshes the timer. That means that whatever buffs you had when you applied the diseases stick until the disease falls off.

#2172SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• frmorrison
Originally Posted by rotflcopter
Howdy,

recently switched from DW Frost dps to 2H Blood (51/0/20) & 2H Unholy (17/0/54). Tested both specs both on dummies & raid environment (ToC25,ToGC25, 6k+ ap raidbuffed) and I found that 2H Unholy leaves me with 2.5-5.5k dps loss comparing to 2H Blood (5k dps with a lot of target switching up to 11k dps while AEing).
Are you including the Ghoul/Garg's damage? Normally Ghoul is around ~12% and Garg is around 3%. Assuming you did add it (note World of Logs can do each separate, but adds all three in the overall damage), unless your raid needed the sp buff (Moonkin and Lock have it), use some other spec instead. You are lucky that you have three viable dps specs!

#2174SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Hatesfury
Originally Posted by Fugh
Marking on the run is a royal pain, is there a macro that I can use to mark? Like I'm looking at one of the bosses/mob and can skull him, hit tab and get a quick x on him?
You can keybind the marks. I personally have skull set to both the numpad1 and one of the thumb buttons on my mouse. Generally speaking if i am tanking i just skull a mob, once it reaches ~10% i change targets and skull my new target. I do however have X and "moon" bound to numpad2 and 3 respectively, so if i want to pause for 1 sec i can tab through and make 3 targets quickly.




My question, and a very noobish one at that, apologies. I'm in the process of switching to a DK for my "dps main", and trying to learn "everything"... I've spent some time googling and searching EJ, but can't find a yes or no to "does haste lower the CD on runes"?? Basically i'm tinkering around in rawr, and i pushed theoritical DPS up alot tinkering with rotations, but i'm not sure if rawr is properly enforcing game mechanics.

All the reading i've done leads me to believe that nothing will affect the CD on runes (other than abilites that reset them) but i'd just like to get a solid yes or no.
#2175SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Ebonplague
Originally Posted by Hatesfury
"does haste lower the CD on runes"??
It does not. Apart from the combination of playing in UP and having skilled it in deep Unholy (lowers the CD by 1 sec) you were right to conclude, that there is nothing that affects the Rune CD. It would be really odd, if haste lowered the CD on your runes, since haste never affects cooldowns, except for the GCD of all abilities. Runes limit our set of abilities we are allowed to use over a certain period of time. It's intended that way and therefor has to remain at this set amount.
Last edited by Ebonplague : 09/26/09 at 12:01 PM.
#2176SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by Fugh
Marking on the run is a royal pain, is there a macro that I can use to mark? Like I'm looking at one of the bosses/mob and can skull him, hit tab and get a quick x on him?
 
/script SetRaidTarget("target",x);
Where x = 0 for no target and 1 through 8 for yellow, orange, purple, green, crescent, blue, cross, skull

As mentioned previously you can also bind them in the keybindings menu. But, if you want to, say, mark the target and focus it with one key you need to use the script command in a macro.
#2177SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3keebz
Originally Posted by Amroo 
/script SetRaidTarget("target",x);
Where x = 0 for no target and 1 through 8 for yellow, orange, purple, green, crescent, blue, cross, skull

As mentioned previously you can also bind them in the keybindings menu. But, if you want to, say, mark the target and focus it with one key you need to use the script command in a macro.
Would I need to make 8 different macro's, each one replacing x with a number 1-8? Or is that one line going to just cycle between 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 while I switch targets and press it as many times as targets that I have?
#2178SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Hellovalotofun
DK tank and hit rating
Hi, I have decided to lvl a DK for tanking, so I'v been reading up on some of the mechanics behind it. 1 thing that has confused me is how important is hit for a DK tank? It is stated clearly that DK tanks need to reach the exp soft cap and def cap, but hit is a bit vague, I know DKs generate threat by attacking, and missing obviously means less threat, but I have looked at some endgae DK tanks from top-end guilds and a lot have not reached the melee hit cap. So the simple queston is should hit be gemmed as priority over stam before the hit cap?

Thank you for your time
#2179SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Hellovalotofun
Hi, I have decided to lvl a DK for tanking, so I'v been reading up on some of the mechanics behind it. 1 thing that has confused me is how important is hit for a DK tank? It is stated clearly that DK tanks need to reach the exp soft cap and def cap, but hit is a bit vague, I know DKs generate threat by attacking, and missing obviously means less threat, but I have looked at some endgae DK tanks from top-end guilds and a lot have not rached the melee hit cap. So the simple queston is should hit be gemmed as priority over stam before the hit cap?

Thank you for your time
If you have problems with threat, you'll want to gem to reach the hit cap. This is, however, extremely unlikely unless you're horribly undergeared and your DPS is way overgeared. As such, you'll want to gem for survivability (stam/dodge etc).
#2180SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Hellovalotofun
It is stated clearly that DK tanks need to reach the exp soft cap and def cap, but hit is a bit vague, I know DKs generate threat by attacking, and missing obviously means less threat, but I have looked at some endgae DK tanks from top-end guilds and a lot have not reached the melee hit cap. So the simple queston is should hit be gemmed as priority over stam before the hit cap?
DK tanks do not need to reach the Exp soft cap (26), although it is a nice thing to reach, however the def cap (-5.6% crit removal) or 540 Def on your character sheet is very important. Once you have a decent stamina and avoidance levels, then get expertise to soft cap and then hit (expertise is better because most DK attacks are melee, although there are a few spells as well).

My goal with tank gearing is pickup the best tank drops I can and gem for stamina/avoidance.
#2181SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by keebz
Would I need to make 8 different macro's, each one replacing x with a number 1-8? Or is that one line going to just cycle between 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 while I switch targets and press it as many times as targets that I have?
You would need to make eight different macros. You could, however, put several icons in one macro and have each icon be assigned on a different modifier (ctrl, alt, ...). It depends very much on what you want to do. If you only want to assign an icon to your current target it's probably best to just use the standard key bindings. If you want to do more (like the aforementioned focussing of that target) you'd need a macro.
#2182SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lightshadow
Can you plug things like SetRaidTarget into a cast sequence? If so, that might do exactly what he wants.

Magic Marker : WoWInterface Downloads : Ace: Raid
Uncle Mark : WoWInterface Downloads : Raid Mods

#2185SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Unless you're not defense capped the Ony trinket is pretty bad, considering how much of its item budget is wasted on the 101 hp/5 and it's use of parry (which is always worse than dodge).

I don't understand how you can be producing such low threat numbers. The only fight that DPS are even remotely close to me on threat is twins and that's largely because they significantly outgear my tank set. Furthermore, if you're looking to improve your threat, you should focus on becoming hit-capped way before becoming exp. capped. Hit will affect your threat much more than parry, especially considering how Rune Strike provides so much of your threat while being undodgeable/unparryable.
#2186SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Illu

The only fight that DPS are even remotely close to me on threat is twins and that's largely because they significantly outgear my tank set. Furthermore, if you're looking to improve your threat, you should focus on becoming hit-capped way before becoming exp. capped. Hit will affect your threat much more than parry, especially considering how Rune Strike provides so much of your threat while being undodgeable/unparryable.

It's usually a lock or hunter, and then I pretty much only mean getting dodged or parried. So that's why i tend to value expertise quite a bit, as a bonus of course. #2187SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Selph

#2188SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Jackinthegreen
One thing I've noticed while doing ToC 25 is that having three tanks for Gormok really helps on the impales since a 2-stack rotation is possible then for reg and heroic.

#2189SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison

The "clickies" for those trinkets have no raid value (unless you count getting drunk or having 300ish health granted every two seconds for 10 seconds to be worthwhile).
One could consider it a negative benefit, since both summons can melee the boss, thus making parry haste.

#2194SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Arthemis
This has been answered perhaps, but i found only 1 reference in the DK forum which is ambiguous so please bear with me.

How does the 101hp per 5sec work in the trinket off Onyxia's head?

#2195SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Amroo
Originally Posted by Tahra
Assume Glyph of Disease is not being used. In that case, does spreading diseases via Pestilence to already-diseased enemies reset their disease tick timers, or do diseases continue to tick every 3 seconds, unperturbed?
The disease timers are reset. Generally you can distinguish between "refresh disease", "(re-)apply disease", "spread disease" on the one hand (this always implies a tick reset) and "refresh disease duration" on the other hand (this always implies, that the tick is not being reset).

Originally Posted by Nahela
Apologies if this was covered as I haven't seen it anywhere, but does anybody know the reasoning/mechanics behind why the crits from diseases via 4pc T9 always crit at the same time across multiple targets? I'm wondering if this has something to do with the crits coming from a 'proc' type effect rather than actually simply factoring in your crit rating.

It certainly is bizarre to watch when you're on large number of targets.
I'm not absolutely positive on this, as I just got 4T9 today and haven't spent much time on observing this, yet. However, I just tested it on some elite Jormungar. Fact is, they do not proc always simultaneously if you analyze the combat log. However, I had similar experiences during the raid today (yay @107k DPS at Onyxia whelps) and I suspect that Wandering Plague procs off critical disease strikes are displayed in the floating combat text as crits themselves (even though they technically aren't). However, this is just guessing, since I disconnected at Onyxia shortly afterwards.

[e] Just realized that you are Blood specced, so it cannot be WP. However, they definitely don't always crit simultaneously on all targets. But it could just very well be, that if you have 30 targets (say, at Onyxia) and you have a 33% crit chance on diseases, you have an expectation of 10 simultaneous crits. It could just be, that those crits fill the screen to such a degree, that you don't realize the non-crits.

#2199SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Diello
Those two weapons are about even if you don't need the +hit at all and aren't human (or don't need the bonus expertise). The proc on Shadowstrike might put it over the mace but the fact that it's a 3.1 speed is really holding it back.
#2200SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by pessadilla
How does [Reinforced Shadowstrike] compare to [Earthshaper] for an UH build, assuming I can get the hit rating from other sources.
For Unholy, weapon speed doesn't matter as much as for Blood and other Plate dps, since a lot of damage comes from the Ghoul, Death Coil, and diseases which are unaffected by weapon speed. 3.3 may change that though.

Assuming you had your 7% hit (with a space goat) elsewhere, the Shadowstrike may be better. Rawr in this case can run that calculation. Dwarf and Humans get expertise from Maces, so that is something to look at as well.

Note the one time use effect of the weapon makes a Polearm that is good for tanking.

#2203SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Deke
I have a question about the usefulness of agi for a DK.

I read somewhere that agi only increases melee crit, and thus wont affect the crit % of our abilities that are spell based (ie almost everything as a frost dk). Is this true?

If so, which abilities are considered spells and which are melee? I've just hit 80 and am really struggling to find craftable/boe gear that has good DK stats, but there is plenty of leather/mail packed full of agi/ap/hit, but I don't want to stack all this agi if it doesn't actually help.
#2204SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Yes, agi will only increase melee crit chance. As a general rule, anything that can be used outside of melee range is a spell. This includes, but is not limited to, Death and Decay, Howling Blast, Icy Touch etc. etc.

#2206SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Lithilara
Originally Posted by SuperSoft
whats the hitrating a frost dk should aim for?
That depends on 2H or DW.
For 2H, 263 and get a draenei in the group.
For DW, as much as you can without compromising on your dps and other things.
However, if you're a tank, you may not need to get 263 unless you're having a lot of threat problems due to the missing of spells.
I hope that was simple enough?

Originally Posted by Kelthuryon
It's the lack of STR that bugs me from using it over the JB as a dps weapon. But perhaps the AGI would work on a tanking weapon especially considering I could add a solid or enduring gem to it? I'm looking to improve my single target TPS here.
If you have problems with single target TPS, you should also look at your rotation as that may be the problem.
Also, if you're prioritising TPS, you should still stick with the Titansteel Destroyer as that would give you slightly more threat. However, if your threat was fine, I'd suggest using Marrowstrike with a [Solid Majestic Zircon] in it as agility gives extra dodge and slightly more hit, while it has much more stamina than the destroyer.

#2209SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
I've got a DK Tank I use for casual 10-mans and 5-man content. I'm tanking in 2H-frost (mostly because we AoE a lot of the content and I find HB comforting). I'm hovering around 556Def (with SG runeforge) and 31k HP. I use a single-disease build with glyph of HB, OB and FS.

I've got three questions: First, I'm Defcapped but I understand Diminishing Returns don't apply before 565 (due to SG not counting for cap). Should I be aiming for 565 Def, or should I be aiming for (whatever above 540) and aim my gear in the direction of Stamina/Dodge?

Second, how useful in TPS terms is the 10% Runestrike damage bonus on Tier gear? I can't accurately determine what percentage of my TPS Runestrike represents because there's always a large amount of adds diluting my damage-recording addon data. The only thing I've noticed, is RS represents circa 10.5% of my Damage Done, fractionally less than OB (~11%), which is also single target. Is it normal to have RS damage comparable to OB damage (assuming no RS glyph, and wearing OB glyph)? I'm not estimating the set bonus is all that given my content. Am I wrong?

Lastly, I've got both Brewfest Stam trinkets, as well as The Black Heart. I'm assuming the Heart's proc is worth more than the 44 Stam difference, am I right or am I better off wearing both Stambuckets?
1 - You aim for 540, if you are looking for gear with high avoidance or hit / exp and that pushes you above that, so be it, but you only really aim for 540, otherwise you are 'wasting' itemization points that could be spent on armor, dodge, parry, hit, exp, strength, etc. That doesn't mean that defense after 540 is worthless by any means, just that you can stop stacking it and aim for other stats.

2 - Runestrike is your top TPS skill, by a substantial amount. 10% increased TPS is a very big deal and you should look into it. The skill is designed to generate a large amount of threat percentage in relation to its damage, so despite it doing slightly less damage than Obliterate, it is miles ahead of Obliterate in terms of threat.

3 - Blackheart's proc is better than the Brewfest trinkets.

Also, using a single disease is, for the most part, fine, but you didn't mention the usage of BS above in your priority list, you are using Blood Strike, correct?

#2215SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Serjo
Simple question about tanking (2h frost spec) and weapon speed:
it is known that slower weapons generally do higher DPS and then TPS but, being Rune Strike one of DKs best threat generation abilities, and occurring it on next melee hit, wouldn't it be better for a DK tank (at least at starting gear level) using a fast weapon in order to use it more often when it procs?
#2216SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Serjo
Simple question about tanking (2h frost spec) and weapon speed:
it is known that slower weapons generally do higher DPS and then TPS but, being Rune Strike one of DKs best threat generation abilities, and occurring it on next melee hit, wouldn't it be better for a DK tank (at least at starting gear level) using a fast weapon in order to use it more often when it procs?
Ideally yes. Since this is hard to do, it's usually best to just go with the highest DPS/highest avoidance weapon you can find.
#2217SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
I'll interpret from your post that Glyph of RS is less TPS than Glyph of Oblit, yes? It does seem logical from where I'm standing.
Glyph of RS is superior to Glyph of Obliterate if you are using RS correctly (ie - make a macro for it on every ability you have essentially and only using rp dumps like Frost Strike / Death Coil if your RP is at 60+). That is for TPS only, for DPS the reverse is true. Obliterate does a higher percentage of damage and 20% raw bonus is a higher damage bonus than 10% crit is on rune strike, so Glyph of OB will result in higher DPS while Glyph of RS will result in higher TPS.

#2223SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by athinker
I heard a poster here firmly believing that Death Strike is higher threat that Heart Strike (in Blood specced tanking). Is it true? The end-game tanking thread lists HS having a priority in single-target rotation while DS is glyphed.
One DS does more tps than one Heart Strike, however one costs 2 runes versus 1 rune. HS use is the correct priority (unless you needed a heal and DS lands in time, then you get half the heal's amount in threat, however usually healers beat you to it).

Auto attack mechanics
Its seems such a simple thing yet I can’t find the answer in black and white anywhere.
How do auto attacks work?

Not so much how do they hit as what determines when and how often they swing?

Are they independent from strikes and spells (since except for AOTD all my spells are instant cast)?

Does haste and presence affect them?

I played around on the dummy a bit and got the impression melee just goes at a set rate independent of strikes etc and that unholy presence does increase the number of swing. Implying that haste would also increase white hits (in blood anyways).

Is this correct?

Another thing I am curious about and lack the knowledge of statistics and hard core math to figure on my own, after melee hit cap for dual wield, 5%, does additional hit increase white damage as a linier function? Or is it a curve of some sort?
Last edited by elf-boy : 10/14/09 at 6:23 PM.
#2225SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Your question could be answered by merely looking at your character panel, or even the abysmal wikis that abound. Haste affects the swing timer, that's practically all it does unless you're casting. You could discover this just by swapping presences and reading your Melee tab. The melee hit cap is not 5% and hit never did increase anything as a linear function. Hit past any cap is pointless in PvE. Hit past the cap in PvP only serves as a mitigation to abilities that increase character resistance or racial resistance, like Cloak of Shadows or the Bloodelf magic resistance racial.

In case it does would it be possible to get some numbers? Like for example how much would 1 SP averagely increase dps.
#2227SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Maxxthepenguin
Spell power has absolutely no effect on anything a DK does. Attack power functions like spell power for all our spells.
