#2231SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3elf-boy
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
Your question could be answered by merely looking at your character panel, or even the abysmal wikis that abound. Haste affects the swing timer, that's practically all it does unless you're casting. You could discover this just by swapping presences and reading your Melee tab. The melee hit cap is not 5% and hit never did increase anything as a linear function. Hit past any cap is pointless in PvE. Hit past the cap in PvP only serves as a mitigation to abilities that increase character resistance or racial resistance, like Cloak of Shadows or the Bloodelf magic resistance racial.
I am aware that haste reduces swing time. Does it also reduce the GCD (provided your not in unholy presence) thus getting an additive effect. (faster swings more often).

How does melee attack frequency work? Is it independent from the global cool down? Is it independent from any strikes and/or spells cast? Does it sit there adding up damage at a pretty set rate despite anything else you might be doing? Or does other activity slow or interrupt white damage?

As for hit, I was unclear, I forgot to mention with respect to dual wielding where the strike hit cap is 5%. The dw melee hit cap being 24%. Does +hit over 5% add more damage in a liner function or with diminishing returns?

As hit gets closer to 24% it seems that the number of misses would start to diminish rapidly at some point. Where is the break in that curve? Or is it a straight line?
#2232SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Thunderchylde
Haste reduces the swing time on your white hits. It also reduces the GCD on your spells (IT, BB, PE, DC, DnD) which means that you do get through most rotations at least slightly quicker (e.g. if you are under 200 or so haste it is better to run imp unholy, see the unholy thread for more info).

As far as hit is concerned - you should only focus on getting the 263 hit rating to ensure that you don't miss with special attacks, beyond that hit is far less attractive than other stats (you do however want to get to 13% spell hit including talents, so your spells won't miss). I can't answer to the maths of the curve though.

Unless you cast/do something that resets your swing timer your white attacks will continue while you cast other strikes - I can't speak to which spells reset the swing timer for DKs, apart from any non-instant.
#2233SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Jimmy
Originally Posted by Thunderchylde
Haste reduces the swing time on your white hits. It also reduces the GCD on your spells (IT, BB, PE, DC, DnD) which means that you do get through most rotations at least slightly quicker (e.g. if you are under 200 or so haste it is better to run imp unholy, see the unholy thread for more info).

As far as hit is concerned - you should only focus on getting the 263 hit rating to ensure that you don't miss with special attacks, beyond that hit is far less attractive than other stats (you do however want to get to 13% spell hit including talents, so your spells won't miss). I can't answer to the maths of the curve though.

Unless you cast/do something that resets your swing timer your white attacks will continue while you cast other strikes - I can't speak to which spells reset the swing timer for DKs, apart from any non-instant.
Note that the effects of haste depends a lot on your spec and ability usage. As mentioned, only a few abilities have their GCD reduced, so the effect of haste is increased/decreased by that. For example, Unholy specs that favor DC spam will get a good deal out of haste, whereas a Frost build that uses only one 'spell' every 20 seconds (either Icy touch or Pestilence, depending on IIT or GoD) get practically nothing. When in doubt, use Kahorie's sim I've found to be a good policy
#2234SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Originally Posted by elf-boy

As for hit, I was unclear, I forgot to mention with respect to dual wielding where the strike hit cap is 5%. The dw melee hit cap being 24%. Does +hit over 5% add more damage in a liner function or with diminishing returns?

As hit gets closer to 24% it seems that the number of misses would start to diminish rapidly at some point. Where is the break in that curve? Or is it a straight line?
You seem to be confusing linearity. Hit past 8% (not 5%, as I corrected you already) will not affect special melee attacks. Hit past 18% will not affect Spell attacks. Hit past 24% will not affect anything at all.

It's inaccurate to call it Linear to begin with. Each % of hit increase gives you less and less, relatively, for example a 50% hit increasing to 51% hit is a relative 2% increase, while a 99% going to 100% is just a relative 1.01% increase. The rate of decay, however, is totally linear.

There is no curves involved, and at no point is there a drop-off, an inflection point, or any irregularity related to maths.

Strictly, the only critical points are 8%, 18% and 24%, and then only because Hit stops affecting some part of your DPS cycle. Those are not related to the rate-of-decay of Hit rating's benefit however.
#2235SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
Strictly, the only critical points are 8%, 18% and 24%, and then only because Hit stops affecting some part of your DPS cycle. Those are not related to the rate-of-decay of Hit rating's benefit however.
In fact, the critical points are 8% melee, 17% spell and 27% melee.

At 8% (melee hit) 2H and special melee hit is capped. For DW with Nerves of Cold Steel this point is at 5%.
At 17% (spell hit) spell hit is capped. With Improved Faerie Fire / Misery (3%) and Virulence (3%) this point is at 11%. Notice, though, that spell hit scales faster than melee hit, so 11% spell hit equals about 9% melee hit.
At 27% (melee hit) DW autoattacks are capped. With Nerves of Cold Steel this point is at 24%.
#2236SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3teiglin
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
You seem to be confusing linearity. Hit past 8% (not 5%, as I corrected you already) will not affect special melee attacks. Hit past 18% will not affect Spell attacks. Hit past 24% will not affect anything at all.

It's inaccurate to call it Linear to begin with. Each % of hit increase gives you less and less, relatively, for example a 50% hit increasing to 51% hit is a relative 2% increase, while a 99% going to 100% is just a relative 1.01% increase. The rate of decay, however, is totally linear.
Actually, you're the one confused on what linear means. Hit does provide a (very nearly) piecewise-linear--or more precisely, affine--increase to dps. That is to say, for a dual-wielder, increasing hit by 1% gives you the same white damage increase whether you're at 15% or 20% hit. There are some second-order effects from procs such as KM, FC, and some trinkets, that change this slightly, but the overall effect is pretty negligible.

While it's true that each point is a smaller relative increase in damage, that is true of any linear function. Crit, haste, and AP all scale in the same way--the damage increase is linear if you fix the rest of your stats (again ignoring some small second-order effects), which means the relative gain is smaller at higher values. If there were a stat whose relative dps gain increased linearly, then the stat would provide exponential growth to your damage.
#2237SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Growler
figured out, please ignore.

#2238SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Alundra
King's vs might, scaling.
Well, i was checking to see when kings would be better for dk's then might (assuming there is only one pally and nobody has drums for kings)

So i did some checking on a training dummy with a pally next to me casting kings when i asked. and it seemed kings scaled very well if you have a lot of str buff's eg, DMC greatness, SoV (200str) and other said bonuses.

Horn of winter scales and so does all other dk's proc's and buffs, but im wondering how far will i need to push str, to see a constant benifit, as i went from about 2000 str without kings, to 2240 with kings (buffs that stay up constantly) that is a pretty large increase, but i was hoping someone could help me out here.

P.s My final str buff was at 2458 exact, without kings, and with kings it was just under 3000 str with kings (with all item/enchant proc's going off for both value's)

#2243SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Jackinthegreen
First, take a look at Rawr or any other DPS app, and go with the greater gain. 4pT8 is a duh investment for DK's.

Also keep in mind that each piece of gear isn't the greatest (or worst) thing in the world, and while maximizing your DPS is always a good thing, it takes several steps to get there. Don't waste your time freaking out about the little stuff at the very least until you have the biggest issues taken care of.


Alundra, base might is 550 AP, upped to 687.5 with talents. Kings will overtake might when the total stat weight bonus becomes greater than those numbers. Looking at the equivalency points and such, kings will guarantee at least 550 AP equivalent at 2200 strength (this is for strength->AP only, and is an overestimation, hence why it's a guarantee. The actual value could be as low as 1800ish. From what you say about your gear, ask for Kings first since it'll be a bigger buff for you.)

#2245SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Nich
I was under the impression slower weapons were favoured (this from a frostdw perspective, anyway) because of their higher top-end. A slower weapon with a lower top-end and lower DPS doesn't sound appealing.
#2246SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Repeat after me:
SLOWER IS NOT BETTER.

Weapon speed is irrelevant, what matters is average damage/DPS. In almost every case, the weapon with the highest damage will be better. Of course, weapon speed is often indicatory of a high base-damage weapon, but, as we've just seen, not always.

#2248SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pipson

In the fantastic frost thread on this forums it's stated that you'll want to go for a slow mh and oh. Thanks!
#2249SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Thunderchylde
For Frost DW you want Slow/Slow as both weapons hit on your strikes (OB,FS,BS). For Unholy, since they don't have that talent you want Slow/highest dps.
#2250SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pipson
Originally Posted by Thunderchylde
For Frost DW you want Slow/Slow as both weapons hit on your strikes (OB,FS,BS). For Unholy, since they don't have that talent you want Slow/highest dps.
Doh! Completely explains why I've gotten confused. Thank you!

#2253SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		ultrafresh23
PVP hit for Unholy DK's
Okay, I scoured the unholy dk forum posts and came up with this:

Melee hit against an 80 = 5% or 163.95 to always hit with weapons + 1% per level above 80 so for pve it would be 8% hit

Spell hit against an 80 = 14% +1% per level above 80 so to be spell hit capped for pve it would be 17%

My friends tell me for pvp I just need 5% as an unholy dk, but according to the unholy thread wouldn't it be more correct that I stack hit until I am at 14% as I depend on diseases and deathcoils to burst down healers?

Someone please shed some light on this as I depend on your opinions greatly.
Last edited by ultrafresh23 : 10/20/09 at 5:32 PM. Reason: add more detail to my post
#2254SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by ultrafresh23
Okay, I scoured the unholy dk forum posts and came up with this:

Melee hit against an 80 = 5% or 163.95 to always hit with weapons + 1% per level above 80 so for pve it would be 8% hit

Spell hit against an 80 = 14% +1% per level above 80 so to be spell hit capped for pve it would be 17%

My friends tell me for pvp I just need 5% as an unholy dk, but according to the unholy thread wouldn't it be more correct that I stack hit until I am at 14% as I depend on diseases and deathcoils to burst down healers?

Someone please shed some light on this as I depend on your opinions greatly.
Spell hit does not work like melee hit. You spell miss at level 80:
80: 96%
81: 95%
82: 94%
83: 83%

So for PvP you need 4% spell hit (note Unholy gets 3% spell hit for free and some classes have spell miss talents/racials).

#2266SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lua
I've got a question regarding Glyph of Disease.

When exactly is the best time to refresh the diseases with Pestilence?
Diseases tick once every 3 seconds, so i assume the 0-3second window would be ideal.

Does it matter if I refresh them with say 0.1sec left or 2.9sec left?
Is Pestilence pushing the timer to 21sec or to 18sec+timeLeft?

I tried using Pestilence 6 times in a row (via Death Runes) and I did get damage ticks.

So I assume it's 18sec + timeLeft, or am I wrong? Which would lead to the conclusion it doenst matter when I refresh my diseases, as long as it is in ]0,3[
#2267SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Glyph of Disease does not do anything beyond refresh the timer left on your diseases; it will not affect the tick rate whatsoever. Refresh them when is best convenient for you on a case-by-case basis.
#2268SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Seraphum
Quick question on frost rotation
I've tanked almost everything but ulduar and ToC on my dk. Using a frost build for my tanking. But my question is on rotation.

As a frost dk, should i not use PS in my rotation? Just ignore that, start with IT then go into my usual rotation? Or is PS ok to use to help up OB's power?
#2269SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Jackinthegreen
Why would you go single disease when having the extra one up would grant much more threat (and some damage) over time? Single target or AOE. many things we do benefit from having both diseases up. Even if a boss doesn't require max threat from you, the extra damage helps anyway.
#2270SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Normally I'd only advise a single-disease rotation in the case of Glyph of Howling Blast. The relative merit is the trade-off:

is [ 1xIT + 1xPS + (the increased damage to OB and BS in 2 rotations) ] greater than [one more OB in the same 2 rotations, but all OB/BS at lower damage]

Remember, while an average non-crit IT+PS is comparable though lower damage to 1xOB, OB has a much higher crit rate and benefits from GoG. And never eats up a KM proc, unlike IT.

I've not seen benefit, from a tanking perspective, to adding a second disease as Frost. Frost seems more comfortably tuned towards using runes two at a time (appart from BS, but that's only because you have no other option) and so Glyph of Disease isn't really an optimal choice, like it is for Blood tanking.

Personally I swear by GoHB and single-disease Frost spec. Particularly when dual-weilding, Rime is almost always enough to keep FF up even with 0/2 Epidemic. Admittedly, I've not always felt totally comfortable with 2h Frost threat generation, but as DW it seems much improved.
#2271SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Arnakh

And if it's viable, is there any one handed weapons that I'm overlooking? Most of the easy things to get are tanking or found in "high" level raids that a fresh 80 wouldn't be able to enter.
#2272SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Nich
There are some nice-ish blues you can buy (Ebon Blade rep, from memory) that have a relatively high top-end, eg Reaper of Dark Souls. To start with tho', I'd suggest you use whichever weapons you have that are best - eg if you get a nice 2h and still have bad 1hs.
Last edited by Nich : 10/25/09 at 9:42 AM.
#2273SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3urotas
Originally Posted by Arnakh
My DK is nearing the level 80 point, and I'm looking forward to Dual Wield DPS builds. My only question is, is it better to start off as a Two Hander build or is it viable to Dual Wield from the start?

And if it's viable, is there any one handed weapons that I'm overlooking? Most of the easy things to get are tanking or found in "high" level raids that a fresh 80 wouldn't be able to enter.
If you have some gold to spend, I'd look for Tankard of Terror in the auction house. A lot of them dropped during Brewfest, and you can still often find them for affordable prices. Other than that your best best is trying to get in some heroic ToC groups for Aledar's Battlestar. You may have difficulties finding a group that will take you in starter 80s gear though.

For some easier weapons you have The Horseman's Baleful Blade for as long as Hallow's end continues. The droprate is very low, but you can also make use of the melee dps ring dropping from the horseman. There is also Grimhorn Crusher from the Argent Tournament, but you will first need to get valiant with a faction before you can start the champion dailies.

#2275SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison

DRW is an awesome dps cooldown. You want to use it anytime you want your target to take extra damage. It should be your 51st talent.

For raiding, refer to the Blood thread here for tips of when to use it.
#2276SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Zelyon
Hello, here's a small question.
I was reading the DK Tanking thread, and the OP is (obviously) a bit outdated.
I recently switched to a blood tanking tree, and I was wondering what exactly should my rotation be, and when should I use the abilities like Mark of Blood, Rune Tap, etc.

#2277SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Zelyon
Hello, here's a small question.
I was reading the DK Tanking thread, and the OP is (obviously) a bit outdated.
I recently switched to a blood tanking tree, and I was wondering what exactly should my rotation be, and when should I use the abilities like Mark of Blood, Rune Tap, etc.
Thanks much.
While the OP may have not been edited recently, the rotation is the same has it has been for the past year.

In general, you want to avoid Mark of Blood because it is hard to use properly. Rune Tap can be used when you get low if you are quick about using it. Note you may just cause the healer to overheal even if you heal yourself with Rune Tap.
#2278SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Zelyon

While the OP may have not been edited recently, the rotation is the same has it has been for the past year.

In general, you want to avoid Mark of Blood because it is hard to use properly. Rune Tap can be used when you get low if you are quick about using it. Note you may just cause the healer to overheal even if you heal yourself with Rune Tap.
Alright, thank you.
However, I forgot to include in my post Vampiric Blood. When should I be using that?

I pop it when I drop to 50% health or if a big hit is incoming.

#2284SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Uhkt
Just wondering if i should have a certain gear level before going blood tank. Currently I am frost and I'm not sure if I have the gear to benefit from all the extra health at the expense of mitigation.
#2285SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Uhkt
Just wondering if i should have a certain gear level before going blood tank. Currently I am frost and I'm not sure if I have the gear to benefit from all the extra health at the expense of mitigation.
For Blood you gain 3% stamina versus Frost with 3% less melee hits. The advantage of Frost is snap AoE threat (Blood takes some time to get AoE threat with Pest then Blood Boil), so if you don't need that spec Blood now.
#2286SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Piradix
Hello everyone, I have this small question regarding unholy and the gargoyle.

Does the gargoyle benefit from the troll racial Berserking? I know they it's supposed to scale with haste, but seeing how it is affected by bloodlust/heroism this question popped to my mind. I am new to trolls and their racials myself, hooray for race change.

EDIT: Nevermind! I tested it out myself and in case someone was wondering the same question, yes, it does seem to affect the gargoyle. When I popped berserking right before gargoyle, it did a few extra strikes during it's duration.

No berserking = 11 gargoyle strikes
Berserking = 15 gargoyle strikes
Last edited by Piradix : 10/28/09 at 6:22 AM.
#2287SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Peinbringer
There are some encounters a failed taunt is something that should not happen. Especially Gormok.

I wonder if it is worth using "Glyph of Dark Command", to ensure that the taunt will always be successfull? I currently use it in my blood tanking spec instead of "Glyph of Runestrike".

How much hit is needed for "Dark Command" to not miss? In this thread there have been posts stating that this taunt is a spell and therefore uses the spell hit cap or that it is a "melee attack" and uses the melee hit cap. What is true?
#2288SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Originally Posted by Peinbringer
I wonder if it is worth using "Glyph of Dark Command", to ensure that the taunt will always be successfull? I currently use it in my blood tanking spec instead of "Glyph of Runestrike".
Dark Command is not classified as a spell, and as such it only requires 8% to hit. The glyph is in place so extremely low-geared tanks don't have a horrific time with it. Past levelling tanking it's practically useless, as you can expect to have at least 5% hit.

As a tank you should be at or near the 8% hit mark; in the extremely rare occasion it doesn't work, you can always try DG, which contains a taunt even if the target does not get "pulled" or comes up with "immune".

Runestrike can be more than 15% of your DPS, which means it's significantly more of your TPS. GoRS is a very serious investment in TPS while GoDC is a glyph that prevents something that shouldn't happen at all.
#2289SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Peinbringer
Currently my hit in Tank-Equip is shown as 6,98%.

However - I am a Draenei. Is the racial +1% to hit already included in this calculation?
#2290SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Nich
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
Dark Command is not classified as a spell, and as such it only requires 8% to hit. The glyph is in place so extremely low-geared tanks don't have a horrific time with it. Past levelling tanking it's practically useless, as you can expect to have at least 5% hit.

As a tank you should be at or near the 8% hit mark; in the extremely rare occasion it doesn't work, you can always try DG, which contains a taunt even if the target does not get "pulled" or comes up with "immune".
Confirmation? My understanding (moreso from a paladin perspective) is that it's a spell. Keeping in mind that there is a 3% spellhit buff floating around, and 8% melee hit should give around 10% spell hit. Some paladins, even near the melee hit cap, still use their version of the taunt glyph to guarantee it goes off; unlike DPS DKs, tank DKs don't usually have the spare points to grab virulence to make capping spells easy.

That being said, it'd be extremely rare to see a taunt resist without GoDC and high hit anyway, not to mention you have a backup taunt - DG - to use if it does resist.
#2291SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Urrumi

#2292SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Clandestine
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
Dark Command is not classified as a spell, and as such it only requires 8% to hit. The glyph is in place so extremely low-geared tanks don't have a horrific time with it. Past levelling tanking it's practically useless, as you can expect to have at least 5% hit.

As a tank you should be at or near the 8% hit mark; in the extremely rare occasion it doesn't work, you can always try DG, which contains a taunt even if the target does not get "pulled" or comes up with "immune".

Runestrike can be more than 15% of your DPS, which means it's significantly more of your TPS. GoRS is a very serious investment in TPS while GoDC is a glyph that prevents something that shouldn't happen at all.
Pretty sure all taunts still go through a spell hit check rather than a physical hit check - they just benefit from melee hit rather than spell hit (this was changed before hit became one universal stat).

#2294SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3enemy5

#showtooltip Plague Strike

/cast !Rune Strike

Has something changed about the game mechanics, and/or is this still a valid macro?

#2297SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by Clandestine
Pretty sure all taunts still go through a spell hit check rather than a physical hit check - they just benefit from melee hit rather than spell hit (this was changed before hit became one universal stat).
Dark Command, Death Grip, Taunt and Growl are all listed as School: Physical (implying melee hit check).

Hand of Reckoning and Righteous Defense are listed as School: Holy, implying spell hit check.

At leat that is how I always understood it works.
#2298SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Taoofss
I've noticed a rune strike macro in the Unholy dps thread, however, the main post in that thread does not mention if Rune strike should be cast every time it procs. Does saving RP for DCs as Unholy yield more dps then macroing Rune Strike into your other spells?
#2299SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Asphyxialol
Originally Posted by Taoofss
I've noticed a rune strike macro in the Unholy dps thread, however, the main post in that thread does not mention if Rune strike should be cast every time it procs. Does saving RP for DCs as Unholy yield more dps then macroing Rune Strike into your other spells?
The only time Rune Strike will be proccing is if you are tanking. If you are tanking RS is significantly better to use in place of DC. As a DPS the only time RS *may* be proccing is on AoE trash, possibly during an early pickup on Anub 25h burrowers, or a really bad tank, so you're free to macro it to every ability if you want, but you shouldn't have to worry about priorities on DC vs RS.

#2301SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3evilhacker
I've spent the morning looking at various sources to figure out how Armor Pen specifically affects my primary attacks as a Blood DK. Could someone more versed at TC confirm my assumptions below? Some of the articles on Wowwiki I found were out of date.

1. Armor Pen offsets the amount of damage we lose when hitting a boss. A boss typically has 13083 armor and that reduces our damage by 46.2% [(13083/(13083+15232.5)]

2. The Armor Pen cap for a level 83 boss is 9906 [(13083+16635)/3]

With these assumptions, I end up with this formula for figuring out how ArP affects damage:

Base Boss Armor Reduction - Adjusted for ArP Boss Armor Reduction
(13083/(13083+15232.5)) - ((13083-(9906*ArPen%))/((13083-(9906*ArPen%))+15232.5))

The reason I'm confused is because it looks to me like the more ArP you have the better it gets and the decision on when to gem ArP really doesn't have a lot to do with how much AP you have, it depends on how much ArP you have.

Here's a link to what I've got: http://spreadsheets.google.com/ccc?k...WX1FhaGc&hl=en

Also, I assume normalized weapon damage is still calculated as Base Weapon Damage + ATK/14 * 3.3+Bonus (Base Weapon Damage can be calculated as top damage on weapon + bottom damage on weapon /2) and this is what we apply as "weapon damage" in our attack's tooltip.
#2302SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• Darkside
You're correct in realizing that ArPen has "positive feedback"; the more of it you have, the more valuable it becomes. However, it's relative value when compared with other stats is affected by how much of the stat you are comparring it to you have. For example, if I am comparing the worth of ArPen to attack power and I have very little AP, the relative value of ArPen when compared to attack power dimishes. It's value will increase as I stack more and more AP until I reach a theoretical breaking point (which is a function both of ArPen and AP). This breaking point has never been reliably calculated (though the math to do so is actually fairly simple, I would have done it long ago except I'm really lazy). That being said, the decision to gem armor penetration will never be cut and dry simply because of how necessary AoE is in many encounters and how little DK AoE damage is affected by ArPen. Furthermore, different specs get different mileage from similar amounts of ArPen, just because of how their damage breakdown is split.

edit: looking at your formula, it looks like you got a few numbers wrong. With 100% ArPen, the boss should have 0 armor; your formula gives a different result. Did you not account for the pre-reduction effects of Sunder and Faerie Fire?
Last edited by Darkside : 11/03/09 at 4:23 PM.

#2305SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Varag
For Phase 3 of the Heroic Anub'arak fight, are Blood Death Knights finding that they avoid the use of Death Strike all-together for dps?

A combonation of JoL, Imp. LotP, Blood Presence (10000 dps with adds up means a hefty amount of healing) and Unholy Strength procs means my healers never have to bother healing our DKs when they don't have PC. I don't know much about Death Strike, but I imagine that it would be better to avoid it in order to keep the Anub healing to an absolute minimum. As such, you're probably better off swapping to a different spec for this fight as the damage loss from no longer using Death Strike and it's consequences (no Death Runes, being forced to reapply diseases etc.) will by substantial.
#2306SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3teiglin
Originally Posted by evilhacker
... armor pen stuff ...
1. Boss armor was reduced in 3.1 (I think, whenever sunder was nerfed). Base armor for bosses is now 10643.
2. The armor pen cap is based off _your_ armor coefficient, not the boss/lv83 coefficient. So ArP cap for boss is (10643+15232.5)/3 = 8625. However, a more relevant number is the cap of 7774 against a boss afflicted by sunder/ff, whose armor has been reduced to 8089.

The math you follow up with doesn't look quite right. Without inspecting your spreadsheet, the easiest way to calculate post-arp mitigation is simply to calculate the boss' effective armor after your ArP is applied, then plug into the mitigation formula. So if you have 50% ArP on gear and blood gorged, and are attacking a fully debuffed boss, you just subtract 60% of the ArP cap from the boss' armor, leaving about 3425 armor, and 18.35% mitigation.

In any case, your conclusion that ArP provides increasing gains as you get more of it is correct. As a general point of reference, the last few points of ArP rating are roughly half again more valuable than the first few.

#2317SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Uhkt
How much Defense past the floor do I need for it to be worth it for extra mitigation?
#2318SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Uhkt
How much Defense past the floor do I need for it to be worth it for extra mitigation?
1. Any defense past the 540 defense cap is useful to have, although not as good as dodge or parry. In fact with the 25 defense rune, you can go up to 565 defense without hitting DR.
#2319SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3teiglin
Originally Posted by consumerboy
Stupid question because I want to make sure I understand a particular phrase...

What is 'rolling' with regards to diseases and how explicitly is it usually achieved?

thanks
The term is usually implies keeping a higher AP/crit on your diseases by applying them with str/ap/crit procs active, then refreshing them via Glyph of Disease so they keep the higher damage from the proc bonuses.

Originally Posted by frmorrison
1. Any defense past the 540 defense cap is useful to have, although not as good as dodge or parry. In fact with the 25 defense rune, you can go up to 565 defense without hitting DR.
Saying "without hitting DR" is misleading at best. There is no point at which dodge/parry aren't affected by diminishing returns, and it's not like those diminishing returns accelerate when your defense skill hits 540. DRs on dodge/parry include all contributions to those stats--defense rating as well as dodge rating/agility/parry rating/strength. They do NOT include dodge/parry from talents and runeforges, including defense from SSG. The only significance of 540 defense is that it makes raid bosses unable to crit you; it is only a small part of your total avoidance.
#2320SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Aryee
I've been doing some reading and I kinda just need to throw this over to the people. So for Anub 25 HM I've been using the following:

IT>PS>Pest>DND>SS>BS repeat - dumping where runes are on CD, with glyphs DnD, IT, and Ghoul.

On the ensidia guide it recommends for unholy:

IT>PS>Pest>DND>IT>PS>Pest>SS>BB repeat.

Is this used as an opener to engage the 2 second rule and then use DnD after pestilence on cooldown? Or is it used as the base rotation for the entirety of the fight? I have been testing both rotations on lvl 60 dummies in org ( 4 dummies in a diamond ) for wandering plague purposes. The second rotation does 500-1000 less dps than the 1st. I've been doing some reading and I kinda just need to throw this over to the people. So for Anub 25 HM I've been using the following:

IT>PS>Pest>DND>IT>PS>Pest>SS>BB repeat.

Is this used as an opener to engage the 2 second rule and then use DnD after pestilence on cooldown? Or is it used as the base rotation for the entirety of the fight? I have been testing both rotations on lvl 60 dummies in org ( 4 dummies in a diamond ) for wandering plague purposes. The second rotation does 500-1000 less dps than the 1st. I have only tested the first in raids and it is netting me ~11500 dps on most pulls.

Just wondering if anyone had advice because ensidia doesn't answer rotation questions on their website.
Both rotations that you've mentioned are impossible due to the simple reason that you have 2 of each rune. Once you do IT>PS>Pest>DND you have no runes left (DND uses 1 of each rune... I knew that:P ) which is why you need to use the following 2 rotations

Rotation 1 (DND ready)
IT>PS>Pest>DND>DC>(DC/Horn)

Rotation 2 (DND on cooldown)
IT>PS>Pest>SS>BS(some argue in favour of BB here)>>DC>DC

Again you could techincaly use BB instead of BS however you're loosing Desolation, Reaping and 2PT9 proc buffs. You can read more about it in the Unholy thread as it is currently being discussed... again

Originally Posted by crazy dodo
Both rotations that you've mentioned are impossible due to the simple reason that you have 2 of each rune. Once you do IT>PS>Pest>DND you only have 1 blood rune left so your only option is BS or BB (not SS or IT/PS for another 4 seconds or so) which is why you need to use the following 2 rotations
Rotation 1 (DND ready)
IT>PS>Pest>DND>BS(some argue in favour of BB here)>DC>(DC/Horn)

Rotation 2 (DND on cooldown)
IT>PS>Pest>SS>BS>DC>DC

Again you could techincaly use BB instead of BS however you're loosing Desolation, Reaping and 2PT9 proc buffs. You can read more about it in the Unholy thread as it is currently being discussed... again
After IT>PS>PE>DND you have, in fact, no runes left since you used all six. The rotation Aryee postet is for 1.5 rune sets, the Ensidia rotation for 2 rune sets.

I suppose the Ensidia rotation is for a talent spec without Epidemic (which is until 3.3 still the highest Unholy single target DPS spec, although some people spec Epidemic specifically for Anub). If you have Epidemic in your spec for Anub there is no reason to reapply / spread diseases every 10 seconds.

Equip: Improves haste rating by 91.

What is interesting is they put Agility and Expertise on a 2H weapon again (last time it was on that trash drop Naxx Mace), so that would also be nice for a Druid as well.

#2327SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3xylotism

My average dps was higher, but I'm not sure if that was the bonus in action or just the better gear. Does the effect normally show in the default Blizz FCT as a normal "sticky" crit, or just doubled damage? If it's not a direct link and 1/10 ticks is normal, that'll become 1/20 when 3.3 changes it to remove Frost Fever.

Is it normal for an Unholy DK in 232-245 gear to be at 5k dps with 5-man buffs with this set bonus? I'm seeing talk of 11k in raids... I don't know how a few more raid buffs can more than double our dps.
#2328SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
5mans are an absolutely terrible way to judge DPS. The fights typically last less than 30s or so, so a significant portion of the fight is spent getting diseases/procs up, which is reflected in your average DPS at the end of the encounter. Furthermore, those missing buffs can make a TREMENDOUS difference. I will typically have 5-6k average AP in a standard 5man run, while I probably push 8.5k average in raids (if not higher). You will also always be missing some important raid buff (be it 20% haste, extra crit, reduced armor or what have you). Finally, the 11k numbers you see being tossed around are often the result of encounters with significant AoE or damage increasing components (i.e. twins or Anub).
#2329SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3xylotism
Originally Posted by Darkside
5mans are an absolutely terrible way to judge DPS. The fights typically last less than 30s or so, so a significant portion of the fight is spent getting diseases/procs up, which is reflected in your average DPS at the end of the encounter. Furthermore, those missing buffs can make a TREMENDOUS difference. I will typically have 5-6k average AP in a standard 5man run, while I probably push 8.5k average in raids (if not higher). You will also always be missing some important raid buff (be it 20% haste, extra crit, reduced armor or what have you). Finally, the 11k numbers you see being tossed around are often the result of encounters with significant AoE or damage increasing components (i.e. twins or Anub).
Ah, a perfectly logical answer. That makes total sense. I assumed Kings, Sanc, Windfury and my own buffs would be the brunt of the dps boosts, but now I realize raid DEBUFFS play a part as well, along with time on target. I also assumed 5man aoe would be about the same as 10/25-man, but I'm guessing the same things apply.

So I guess my dps is pretty normal, now I'm just interested in the set bonus.
#2330SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by xylotism
So I guess my dps is pretty normal, now I'm just interested in the set bonus.
The set bonus scales with your own crit percentage, although I'm not sure if it was spell crit or melee crit chance. Looking at my recent parses doesn't give an answer, either, since the disease crit percentage is always less than the melee crit percentage, but above the death and decay crit percentage. But the answer must be somewhere in the threads.

It is usually around 40ish percent, so definitely worthwile. Do you track your disease crits by looking at the scrolling combat text or do you use Recount or something similar? By simply relying on SCT it's near impossible to really get the correct impression of your number of crits. Besides, what Darkside mentioned also applies here, full raid buffs also increase your crit chance by quite a bit (although 10% is unrealistically low).
#2331SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Esh-324
Testing has show that 4pc T9 was critting at the same rate as your melee crit, minus the innate crit suppression on bosses.
#2332SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3VulcanR

#2334SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Necrolytus
Something I've always wondered, the strength gained from HoW and BoK does it double/triple dip into the bonus strength bonus's from ravenous dead and veteran of the third war? If so(Because I've always assumed it does and can never wrap my head around how to do this) how would I go about getting an accurate number for my buffed strength while not able to get a pally to buff me, stupid question I know but then again that is this thread purpose :P. Thank you in advance.
#2335SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Leaflock
Originally Posted by Necrolytus
Something I've always wondered, the strength gained from HoW and BoK does it double/triple dip into the bonus strength bonus's from ravenous dead and veteran of the third war?
Percentage bonuses from buffs and talents are multiplicative, so they all affect each other, yes. The HoW flat bonus is just added on before multipliers. "Double-dipping" usually refers to an ability benefiting twice from raid buffs, or from two different types of buffs that aren't normally meant to overlap (i.e. melee and spell raid buffs).
#2336SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Necrolytus
Ah, thank you for correcting my misunderstanding of the terminology then . I guess my actual question would be if the strength from BoK is added before or after multipliers are calculated.
#2337SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Since BoK is itself a multiplier it does not matter. (base + absolute values) * talent multiplier * BoK multiplier yields the same result as (base + absolute values) * BoK multiplier * talent multiplier

Absolut values includes strength from gear, totem, MotW and such.
#2338SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Exemplar
Originally Posted by Necrolytus
Ah, thank you for correcting my misunderstanding of the terminology then . I guess my actual question would be if the strength from BoK is added before or after multipliers are calculated.
Blessing of Kings is a Multiplier.

Take your base attribute. Add bonus to that attribute from gear/enchants/gems. Add bonus from buffs, such as Horn of Winter or Strength of Earth Totems, Mark of the Wild, etc.

Take this combined number and begin multiplying by bonuses - talents, Blessing of Kings, etc. Order of multiplication doesn't matter - multiplication is commutative.
#2339SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sabellian

#2342SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
I use glyph of Disease as a DPS and would like an addon that tells me at any given point what my AP is, so I can effectively refresh when my AP is at it's most. I was under the impression Bleeding Hearts was ideal for exactly this, but I can't get it to function. What I'd like, is either a pointer in the direction of a similar addon, or a suggestion as to why Bleeding Hearts won't work.
#2343SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Fugazor
Kinda off-topic but did anyone found out what is causing ghoul missing from combatlog parses and how (at least try) to prevent this from happening?
This issue has been around for a while. The person tracking the combat log needs to see DK casts summon Ghoul X, so that WoL knows Ghoul X goes with the DK. If the log misses that event, the ghoul damage is still in the log, just it isn't added to the DK's damage.
#2344SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Symphonia
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
I use glyph of Disease as a DPS and would like an addon that tells me at any given point what my AP is, so I can effectively refresh when my AP is at it's most. I was under the impression Bleeding Hearts was ideal for exactly this, but I can't get it to function. When enabled it doesn't appear anywhere, no commands produce any result and it's not registered as consuming any memory.

What I'd like, is either a pointer in the direction of a similar addon, or a suggestion as to why Bleeding Hearts won't work.
To get Bleeding Hearts to work you need to have AceGUI 3.0 SharedMedia Widgets, Ace3, and LibSharedMedia-3.0. I'm assuming this is your problem.

#2346SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3epv

#2347SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
The best answer is to spec Blood one week and Unholy the next and compare. Then once you find which one works best for you and your group, you can use sims to get the EP for it.

For current content where Twins and Anub are the hardest, Unholy should always win on personal dps due to AoE.
#2348SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Taklok
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
I use glyph of Disease as a DPS and would like an addon that tells me at any given point what my AP is, so I can effectively refresh when my AP is at it's most. I was under the impression Bleeding Hearts was ideal for exactly this, but I can't get it to function. When enabled it doesn't appear anywhere, no commands produce any result and it's not registered as consuming any memory.

What I'd like, is either a pointer in the direction of a similar addon, or a suggestion as to why Bleeding Hearts won't work.
The addon On Screen Stat Display (or OSSD) displays a given stat on the screen (yes, the name is explicit) in a small frame that you can move easily. You can choose any stat, including AP. The addon is available on curse.com.

#2350SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Duress
EJ Guides vs WMO
I'm researching DK DPS classes to decide which talent tree I want to pursue and am stymied by a major inconsistency that I hope someone can help me resolve.

I have looked up a number of Unholy DK DPS guides, both here at EJ and elsewhere, and found that they concede best single-target DPS to the Blood class. I grant that nearly all of them haven't been updated in the past three months and many don't specifically address 3.2.2 changes, however minimal.

However, excluding Faction Champions, and with the realization that there are two bosses to DPS during Val'kyr Twins and Northern Beasts (albeit nerfed damage to the former and partial availability of the latter), and lastly assuming accurate results from Player Ranking - DPS to Bosses - Death Knight - All Region - Normal Mode(25), of the top 80 DKs to DPS a ToGC25 boss:

00 are Frost,
13 are Blood, and
67 are Unholy.

What am I missing? Is there something simple that explain this disconnect?

Thank you in advance for your time.
#2351SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Consider
@Yoricome: Yes, they still stack. Why wouldn't it be intended?

@Duress: The main reason for the disconnect is the fact that not a single fight in TotC/TotGC is single target, as you yourself admit: Twins and Beasts included (you seem to underestimate the dps gained on these fights by being able to pest and such). That's the key.

A second target will inflate Unholy dps enough to surpass that of Blood, since the gap isn't all that huge to begin with.

If there was a Patchwerk-esqe fight in TotC/TotGC, yes, Blood would almost certainly have high representation.

Besides, WMO records are not a good way to measure the strengths of different specs, for a variety of reasons.
#2352SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by Duress
Specs.
It's not the number of bosses, it's the number of targets.

Northrend Beasts has during the Gormok phase most of the time two targets (snobold and boss, at least if you let melee kill snobolds), until the first worm dies you have two targets during the worm phase and during Icehowl you are frequently not in melee range to the boss (kick) or can't actively do DPS (massive crash), so that things like disease ticks and death & decay (where Unholy is strong) account for a higher percentage of your damage.
Jaraxxus has mutiple targets throughout the encounter. Diseases / D&D on three infernals before turning back on the boss yield a massive DPS increase.
Wandering Plague damage double dips on the damage buffs during the Twins encounter, yielding a high DPS increase for Unholy.
Anub'arak has lots of adds leading to lots of Unholy DPS.

Also, you have to consider how many players play each spec, if there are only few well equipped Frost DKs around who upload on WMO, it's not surprising that there are few aming the top parses. Although it's pretty much accepted, that for TOC encounters Unholy is king, but that does not automatically imply that Unholy is always best for every boss for every player/playstyle, even in TOC.

#2355SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Should those runes be ready or do you just assume they are ready because the unit frames displays them as being usable? I sometimes have the problem that the unit frames (no matter if I use an add-on or standard Blizzard UI) fail to display a rune that I just used as on cooldown (but they are on cooldown). Since the action bars seem to get their information which strikes are available from the available runes, my strikes are even displayed as being usable (even though all runes are on cooldown).
If this is your problem, then I guess it is just a rather common bug caused by the part of the game that displays things and the part of the game that calculates things sometimes not getting along. If you actually have to wait 3 more seconds to use runes that should be off cooldown, then that would be a bigger issue.

#2358SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.366gt40lm
So, I'm a bit confused; in the DK FAQ post it says something along the lines of DnD being a threat multiplyer... now does that only consist of DnD damage being multiplied by 1.9 or whatever the number was, or will it multiply the threat of all attacks done while a target is affected by DnD?

If you need an example, if i drop DnD and then do a Heart Strike, will the threat from Heart Strike be multiplied by 1.9 of what it would have been without DnD present?
#2359SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
DnD will not multiply anything else. DnD has an increased threat built-in, like Rune Strike does. It even says so in the tooltip. It will not increase the threat of anything else.

You could use common sense to realize that if we had a 90% increase from one GCD, it'd really be a no-brainer, wouldn't it?

#2362SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Frost DW is a top spec now and will remain so in 3.3 (Frost is only a few hundred under Unholy, but to some people that is too much), since there are few changes for DKs next week (big ones are T9 4 piece/UB nerfs and SS buff).
The amount of AoE in ICC will determine how Blood does compared to the other specs (if Blood doesn't do well, maybe the nerf to Heart Strike's cleave will be tweaked).

Thanks up Front
There is alot of changes across the board, but nothing that will effect the relativity of each tree's numbers (before anybody jumps on that comment, I mean by a substantial amount).

Having said that, one of those changes is UH DW not being competitive with Fr DW anymore. You will want to be taking advantage of UH DW now, but going back to Fr DW when 3.3 drops. So make sure your off-hand is a slow one now, before you get caught with something that gimps your DPS on patch day.

#2369SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Uhkt
I have about 573 defense, and I got a new cloak.

Should I enchant it with Agil, armor or Defense?
#2370SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Diminishing returns on Defence rating are 540, or 564 provided 25 of those are provided by Runeword, which has been proven to be above and beyond the diminishing returns. Either way, you're well into Diminishing returns.

Strictly, Rawr will probably value 225armor as a superior choice, and it may not be that bad, particularly as ICC is incoming, with its many small hits (rather than few enormous ones we'd rather dodge).
#2371SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Uhkt
And thats taking into account the damage reduction from Icebound Fortitude being increased by the Added defense?

Armor would still be better?
#2372SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
You can't accurately take into account IBF, unless you assume it's used as soon as it's cooled. Simulating an emergency ability is quite pointless. It's not like an on-use dps trinket, which you can accurately say "I'll use it as soon as it's cooled".

Aside from that point, the increase to IBF will be totally trivial from 16 def.

For most intents and purposes, Rawr reports priorities based on weighting. That means, the data you get out depends on how much you tell it to value everything. Is 10hp better than 0.04% dodge? It's a fallacy to suggest either yes or no.

Going by the default weightings in Rawr.TankDK, raidbffed (which is to the advantage of Agi) 225 armor is superior, provided you're def-capped. Closely followed by 22Agi, which also has a tiny benefit in threat terms. Last comes in Defence.

Essentially the difference is that Armor is mitigation, Agi is evasion and Defence is slightly less evasion. Frankly you're clutching at straws if you're trying to work out which one is superior.
#2373SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Kennshin
I've read earlier in the thread that the "6200AP start gemming ArP" is incorrect and that a blood DK should gem +str at all times.
I've also read that ArP is exponential in value and after a certain point (didn't see specifics) it becomes more valuable per point than strength. I'm currently trying to get Grim Toll to test this out.
Anybody have knowledge that could clear the air a bit for me? Mostly, at what point, if any, is ArP better to gem for?
#2374SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Because Death Knight AoE is not affected by ArPen and AoE is very important for many fights, there is no point in gemming ArPen as a DK over strength. Furthermore, it has not been conclusively demonstrated by anyone, anywhere that ArPen ever becomes more valuable than strength at any gear level.
#2375SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3as_kobilv
Question about Heart Strike
"Instantly strike the target and his nearest ally, causing 50% weapon damage plus 125 on the primary target, and 25% weapon damage plus 62.5 on the secondary target. Each target takes 10% additonal damage for each of your diseases active on that target."

about the statment "Each target takes 10% additonal damage for each of your diseases active on that target"
does this means the primary target also takes 10% additional damage for each of the diseases? or only the additional mobs?

or if i'll rephrase it when fighting only 1 mob does the mob takes 10% additonal damage for each of your diseases active on it?
#2376SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Originally Posted by as_kobilv
Each target takes 10% additonal damage for each of your diseases active on that target.?
Assume target A and B. Targer A has one disease, and B has two. You strike target A, and A and B are both hit. A will take 10% additional due to the one disease on it, and B will take 20% additional due to the two diseases on it. There is no feedback-loop.
#2377SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foyle
First off, I hope this fits into the category of 'simple' questions :-)

I've been stuck with Inevitable Defeat - which I've been using for tanking as well as dps'ing (!) - for a veeery long time now (having to go to Acherus Hold to re-runeforge everytime you need to change specs is *damn* annoying). I recently got Fordragon Blades from Anub'Arak in ToC10, not a typical DK weapon - at all - I know.

Since I've gotten it (no one else needed it, and I wasn't certain if I'd get an actual DPS upgrade from it) I've been trying to test my dps on dummies, 1 minute fights, 2 minute fights and 5 minute fights using EXACTLY the same rotation (IT, PS, DS, HS, HS, HoW, DC (1x), DS, HS, HS, HS, HS and from there on PS, DS, HS, HS, DC (1/2x), DS, HS, HS, HS, HS)
for the duration of whatever fight I was doing. I would always complete the rotation so fights would never end on exactly x minutes, but as soon as the timer "ended" I'd stop after my current rotation.

I've almost not been able to see any dps difference (only based on i.e. grim toll procs) at all. The very few times I've had the same procs, Fordragon Blades have had a very slight edge. We're talking sub 100 dps, often sub 50 dps. Now my question is: Would it be viable to use this weapon for dpsing? I imagine Inevitable Defeat (since it has strength) will scale better with buffs, and therefore be a much better weapon for any raid than Fordragon Blades will be.

Do you guys have any suggestions? Should I use Fordragon Blades or Inevitable Defeat for dpsing? I'm also a blood tank offspec, should I keep using ID for that, or switch to using FB for that? Thanks in advance.

Link to armory (in case needed): The World of Warcraft Armory

Training dummies are poor simulations of anything, your method of testing is flawed because the duration of each test is different due to your ending it based on your position in rotation instead of time, and it doesn't look like your polearm weapon skill is maxed. Fordragon Blade should be a substantial upgrade from Inevitable defeat, though.
#2380SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Foyle
Originally Posted by Clandestine
Training dummies are poor simulations of anything, your method of testing is flawed because the duration of each test is different due to your ending it based on your position in rotation instead of time, and it doesn't look like your polearm weapon skill is maxed. Fordragon Blade should be a substantial upgrade from Inevitable defeat, though.
I'm sorry, I was unclear about the matter of stopping after a rotation. I've done both exact timed "events" and stopped at the end of a duration. It hasn't changed much for me.

I'm aware training dummies are not the best simulation - however, before I have a raid again, it's what I have :-) The poor dps increase that I was referring to made me believe Inevitable Defeat might actually be better with stat increasements (kings).

I'll be trying Fordragon Blade in my next raid and report back. Thanks for your assistance

Sigil of Insolence
ilevel 245
Equip: Each time you use your Rune Strike ability, you have a chance to gain 200 dodge rating for 20 sec.

Bryntroll - 2560 (not including the proc "Chance on hit: Steals 2138 - 2362 life from target enemy"
Aesir's - 2416

So, not counting the possible proc, Bryntroll is a small upgrade for me. Any idea on how often it might proc? I will try it tonight and see if I can get some data. Also, it was mentioned to me that it would be a better tanking weapon. Any opinion on that?
#2387SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Khrala: Towards the tanking question, Bryntroll has roughly the same amount of stam as some of the tocr tanking two handers and has that little proc on it. The proc is nice, as it autoheals, and we'd need more information on how often it procs, but I think that I would stick with something that has expertise and AP.

Depending on the outcome of your proc study, it may prove to be a nice bonus though to keep your healers mana up a little more during some of the taxing fights.
#2388SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Tikiman49
Spec Comparisons in 3.3
With the advent of 3.3, I've gotten my hands on the Battered Hilt and am ready to pick a Quel'Delar reward. As of right now, I've been both Blood and Frost, haven't touched Unholy since before the 10sec rotation came about. My guild is relatively casual and probably will take a good chunk of time to clear the first ICC10 wing. With this in mind (QD is the best I'll get for a while), which weapon is best to choose? In 10mans around my gear level, which specs am I going to see the best numbers out of? I'm very comfortable in every spec's playstyle, having played around with them on the PTR, and I have pros and cons for all of them. How do the specs scale in ICC?
#2389SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Exemplar
Originally Posted by Khrala
So, not counting the possible proc, Bryntroll is a small upgrade for me. Any idea on how often it might proc? I will try it tonight and see if I can get some data. Also, it was mentioned to me that it would be a better tanking weapon. Any opinion on that?
Byrntroll has approximately a 15% proc rate. Autoattack and other melee attacks are valid sources of proc. Spelldamage does not proc. The first strike of AOE/cleave attacks can proc, the additional strikes will not proc.

Here's the Paladin 3.3 PTR thread where a Bryntroll was tested extensively.

Due to Ret Paladin seal mechanics, it's slightly better for single-target Ret usage than DK or Warrior DPS usage (SoV uses a second fake autoattack mechanic to apply stacks - this hidden attack can proc Bryntroll). There is some thought that DK would be superior to Warrior due to proc interaction with self-buff talents.

Regarding tanking purposes, a Blood Tank has a heavy degree of self-healing, this certainly would not be a bad addition to such. The self-healing would also be decent single-target threat. No real advantages for AOE tanking.

There is no real disadvantage to using Bryntroll for tanking - for once the proc seems worth the lack of hit/crit/haste/armpen/expertise, especially with the Str and sockets.

It should dish out decent threat. As always the decision is up to you and your guild whether a specific 2H is better for the DK tank or for melee DPS.

#2399SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by grzesieq
While most spec discussions consider top-level gear, I couldn't find any info on spec choice for new DKs in 3.3. Which spec would be the most forgiving with weak gear?
Really any of the specs would be perfectly fine. When you have low quality gear the best thing to do is choose a spec that you like and that fits your play style, and then work on getting the gear for it. Each of the threads that talks about end game gear, and all you have to do is follow the gemming and enchanting instructions and strive for the stats that bring the most benefit to you as per the stat weight for the spec.

#2404SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dharts

#2405SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Dharts
Does the orc racial ability apply to the temporary version of a summoned ghoul, or just the permanent one from Unholy?
Command only works with pets that have pet bars, so only the Unholy ghoul, hunter/warlock pets, and Shaman Spirit Wolves.
#2406SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3lichdawg
I am struggling to understand the new unholy builds since the nerf to SS.

On one side it is acknowledged that SS is still worth it damage wise.
On the other side the spec suggested in the main unholy thread (Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft) does not take reaping. The consequence is more BS and less SS every two rotations.

Could anyone explain to me why reaping is not taken in order to blow more SS, and what is the rotation of the suggested spec above?
#2407SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Amroo
Originally Posted by lichdawg
I am struggling to understand the new unholy builds since the nerf to SS.

On one side it is acknowledged that SS is still worth it damage wise.
On the other side the spec suggested in the main unholy thread (Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft) does not take reaping. The consequence is more BS and less SS every two rotations.

Could anyone explain to me why reaping is not taken in order to blow more SS, and what is the rotation of the suggested spec above?
Reaping costs three talent points. So, while SS is always better than two BS, with current gear it is not better than two BS AND spending those three talent points differently (i.e. Dark Conviction). So the real comparison is SS vs. 2 BS + 3% Crit and SS will not win this competition before a few pieces of ICC gear or 2pT10 have been acquired.
#2408SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3joe_nothin

I have IUP, so i know i have more runes to spend, and more time to spend them in in UP, and it *seems* to me like i'm doing better in UP, but i dont have the math to back it up and i'd like to.
#2409SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Katashii
With Blade Barrier, if the blood runes are turned into death runes and not on cooldown, does this effect still activate? I've looked around, and maybe I'm just not wording it properly, but I can't seem to find anything.
#2410SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Originally Posted by Katashii
With Blade Barrier, if the blood runes are turned into death runes and not on cooldown, does this effect still activate? I've looked around, and maybe I'm just not wording it properly, but I can't seem to find anything.
Yes, the effect will activate so long as the runes that *should* be blood runes are both placed on cooldown.

#2417SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by Montmartre
I've been using Greatness and Mirror of Truth for a very long time. I was thinking there must be some better options out there than the Mirror. But, I don't have much chance to run through many locations where upgrades might be located. If I am not able to run ICC, ToC hardmodes, and Ulduar past the keepers are there any trinkets that would generally be a better option than the Mirror? Well, besides Death's Choice/Verdict. Or is the Mirror still a good option? The dps threads do a nice job with BiS, but I can't reach that level without lots of luck. I'm hoping for a more readily attainable upgrade.

Edit: I probably just answered my own question - Neeedle Encrusted Scorpion?
[Needle-Encrusted Scorpion] is indeed a solid upgrade, but you could also go for [Fury of the Five Flights] off of Sarth 25. On a numbers basis, assuming Unholy 2hand as your main spec, [Needle-Encrusted Scorpion] pulls ahead based on stat weighting. From the Unholy thread we see that crit weights for 2.20 at top gear level and armor pen at 2.93. Simple math will yield the total DPS increase for the trinket, but I can tell you that it goes much further DPS wise than [Fury of the Five Flights] AP buff.

Ultimately its up to you, the scorpion is probably much more accessible, and it seems much more desirable for the generic DK spec.
#2418SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
Originally Posted by Grodin
A guild member has been lamenting about going under the hit cap. Everything I've read about tanking has been in relation to feral, so I haven't done too much research into how stats are weighed for other classes. Am I correct in assuming that expertise is a more important stat for building threat than hit? If so is it ok to drop about 50 hit rating if the piece is an overal upgrade in mitigation/avoidance?
You can't compare tanking stats that are unrelated. It's acceptable to compare stats in a DPS class/spec because all stats, more or less, affect DPS. A tank has three primary functions: Avoidance, Effective Health and Threat.

Is it acceptable to drop Threat for increased Avoidance? There is no answer to that: It may be, it depends.

Going under the 8% hit barrier risks putting you in a position where your Dark Command will be resisted. We are lucky in that we have a second taunt with Death Grip, but if you were planning to taunt two adds, that may result in a very messy pull. I'm fairly certain you get the same amount of % to hit (about 32 Hit Rate per % hit and about 33 Exp Rate per % bypassed) however, Exp also mitigates Parry, and Hit ensures your abilities work.

Which is more valuable? Up to you to decide. Thankfully, there are both Hit and Exp foods which are cheap to make and infinitely more useful than the 80AP Feast gives.

I am running everyday to get the Needle-Encrusted Scorpion, but no luck. In my guild almost everyone has a Death Choice, minus me.., but i have faith that will get it one day.

Thanks for any advice!

#2421SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Triton
As a DW Frost tank I'm having trouble figuring out how to gem my yellow and red sockets for pieces with desirable socket bonuses.

Should I be stacking dodge/agility/defense or increasing my expertise/crit?

Why do people use Dodge/Stam gems instead of Agility/Stam gems when Agility scales with buffs?

My current stats:
556 Defense
9.04% Hit
18 Expertise
Last edited by Triton : 12/15/09 at 12:10 PM.
#2422SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
Because Agi gives far less avoidance, even when buffed with BoK. To be precise, DKs need 73.53 agi to get 1% of dodge, while you only need 45.25 dodge rating to get 1% dodge.
#2423SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Triton
Good to know, I guess I'd been relying on Rawr charts a bit too much which made it look like the loss in avoidance was made up for by the +armor and +crit from Agility to make it a better "all-around" gem, even before considering buff scaling.

#2427SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Pintofbrew
I have a rather extensive query about antimagic shell. Specifically, it's use in tanking with respect to the "preventing application of harmful magical effects" component.

I have been trying to use it as an anti-fear device. While I can accurately time it to avoid the fear on, for example, Bronjahm or the mobs at the end of DTK, I've never succeeded in avoiding a fear cast by Onyxia, whether I'm tanking her or not. At first I suspected that I was casting it too soon, and she was simply depleting it (with magic damage) before it got the chance to prevent the fear effect, but lately I've noticed it's still around me while I'm being feared.

Is there some specific strange behaviour keeping this preventative CD from functioning correctly, or am I doing something wrong? How is it possible that I cast the AMS just before her fear, then get feared with it on? The only thing I can suspect is that AMS will prevent either an effect or damage, but perhaps not both, and some elementary damage (just before the fear) is tagging it as a "damage shield" rather than a "debuff shield"?

Also, are there any other raid tanking scenaria where using AMS as debuff-control (instead of damage absorbtion) is useful? I've yet to locate any.
#2428SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Buffie
Onyxia's fear is a physical effect, not magical & can't be prevented by AMS.
#2429SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lyssa
Originally Posted by Pintofbrew
Also, are there any other raid tanking scenaria where using AMS as debuff-control (instead of damage absorbtion) is useful? I've yet to locate any.
Yogg-Saron hard mode (infinitely useful for melee, probably less so for a tank), Hodir (again probably more useful as dps rather than tank), Northrend Beasts (poison application), Faction Champions, probably more but those are the ones that come to mind at the moment.

The main problem is that you don't have reliable timers for the things that would be very nice to avoid if you could, and they're instant cast and/or boss isn't switching target while doing it. For instance I've sometimes been lucky to avoid something at Jaraxxus, Freya & Thorim, while using it to mitigate damage.
#2430SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by Gephet
Considering a lot of people will be having some trouble picking up BiS trinkets(don't get me started on the Death's choice droprates etc), I wanted to enquire about the scaling of some possibly more obtainable trinkets. I have seen a lot of discussion about the scaling of the new: Needle encrusted Scorpion Trinket on both the frost and Unholy threads, its not a very good trinket apparently.


One thing I would like to know for example is whether mjolnir Runestone is still one of the better arpen trinkets around? Currently im either running with the WFS/DMC-G or Mjolnir Runestone/DMC -G combo's.I would like to know whether its worth dropping the DMC or even the WFS single target for it. would it be a different choice for Unholy compared to frost? Considering at the moment the stat weight between the 2 specs seems quite equal the trinket combo will probably be the same, correct me if I'am wrong.

Would love some feedback on this if possible.
Don't misunderstand the discussion about Needle. It's not a bad trinket, it just doesn't stack up very well to some of the trinkets that might be considered BiS. Darkmoon Card: Greatness is still a great trinket, Mjolnir Runestone, for frost at least, might roughly come out to 187.7 + (10/45*1051) = 421 compared to the others in the frost thread. Note that this formula is largely inaccurate for actually rating the dps increase, and is just meant to give a rough numerical value to a trinket based on its internal cooldown and duration.

#2433SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by mpeg
hi there ..

i have a question about the difference between 2 meta gems.

my girlfriend is playing a pretty well geared deathknight and she got the +21 agility and 3% increased crit meta in her helmet socket. now some guild members told me this gem is pretty worse to a melee class especially to a strengh melee. they told me the +21 crit and 3% increased crit is the gem she should use. she has about 890 crit rating (30% crit) so the +21 crit gem makes no sense to us at all.

now im confused because all guides i've been reading since now told me to use the +21 agility gem.

could you guys pls tell us whats the significant difference between those two meta gems so we can consider why to use one of them either?

greetings and thanks a lot
If we're talking directly from a stats and damage point of view, +21 crit is more desirable over agility because it applies to both melee and spell damage, whereas agility only affects melee crit. Most guides say that you should use the +21 agility metagem because its easier to activate with your gems. The crit rating gems requires 2 blue gems to be socketed for it to activate, most of the gems that we want, regardless of socket color, are red, as in bold cardinal ruby etc. So it's easier to use the agility meta because we can activate without taking a +20 strength loss. I'm not sure if the math has been done, but its possible that using the agility gem ends up in higher DPS because we can socket strength gems.
#2434SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3DocSin
I have a few questions oddly enough

I have been playing around with Frost DW Spec - According to Darks guide it should traditionally pull LOWER DPS. However I do about 3700 Single Target DPS to the lvl 80 boss target dummy, Using Ghoulslice and nighttime as weapons.

And should I worry about crit? Whats the cap?

#2435SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by DocSin
I have a few questions oddly enough

I have been playing around with Frost DW Spec - According to Darks guide it should traditionally pull LOWER DPS. However I do about 3700 Single Target DPS to the lvl 80 boss target dummy, Using Ghoulslice and nighttime as weapons.

However when I go Unholy, using a ulduar 2 hander. I cannot push higher then 2500 with garg and pets going.

My question inlies here. how much Hit do I require while dual wielding and when not? Also how much expertise would I require to be capped for both specs?

And should I worry about crit? Whats the cap?

And when using Frost DW is it better to use 2 slow weappons or 1 slow 1 fast?

and 3rd in personal opinion which sigil should I get for both specs? - Honestly Ive looked and theres alot of indecisive controversy so I'm simply looking for perhaps a little more guidance then put forth in some of the DK guides.
With Nerves of Cold Steel you should be striving for 8% melee hit and about 11% spell hit. I think having 8% in rating will give you the spell hit you need.

With Frost DW it is best to have two slow weapons. This is because of the higher damage output in the damage range (ie [Nighttime] has a damage range of 325-605, so 605 is the high end). With faster weapons, you may have the same total DPS for the weapon, but the top line damage is going to be less, making for softer hits with your specials like Frost Strike and Oblit.

[Sigil of Awareness] is very good for frost dual wield. I'm not sure that a new sigil for 3.3 has been decided to replace it, but SoA was close to BiS, if not best for frost dual wield in 3.1 and 3.2.
#2436SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3DocSin
Alright I appreciate it. So having Nighttime in primary and Ghoulslicer in off is decent for now since they both 2.6 and have tremendous top end dmg?
#2437SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by DocSin
Alright I appreciate it. So having Nighttime in primary and Ghoulslicer in off is decent for now since they both 2.6 and have tremendous top end dmg?
There are some better choices in ICC and ToGCr 25 heroic etc. but slow weapons from the new heroics are very decent.

Mostly in heroics, bosses crit me all the time. Is there an explanation for this? DKs take spikey enough damage as it is, but when my poor low health pool DK is tanking Heroic HoR, I can't afford random crits. I am not talking about being hit from behind or anything, mind you. For example, I was helping my friend with H ToC for a drop for him and in p1 of the Black Knight fight I got crit for his first melee swing. What is up?
#2439SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• Darkside
If you actually have 556 defense, you should not be getting crit. If you are, there is a bug in the game (unlikely). More likely you have broken gear or are somehow wrongly interpreting your actual amount defense.

#2443SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Naerys
Originally Posted by Norm
For an unholy DK with all five ilvl 245 T9 pieces -what would be the best order to get the T10 pieces in?
If we're looking strictly at stat changes that will make the most difference to your DPS, you might want to switch out the pants, helm or chest first. I'm not familiar with how these are acquired, but if its available by emblem, then I'd imagine that the pants, helmet and chest are worth a little more to get than the gloves and shoulders, so if you have a small intake of emblems, then you might choose the gloves and shoulders first. If you are getting these from token drops from bosses, then it won't matter too much, and you should go for the more expensive pieces. Here are the strength changes between each piece (I'm assuming normal T10 and not heroic).

You will gain 22 strength when you replace each the shoulders and gloves.
You will gain 30 strength when you replace each of the pants, helmet and chest.
#2444SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Earantur
It may also be worthwhile to prioritise the shoulders, head and chest above the gloves and legs, as the gloves and legs will theoretically be drops off of Toravon.

#2450SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3superworm
I need some help here.

First, is it possible to click one button to cast Frost Strike or Death Coil depending on range? I suppose this could be realized by using some macro or addon, but I'm not an expert here.

Also, with the release of patch 3.3, it seems DW Frost Tank is quite competitive now. Is the single disease rotation by using glyph of HB still variable now (suppose it's for AoE threat)?
#2451SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		• Darkside
Originally Posted by superworm
I need some help here.

First, is it possible to click one button to cast Frost Strike or Death Coil depending on range? I suppose this could be realized by using some macro or addon, but I'm not an expert here.

Also, with the release of patch 3.3, it seems DW Frost Tank is quite competitive now. Is the single disease rotation by using glyph of HB still variable now (suppose it's for AoE threat)?
FS/DC macro: No, you'll have to manually switch buttons.

I can't think of any compelling reason to use only one disease, esp. if you're AoE tanking. You might end up using one disease for a portion of the fight (the pickup, i.e. HB -> DND -> BB) but you should probably always have two diseases rolling on all possible targets for maximum threat.

e: VVV You can write a modifier macro, (or just bind a modifier key to those attacks), but you won't be able to write a "smart" macro that auto-switches for you.
Last edited by Darkside : 12/19/09 at 5:44 PM.
#2452SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3• frmorrison
Originally Posted by Darkside
FS/DC macro: No, you'll have to manually switch buttons.
You can make such a macro. Assume FS was set to "6", you could bind "shift + 6" to death coil.
#showtooltip Frost Strike
/startattack
/cast [mod:shift] Death Coil; Frost Strike
/cast !Rune Strike
